   <h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Ukraine</h1> 
   <div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content"> 
    <div id="siteSub" class="noprint">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div> 
    <div id="contentSub"></div> 
    <div id="contentSub2"></div>

     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       This article is about the country. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Ukraine_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Ukraine (disambiguation)">Ukraine (disambiguation)</a>.
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       "UKR" redirects here. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/UKR_(disambiguation)" class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" title="UKR (disambiguation)">UKR (disambiguation)</a>.
      </div> 
      <p class="mw-empty-elt"> </p> 
      <div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">
       Country in Eastern Europe
      </div>

          </div></th>
         <td><a href="/wiki/Kyiv" title="Kyiv">Kyiv</a><br><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r994658806">.mw-parser-output .geo-default,.mw-parser-output .geo-dms,.mw-parser-output .geo-dec{display:inline}.mw-parser-output .geo-nondefault,.mw-parser-output .geo-multi-punct{display:none}.mw-parser-output .longitude,.mw-parser-output .latitude{white-space:nowrap}</style><span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=Ukraine&amp;params=49_N_32_E_scale:10000000_source:GNS_type:city"><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">49°N</span> <span class="longitude">32°E</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">﻿ / ﻿</span><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">49°N 32°E</span><span style="display:none">﻿ / <span class="geo">49; 32</span></span></span></a></span><span style="font-size: small;"><span id="coordinates"><a href="/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system" title="Geographic coordinate system">Coordinates</a>: 
            <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r994658806"><span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=Ukraine&amp;params=49_N_32_E_scale:10000000_source:GNS_type:city"><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">49°N</span> <span class="longitude">32°E</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">﻿ / ﻿</span><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">49°N 32°E</span><span style="display:none">﻿ / <span class="geo">49; 32</span></span></span></a></span></span></span></td>

            <li><a href="/wiki/.%D1%83%D0%BA%D1%80" title=".укр">.укр</a></li>
           </ul>
          </div></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p><b>Ukraine</b> (<a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">Ukrainian</a>: <span lang="uk">Україна</span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Ukrainian" title="Romanization of Ukrainian">romanized</a>:&nbsp;</small><i lang="uk-Latn" title="Ukrainian-language romanization">Ukrayina</i>, <small>pronounced&nbsp;</small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Ukrainian" title="Help:IPA/Ukrainian">[ʊkrɐˈjinɐ]</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Uk-%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%B0_(2).oga" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="20" data-file-height="20"></a></span><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/be/Uk-%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%B0_%282%29.oga" class="internal" title="Uk-Україна (2).oga">listen</a></span></span>)</span>; <a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian</a>: <span lang="ru">Украина</span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Russian" title="Romanization of Russian">romanized</a>:&nbsp;</small><i lang="ru-Latn" title="Russian-language romanization">Ukraina</i>, <small><a href="/wiki/Literal_translation" title="Literal translation">lit.</a>&nbsp;</small>'ʊkrɐˈinə') is a country in <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">Eastern Europe</a>. It is bordered by <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a> to the east and north-east; <a href="/wiki/Belarus" title="Belarus">Belarus</a> to the north; <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">Poland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Slovakia" title="Slovakia">Slovakia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hungary" title="Hungary">Hungary</a> to the west; and <a href="/wiki/Romania" title="Romania">Romania</a>, <a href="/wiki/Moldova" title="Moldova">Moldova</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crimea" title="Crimea">Crimea</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[c]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a> to the south. Including Crimea, Ukraine has an area of 603,628&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (233,062&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi), and is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_European_countries_by_area" title="List of European countries by area">second-largest country</a> in Europe after Russia. Excluding Crimea, Ukraine has a population of about 42 million, making it the <a href="/wiki/List_of_European_countries_by_population" title="List of European countries by population">eighth-most populous country</a> in Europe. Its capital and largest city is <a href="/wiki/Kyiv" title="Kyiv">Kyiv</a>. </p>
      <p>The territory of modern Ukraine has been inhabited since 32,000 BC. During the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a>, the area was a key centre of <a href="/wiki/East_Slavs" title="East Slavs">East Slavic</a> culture, with the powerful state of <a href="/wiki/Kievan_Rus%27" title="Kievan Rus'">Kievan Rus'</a> forming the basis of Ukrainian identity. Following its fragmentation in the 13th century, the territory was contested, ruled and divided by a variety of powers, including the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth">Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth</a>, <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">Austria-Hungary</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> and Russia. A <a href="/wiki/Cossack_Hetmanate" title="Cossack Hetmanate">Cossack republic</a> emerged and prospered during the 17th and 18th centuries, but its territory was eventually split between <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth">Poland</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian Empire</a>. In the aftermath of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Revolution" title="Russian Revolution">Russian Revolution</a>, a Ukrainian national movement for self-determination emerged and the internationally recognized <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_People%27s_Republic" title="Ukrainian People's Republic">Ukrainian People's Republic</a> was declared on 23 June 1917. After <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> the western part of Ukraine merged into the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic">Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic</a>, and the whole country became a part of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>. Ukraine gained its independence in 1991, following the <a href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Dissolution of the Soviet Union">dissolution of the Soviet Union</a>. </p>
      <p>Following its independence, Ukraine declared itself a <a href="/wiki/Neutral_state" class="mw-redirect" title="Neutral state">neutral state</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-gska2.rada.gov.ua_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gska2.rada.gov.ua-13">[10]</a></sup> it formed a limited military partnership with Russia and other <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Independent_States" title="Commonwealth of Independent States">CIS countries</a> while also establishing a <a href="/wiki/Partnership_for_Peace" title="Partnership for Peace">partnership with NATO</a> in 1994. In 2013, after the government of President <a href="/wiki/Viktor_Yanukovych" title="Viktor Yanukovych">Viktor Yanukovych</a> had decided to suspend the <a href="/wiki/Ukraine%E2%80%93European_Union_Association_Agreement" title="Ukraine–European Union Association Agreement">Ukraine–European Union Association Agreement</a> and seek closer economic ties with Russia, a several-months-long wave of demonstrations and protests known as the <a href="/wiki/Euromaidan" title="Euromaidan">Euromaidan</a> began, which later escalated into the <a href="/wiki/2014_Ukrainian_revolution" class="mw-redirect" title="2014 Ukrainian revolution">2014 Ukrainian revolution</a> that led to the overthrow of Yanukovych and the establishment of a new government. These events formed the background for the <a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation" title="Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation">annexation of Crimea by Russia</a> in March 2014, and the <a href="/wiki/War_in_Donbass" title="War in Donbass">War in Donbass</a> in April 2014. On 1 January 2016, Ukraine applied the economic component of the <a href="/wiki/Deep_and_Comprehensive_Free_Trade_Area" title="Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area">Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area</a> with the European Union.<sup id="cite_ref-European_Commission_Trade_Ukraine_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-European_Commission_Trade_Ukraine-14">[11]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Ukraine is a <a href="/wiki/Developing_country" title="Developing country">developing country</a> ranking 74th in the <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a>. It is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_in_Europe_by_GDP_(nominal)_per_capita" title="List of sovereign states in Europe by GDP (nominal) per capita">poorest country in Europe</a> alongside <a href="/wiki/Moldova" title="Moldova">Moldova</a>, and suffers from a very high poverty rate as well as severe <a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_Ukraine" title="Corruption in Ukraine">corruption</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[12]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="The material near this tag failed verification of its source citation(s). (December 2020)">failed verification</span></a></i>]</sup> However, because of its extensive fertile farmlands, Ukraine is one of the world's largest <a href="/wiki/Grain_trade" title="Grain trade">grain exporters</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[13]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[14]</a></sup> It also maintains the <a href="/wiki/Military_of_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="Military of Ukraine">third-largest military</a> in Europe after <a href="/wiki/Russian_Armed_Forces" title="Russian Armed Forces">Russia</a> and <a href="/wiki/French_Armed_Forces" title="French Armed Forces">France</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[15]</a></sup> Ukraine is a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary republic</a> under a <a href="/wiki/Semi-presidential_system" title="Semi-presidential system">semi-presidential system</a> with <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_powers" title="Separation of powers">separate powers</a>: <a href="/wiki/Legislature" title="Legislature">legislative</a>, <a href="/wiki/Executive_branch" class="mw-redirect" title="Executive branch">executive</a> and <a href="/wiki/Judicial_branch" class="mw-redirect" title="Judicial branch">judicial branches</a>. The country is a member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe</a> (OSCE), the <a href="/wiki/GUAM_Organization_for_Democracy_and_Economic_Development" title="GUAM Organization for Democracy and Economic Development">GUAM organization</a>, and one of the founding states of the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Independent_States" title="Commonwealth of Independent States">Commonwealth of Independent States</a> (CIS). </p> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886046785">.mw-parser-output .toclimit-2 .toclevel-1 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-3 .toclevel-2 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-4 .toclevel-3 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-5 .toclevel-4 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-6 .toclevel-5 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-7 .toclevel-6 ul{display:none}</style>

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology_and_orthography">Etymology and orthography</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Ukraine" title="Name of Ukraine">Name of Ukraine</a>
      </div> 
      <p>There are different hypotheses as to the etymology of the <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Ukraine" title="Name of Ukraine">name <i>Ukraine</i></a>. According to the older widespread hypothesis, it means "borderland",<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[16]</a></sup> while some more recent linguistic studies claim a different meaning: "homeland" or "region, country".<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[17]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>"The Ukraine" used to be the usual form in English,<sup id="cite_ref-merriam-webster_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-merriam-webster-21">[18]</a></sup> but since the <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_Independence_of_Ukraine" title="Declaration of Independence of Ukraine">Declaration of Independence of Ukraine</a>, "the Ukraine" has become less common in the <a href="/wiki/English-speaking_world" title="English-speaking world">English-speaking world</a>, and style-guides warn against its use in professional writing.<sup id="cite_ref-UKrW812991TU_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UKrW812991TU-22">[19]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[20]</a></sup> According to U.S. ambassador <a href="/wiki/William_B._Taylor,_Jr." class="mw-redirect" title="William B. Taylor, Jr.">William Taylor</a>, "The Ukraine" now implies disregard for the country's sovereignty.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[21]</a></sup> The Ukrainian position is that the usage of "'The Ukraine' is incorrect both grammatically and politically."<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_News_Magazine_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_News_Magazine-25">[22]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Ukraine" title="History of Ukraine">History of Ukraine</a>
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_history">Early history</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:%D0%A4%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B3%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82%D1%8B_%D0%9F%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B8.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/%D0%A4%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B3%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82%D1%8B_%D0%9F%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B8.jpg/220px-%D0%A4%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B3%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82%D1%8B_%D0%9F%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B8.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/%D0%A4%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B3%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82%D1%8B_%D0%9F%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B8.jpg/330px-%D0%A4%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B3%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82%D1%8B_%D0%9F%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B8.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/%D0%A4%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B3%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82%D1%8B_%D0%9F%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B8.jpg/440px-%D0%A4%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B3%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82%D1%8B_%D0%9F%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B8.jpg 2x" data-file-width="520" data-file-height="390"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:%D0%A4%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B3%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%82%D1%8B_%D0%9F%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B8.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Gold <a href="/wiki/Scythia" title="Scythia">Scythian</a> pectoral, or neckpiece, from a royal <a href="/wiki/Kurgan" title="Kurgan">kurgan</a> in <a href="/wiki/Pokrov,_Ukraine" title="Pokrov, Ukraine">Pokrov</a>, dated to the fourth century BC
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Neanderthal" title="Neanderthal">Neanderthal</a> settlement in Ukraine is seen in the Molodova archaeological sites (43,000–45,000 BC) which include a mammoth bone dwelling.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[23]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[24]</a></sup> The territory is also considered to be the likely location for the human <a href="/wiki/Domestication_of_the_horse" title="Domestication of the horse">domestication of the horse</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[25]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[26]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[27]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-cbc.ca_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cbc.ca-31">[28]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Modern human settlement in Ukraine and its vicinity dates back to 32,000 BC, with evidence of the <a href="/wiki/Gravettian_culture" class="mw-redirect" title="Gravettian culture">Gravettian culture</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Mountains" title="Crimean Mountains">Crimean Mountains</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-orig_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-orig-32">[29]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bbc_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-33">[30]</a></sup> By 4,500 BC, the <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> <a href="/wiki/Cucuteni%E2%80%93Trypillia_culture" title="Cucuteni–Trypillia culture">Cucuteni–Trypillia culture</a> flourished in wide areas of modern Ukraine including <a href="/wiki/Trypillia" title="Trypillia">Trypillia</a> and the entire <a href="/wiki/Dnieper" title="Dnieper">Dnieper</a>-<a href="/wiki/Dniester" title="Dniester">Dniester</a> region. During the <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age" title="Iron Age">Iron Age</a>, the land was inhabited by <a href="/wiki/Cimmerians" title="Cimmerians">Cimmerians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scythians" title="Scythians">Scythians</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sarmatians" title="Sarmatians">Sarmatians</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[31]</a></sup> Between 700&nbsp;BC and 200&nbsp;BC it was part of the Scythian Kingdom, or <a href="/wiki/Scythia" title="Scythia">Scythia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[32]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Beginning in the sixth century BC, colonies of <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">Ancient Greece</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">Ancient Rome</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine Empire</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Tyras" title="Tyras">Tyras</a>, <a href="/wiki/Olbia,_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="Olbia, Ukraine">Olbia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Chersonesus" title="Chersonesus">Chersonesus</a>, were founded on the northeastern shore of the <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a>. These colonies thrived well into the sixth&nbsp;century AD. The <a href="/wiki/Goths" title="Goths">Goths</a> stayed in the area, but came under the sway of the <a href="/wiki/Huns" title="Huns">Huns</a> from the 370s AD. In the seventh&nbsp;century AD, the territory that is now eastern Ukraine was the centre of <a href="/wiki/Old_Great_Bulgaria" title="Old Great Bulgaria">Old Great Bulgaria</a>. At the end of the century, the majority of Bulgar tribes migrated in different directions, and the <a href="/wiki/Khazars" title="Khazars">Khazars</a> took over much of the land.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[33]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the fifth and sixth centuries, the <a href="/wiki/Antes_(people)" title="Antes (people)">Antes</a> were located in the territory of what is now Ukraine. The Antes were the ancestors of <a href="/wiki/Ukrainians" title="Ukrainians">Ukrainians</a>: <a href="/wiki/White_Croats" title="White Croats">White Croats</a>, <a href="/wiki/Severians" title="Severians">Severians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polans_(eastern)" title="Polans (eastern)">Polans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Drevlyans" class="mw-redirect" title="Drevlyans">Drevlyans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dulebes" title="Dulebes">Dulebes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ulichians" class="mw-redirect" title="Ulichians">Ulichians</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tiverians" class="mw-redirect" title="Tiverians">Tiverians</a>. Migrations from Ukraine throughout the <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkans</a> established many <a href="/wiki/Southern_Slavs" class="mw-redirect" title="Southern Slavs">Southern Slavic</a> nations. Northern migrations, reaching almost to the <a href="/wiki/Lake_Ilmen" title="Lake Ilmen">Ilmen</a> lakes, led to the emergence of the <a href="/wiki/Ilmen_Slavs" class="mw-redirect" title="Ilmen Slavs">Ilmen Slavs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Krivichs" title="Krivichs">Krivichs</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Radimichs" title="Radimichs">Radimichs</a>, the groups ancestral to the <a href="/wiki/Russians" title="Russians">Russians</a>. After an Avar raid in 602 and the collapse of the Antes Union, most of these peoples survived as separate tribes until the beginning of the second millennium.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[34]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Golden_Age_of_Kyiv">Golden Age of Kyiv</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Kievan_Rus%27" title="Kievan Rus'">Kievan Rus'</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Vasnetsov_Bapt_Vladimir.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Vasnetsov_Bapt_Vladimir.jpg/170px-Vasnetsov_Bapt_Vladimir.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="210" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Vasnetsov_Bapt_Vladimir.jpg/255px-Vasnetsov_Bapt_Vladimir.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Vasnetsov_Bapt_Vladimir.jpg/340px-Vasnetsov_Bapt_Vladimir.jpg 2x" data-file-width="945" data-file-height="1170"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Vasnetsov_Bapt_Vladimir.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The baptism of <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_the_Great" title="Vladimir the Great">Grand Prince Vladimir</a> led to the adoption of Christianity in <a href="/wiki/Kievan_Rus%27" title="Kievan Rus'">Kievan Rus'</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Kyivan Rus' was founded in the territory of the <a href="/wiki/Polans_(eastern)" title="Polans (eastern)">Polans</a>, who lived among the rivers <a href="/wiki/Ros_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Ros River">Ros</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rosava_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Rosava River">Rosava</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Dnieper" title="Dnieper">Dnieper</a>. Russian historian <a href="/wiki/Boris_Rybakov" title="Boris Rybakov">Boris Rybakov</a> came from studying the linguistics of Russian chronicles to the conclusion that the Polans union of clans of the mid-Dnieper region called itself by the name of one of its clans, "Ros", that joined the union and was known at least since the 6th century far beyond the Slavic world.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[35]</a></sup> The origin of the Kyiv princedom is of a big debate and there exist at least three versions depending on interpretations of the chronicles.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[36]</a></sup> In general it is believed that "Kyivan Rus' included the central, western and northern part of modern Ukraine, <a href="/wiki/Belarus" title="Belarus">Belarus</a>, and the far eastern strip of Poland. According to the <i><a href="/wiki/Primary_Chronicle" title="Primary Chronicle">Primary Chronicle</a></i> the Rus' elite initially consisted of <a href="/wiki/Varangian" class="mw-redirect" title="Varangian">Varangians</a> from <a href="/wiki/Scandinavia" title="Scandinavia">Scandinavia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[37]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>During the 10th and 11th&nbsp;centuries, it became the largest and most powerful state in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-41">[38]</a></sup> It laid the foundation for the national identity of Ukrainians and Russians.<sup id="cite_ref-Columbia_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Columbia-42">[39]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kyiv" title="Kyiv">Kyiv</a>, the capital of modern Ukraine, became the most important city of the Rus'. In 12th–13th centuries on efforts of <a href="/wiki/Yuri_the_Long_Armed" class="mw-redirect" title="Yuri the Long Armed">Yuri the Long Armed</a>, in area of <a href="/wiki/Zalesye" title="Zalesye">Zalesye</a> were founded several cities similar in name as in Kyivan Rus such as <a href="/wiki/Vladimir,_Russia" title="Vladimir, Russia">Vladimir on the Klyazma</a>/Vladimir of Zalesye<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[40]</a></sup> (<a href="/wiki/Volodymyr-Volynsky" class="mw-redirect" title="Volodymyr-Volynsky">Volodymyr</a>), <a href="/wiki/Galich,_Russia" title="Galich, Russia">Galich of Merya</a> (<a href="/wiki/Halych" title="Halych">Halych</a>), <a href="/wiki/Pereslavl-Zalessky" title="Pereslavl-Zalessky">Pereslavl of Zalesye</a> (<a href="/wiki/Pereyaslav-Khmelnytskyi" class="mw-redirect" title="Pereyaslav-Khmelnytskyi">Pereyaslav of Ruthenian</a>), <a href="/wiki/Ryazan" title="Ryazan">Pereslavl of Erzya</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Principalities_of_Kievan_Rus%27_(1054-1132).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Principalities_of_Kievan_Rus%27_%281054-1132%29.jpg/220px-Principalities_of_Kievan_Rus%27_%281054-1132%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="294" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Principalities_of_Kievan_Rus%27_%281054-1132%29.jpg/330px-Principalities_of_Kievan_Rus%27_%281054-1132%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Principalities_of_Kievan_Rus%27_%281054-1132%29.jpg/440px-Principalities_of_Kievan_Rus%27_%281054-1132%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="770" data-file-height="1028"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Principalities_of_Kievan_Rus%27_(1054-1132).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Furthest extent of <a href="/wiki/Kyivan_Rus%27" class="mw-redirect" title="Kyivan Rus'">Kyivan Rus'</a>, 1054–1132
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Varangians later assimilated into the Slavic population and became part of the first Rus' dynasty, the <a href="/wiki/Rurik_dynasty" title="Rurik dynasty">Rurik Dynasty</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Columbia_42-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Columbia-42">[39]</a></sup> Kyivan Rus' was composed of several <a href="/wiki/Principality" title="Principality">principalities</a> ruled by the interrelated Rurikid <i><a href="/wiki/Knyaz" title="Knyaz">knyazes</a></i> ("princes"), who often fought each other for possession of Kyiv.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[41]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Golden Age of Kyivan Rus' began with the reign of <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_the_Great" title="Vladimir the Great">Vladimir the Great</a> (980–1015), who <a href="/wiki/Christianization_of_Kievan_Rus%27" title="Christianization of Kievan Rus'">turned Rus' toward Byzantine Christianity</a>. During the reign of his son, <a href="/wiki/Yaroslav_the_Wise" title="Yaroslav the Wise">Yaroslav the Wise</a> (1019–1054), Kyivan Rus' reached the zenith of its cultural development and military power.<sup id="cite_ref-Columbia_42-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Columbia-42">[39]</a></sup> The state soon fragmented as the relative importance of regional powers rose again. After a final resurgence under the rule of <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_II_Monomakh" title="Vladimir II Monomakh">Vladimir II Monomakh</a> (1113–1125) and his son <a href="/wiki/Mstislav_I_of_Kiev" title="Mstislav I of Kiev">Mstislav</a> (1125–1132), Kyivan Rus' finally disintegrated into separate principalities following Mstislav's death.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[42]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The 13th-century <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasion_of_Rus%27" class="mw-redirect" title="Mongol invasion of Rus'">Mongol invasion</a> devastated Kyivan Rus'. Kyiv was totally <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Kyiv_(1240)" class="mw-redirect" title="Siege of Kyiv (1240)">destroyed in 1240</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[43]</a></sup> On today's Ukrainian territory, the principalities of <a href="/wiki/Principality_of_Halych" title="Principality of Halych">Halych</a> and <a href="/wiki/Volhynia" title="Volhynia">Volodymyr-Volynskyi</a> arose, and were merged into the state of <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Galicia-Volhynia" class="mw-redirect" title="Kingdom of Galicia-Volhynia">Galicia-Volhynia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[44]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Daniel_of_Galicia" title="Daniel of Galicia">Danylo Romanovych</a> (Daniel I of Galicia or Danylo Halytskyi) son of <a href="/wiki/Roman_the_Great" title="Roman the Great">Roman Mstyslavych</a>, re-united all of south-western Rus', including Volhynia, Galicia and Rus' ancient capital of Kyiv. Danylo was crowned by the <a href="/wiki/Pope" title="Pope">papal</a> <a href="/wiki/Archbishop" title="Archbishop">archbishop</a> in <a href="/wiki/Drohiczyn" title="Drohiczyn">Dorohychyn</a> 1253 as the first <a href="/wiki/Monarch" title="Monarch">King</a> of all Rus'. Under Danylo's reign, the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Galicia%E2%80%93Volhynia" title="Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia">Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia</a> was one of the most powerful states in east central Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[45]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_domination">Foreign domination</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Lithuania" title="Grand Duchy of Lithuania">Grand Duchy of Lithuania</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crown_of_the_Kingdom_of_Poland" title="Crown of the Kingdom of Poland">Crown of the Kingdom of Poland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Khanate" title="Crimean Khanate">Crimean Khanate</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth">Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian Empire</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth_at_its_maximum_extent.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/dd/Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth_at_its_maximum_extent.svg/220px-Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth_at_its_maximum_extent.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="173" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/dd/Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth_at_its_maximum_extent.svg/330px-Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth_at_its_maximum_extent.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/dd/Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth_at_its_maximum_extent.svg/440px-Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth_at_its_maximum_extent.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1410" data-file-height="1109"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Polish-Lithuanian_Commonwealth_at_its_maximum_extent.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Following the <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasion_of_Rus%27" class="mw-redirect" title="Mongol invasion of Rus'">Mongol invasion of Rus'</a>, much of Ukraine was controlled by <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Lithuania" title="Grand Duchy of Lithuania">Lithuania</a> and after the <a href="/wiki/Union_of_Lublin" title="Union of Lublin">Union of Lublin</a> (1569) by <a href="/wiki/Crown_of_the_Kingdom_of_Poland" title="Crown of the Kingdom of Poland">Poland</a> within the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth">Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth</a>, illustrated here in 1619.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In the mid-14th&nbsp;century, upon the death of <a href="/wiki/Boles%C5%82aw_Jerzy_II_of_Mazovia" class="mw-redirect" title="Bolesław Jerzy II of Mazovia">Bolesław Jerzy II of Mazovia</a>, king <a href="/wiki/Casimir_III_of_Poland" class="mw-redirect" title="Casimir III of Poland">Casimir III of Poland</a> initiated campaigns (1340–1366) to take Galicia-Volhynia. Meanwhile, the heartland of Rus', including Kyiv, became the territory of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania, ruled by <a href="/wiki/Gediminas" title="Gediminas">Gediminas</a> and his successors, after the <a href="/wiki/Battle_on_the_Irpen%27_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle on the Irpen' River">Battle on the Irpen' River</a>. Following the 1386 <a href="/wiki/Union_of_Krewo" title="Union of Krewo">Union of Krewo</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Dynastic_union" title="Dynastic union">dynastic union</a> between Poland and Lithuania, much of what became northern Ukraine was ruled by the increasingly Slavicised local Lithuanian nobles as part of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania. By 1392 the so-called <a href="/wiki/Galicia%E2%80%93Volhynia_Wars" title="Galicia–Volhynia Wars">Galicia–Volhynia Wars</a> ended. Polish colonisers of depopulated lands in northern and central Ukraine founded or re-founded many towns. </p>
      <p>In the Black sea cities of modern-day Ukraine, the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Genoa" title="Republic of Genoa">Republic of Genoa</a> founded numerous colonies, from the mid-13th century to the late 15th century, including the cities of <a href="/wiki/Bilhorod-Dnistrovskyi" title="Bilhorod-Dnistrovskyi">Bilhorod-Dnistrovskyi</a> ("Moncastro") and <a href="/wiki/Kiliya" title="Kiliya">Kiliya</a> ("Licostomo"), the colonies used to be large commercial centers in the region, and were headed by a consul (a representative of the Republic).<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[46]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 1430 <a href="/wiki/Podolia" title="Podolia">Podolia</a> was incorporated under the Crown of the Kingdom of Poland as <a href="/wiki/Podolian_Voivodeship" title="Podolian Voivodeship">Podolian Voivodeship</a>. In 1441, in the southern Ukraine, especially Crimea and surrounding steppes, <a href="/wiki/Genghisid" class="mw-redirect" title="Genghisid">Genghisid</a> prince <a href="/wiki/Haci_I_Giray" class="mw-redirect" title="Haci I Giray">Haci I Giray</a> founded the Crimean Khanate.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[47]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:BChmielnicki.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/BChmielnicki.jpg/170px-BChmielnicki.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="224" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/BChmielnicki.jpg/255px-BChmielnicki.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/BChmielnicki.jpg/340px-BChmielnicki.jpg 2x" data-file-width="606" data-file-height="800"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:BChmielnicki.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Bohdan_Khmelnytsky" title="Bohdan Khmelnytsky">Bohdan Khmelnytsky</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hetmans_of_Ukrainian_Cossacks" title="Hetmans of Ukrainian Cossacks">Hetman</a> of Ukraine, established an independent <a href="/wiki/Cossack_Hetmanate" title="Cossack Hetmanate">Ukrainian Cossack state</a> after the <a href="/wiki/Khmelnytsky_Uprising" title="Khmelnytsky Uprising">uprising in 1648</a> against Poland.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 1569 the <a href="/wiki/Union_of_Lublin" title="Union of Lublin">Union of Lublin</a> established the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth, and much Ukrainian territory was transferred from Lithuania to the Crown of the Kingdom of Poland, becoming Polish territory de jure. Under the demographic, cultural and political pressure of <a href="/wiki/Polonisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Polonisation">Polonisation</a>, which began in the late 14th century, many landed gentry of Polish <a href="/wiki/Ruthenia" title="Ruthenia">Ruthenia</a> (another name for the land of Rus) converted to Catholicism and became indistinguishable from the <a href="/wiki/Polish_nobility" class="mw-redirect" title="Polish nobility">Polish nobility</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[48]</a></sup> Deprived of native protectors among Rus nobility, the commoners (peasants and townspeople) began turning for protection to the emerging <a href="/wiki/Zaporozhian_Cossacks" title="Zaporozhian Cossacks">Zaporozhian Cossacks</a>, who by the 17th century became devoutly <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Orthodox</a>. The Cossacks did not shy from taking up arms against those they perceived as enemies, including the Polish state and its local representatives.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[49]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Formed from <a href="/wiki/Golden_Horde" title="Golden Horde">Golden Horde</a> territory conquered after the <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasion#European_vassals" class="mw-redirect" title="Mongol invasion">Mongol invasion</a> the <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Khanate" title="Crimean Khanate">Crimean Khanate</a> was one of the strongest powers in Eastern Europe until the 18th century; in 1571 it even <a href="/wiki/Russo-Crimean_War_(1571)" class="mw-redirect" title="Russo-Crimean War (1571)">captured and devastated Moscow</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[50]</a></sup> The borderlands suffered annual <a href="/wiki/Crimean-Nogai_raids_into_East_Slavic_lands" class="mw-redirect" title="Crimean-Nogai raids into East Slavic lands">Tatar invasions</a>. From the beginning of the 16th century until the end of the 17th century, Crimean Tatar <a href="/wiki/Slave_raiding" title="Slave raiding">slave raiding</a> bands<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[51]</a></sup> exported about two million slaves from Russia and Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[52]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Orest_Subtelny" title="Orest Subtelny">Orest Subtelny</a>, "from 1450 to 1586, eighty-six <a href="/wiki/Tatar_invasions" class="mw-redirect" title="Tatar invasions">Tatar raids</a> were recorded, and from 1600 to 1647, seventy."<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[53]</a></sup> In 1688, Tatars captured a record number of 60,000 Ukrainians.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[54]</a></sup> The Tatar raids took a heavy toll, discouraging settlement in more southerly regions where the soil was better and the growing season was longer. The last remnant of the Crimean Khanate was finally conquered by the Russian Empire in 1783.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[55]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the mid-17th&nbsp;century, a Cossack military quasi-state, the <a href="/wiki/Zaporozhian_Host" title="Zaporozhian Host">Zaporozhian Host</a>, was formed by <a href="/wiki/Dnieper_Cossacks" class="mw-redirect" title="Dnieper Cossacks">Dnieper Cossacks</a> and by Ruthenian peasants who had fled Polish <a href="/wiki/Serfdom" title="Serfdom">serfdom</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-zaporizhia_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-zaporizhia-59">[56]</a></sup> Poland exercised little real control over this population, but found the Cossacks to be a useful opposing force to the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Turks</a> and <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Khanate" title="Crimean Khanate">Tatars</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-britcos_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britcos-60">[57]</a></sup> and at times the two were allies in <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_wars_in_Europe" title="Ottoman wars in Europe">military campaigns</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[58]</a></sup> However the continued harsh <a href="/wiki/Serf" class="mw-redirect" title="Serf">enserfment</a> of peasantry by Polish nobility and especially the suppression of the Orthodox Church alienated the Cossacks.<sup id="cite_ref-britcos_60-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britcos-60">[57]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Cossacks sought representation in the Polish <a href="/wiki/Sejm_generalny" class="mw-redirect" title="Sejm generalny">Sejm</a>, recognition of Orthodox traditions, and the gradual expansion of the <a href="/wiki/Registered_Cossacks" title="Registered Cossacks">Cossack Registry</a>. These were rejected by the Polish nobility, who dominated the Sejm.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[59]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cossack_Hetmanate">Cossack Hetmanate</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Marten%27s_Poltava.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Marten%27s_Poltava.jpg/220px-Marten%27s_Poltava.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="139" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Marten%27s_Poltava.jpg/330px-Marten%27s_Poltava.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Marten%27s_Poltava.jpg/440px-Marten%27s_Poltava.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1450" data-file-height="919"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Marten%27s_Poltava.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Russia's victory over <a href="/wiki/Charles_XII_of_Sweden" title="Charles XII of Sweden">Charles XII of Sweden</a> and his ally <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Mazepa" title="Ivan Mazepa">Ivan Mazepa</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Poltava" title="Battle of Poltava">Battle of Poltava</a> (1709) destroyed <a href="/wiki/Cossacks" title="Cossacks">Cossack</a> autonomy.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 1648, <a href="/wiki/Bohdan_Khmelnytsky" title="Bohdan Khmelnytsky">Bohdan Khmelnytsky</a> and <a href="/wiki/Petro_Doroshenko" title="Petro Doroshenko">Petro Doroshenko</a> led the <a href="/wiki/Khmelnytsky_Uprising" title="Khmelnytsky Uprising">largest of the Cossack uprisings</a> against the Commonwealth and the Polish king.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[60]</a></sup> After Khmelnytsky made an entry into Kyiv in 1648, where he was hailed liberator of the people from Polish captivity, he founded the <a href="/wiki/Cossack_Hetmanate" title="Cossack Hetmanate">Cossack Hetmanate</a>, which existed until 1764 (some sources claim until 1782).<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Khmelnytsky, deserted by his Tatar allies, suffered a crushing deafeat at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Berestechko" title="Battle of Berestechko">Battle of Berestechko</a> in 1651, and turned to the Russian tsar for help. In 1654, Khmelnytsky was subject to the <a href="/wiki/Pereyaslav_Council" title="Pereyaslav Council">Pereyaslav Council</a>, forming a military and political alliance with Russia that acknowledged loyalty to the Russian tsar. </p>
      <p>In 1657–1686 came "<a href="/wiki/The_Ruin_(Ukrainian_history)" title="The Ruin (Ukrainian history)">The Ruin</a>", a devastating 30-year war amongst Russia, Poland, the <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Khanate" title="Crimean Khanate">Crimean Khanate</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Cossacks" title="Cossacks">Cossacks</a> for control of Ukraine, which occurred at about the same time as the <a href="/wiki/Deluge_(history)" title="Deluge (history)">Deluge</a> of Poland. The wars escalated in intensity with hundreds of thousands of deaths. The "<a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Perpetual_Peace_(1686)" title="Treaty of Perpetual Peace (1686)">Treaty of Perpetual Peace</a>" between Russia and Poland in 1686 divided the lands of the Cossack Hetmanate between them, reducing the portion over which Poland had claimed sovereignty. </p>
      <p>In 1709, Cossack Hetman <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Mazepa" title="Ivan Mazepa">Ivan Mazepa</a> (1639–1709) defected to <a href="/wiki/Sweden" title="Sweden">Sweden</a> against Russia in the <a href="/wiki/Great_Northern_War" title="Great Northern War">Great Northern War</a> (1700–1721). Eventually Tsar <a href="/wiki/Peter_the_Great" title="Peter the Great">Peter</a> recognized that to consolidate and modernize Russia's political and economic power it was necessary to do away with the Cossack Hetmanate and Ukrainian and Cossack aspirations to autonomy. Mazepa died in exile after fleeing from the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Poltava" title="Battle of Poltava">Battle of Poltava</a> (1709), in which the Swedes and their Cossack allies suffered a catastrophic defeat. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Pylyp-orlyk-constitution-1710.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Pylyp-orlyk-constitution-1710.jpg/170px-Pylyp-orlyk-constitution-1710.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="245" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Pylyp-orlyk-constitution-1710.jpg/255px-Pylyp-orlyk-constitution-1710.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Pylyp-orlyk-constitution-1710.jpg/340px-Pylyp-orlyk-constitution-1710.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2000" data-file-height="2879"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Pylyp-orlyk-constitution-1710.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The first page of the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Pylyp_Orlyk" title="Constitution of Pylyp Orlyk">Bendery Constitution</a>. This copy in Latin was probably penned by Hetman <a href="/wiki/Pylyp_Orlyk" title="Pylyp Orlyk">Pylyp Orlyk</a>. The original is kept in the <a href="/wiki/National_Archives_of_Sweden" title="National Archives of Sweden">National Archives of Sweden</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Pylyp_Orlyk" title="Constitution of Pylyp Orlyk">Constitution of Pylyp Orlyk</a> or Pacts and Constitutions of Rights and Freedoms of the Zaporizhian Host was a 1710 constitutional document written by <a href="/wiki/Hetman" title="Hetman">Hetman</a> <a href="/wiki/Pylyp_Orlyk" title="Pylyp Orlyk">Pylyp Orlyk</a>, a Cossack of Ukraine, then within the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth">Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[61]</a></sup> It established a standard for the <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_powers" title="Separation of powers">separation of powers</a> in government between the legislative, executive, and judiciary branches, well before the publication of <a href="/wiki/Montesquieu" title="Montesquieu">Montesquieu</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/The_Spirit_of_the_Laws" title="The Spirit of the Laws">The Spirit of the Laws</a></i>. The Constitution limited the executive authority of the hetman, and established a democratically elected Cossack parliament called the General Council. The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Pylyp_Orlyk" title="Constitution of Pylyp Orlyk">Constitution of Pylyp Orlyk</a> was unique for its period, and was one of the first state constitutions in Europe.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2015)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>The hetmanate was abolished in 1764; the <a href="/wiki/Zaporozhian_Sich" title="Zaporozhian Sich">Zaporozhian Sich</a> was abolished in 1775, as Russia centralised control over its lands. As part of the <a href="/wiki/Partitions_of_Poland" title="Partitions of Poland">Partitions of Poland</a> in 1772, 1793 and 1795, the Ukrainian lands west of the Dnieper were divided between Russia and Austria. From 1737 to 1834, expansion into the northern Black Sea littoral and the eastern <a href="/wiki/Danube" title="Danube">Danube</a> valley was a cornerstone of Russian foreign policy.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2015)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Kirill_Razumovsky_Tokke.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Kirill_Razumovsky_Tokke.jpg/170px-Kirill_Razumovsky_Tokke.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="221" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Kirill_Razumovsky_Tokke.jpg/255px-Kirill_Razumovsky_Tokke.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Kirill_Razumovsky_Tokke.jpg/340px-Kirill_Razumovsky_Tokke.jpg 2x" data-file-width="916" data-file-height="1192"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kirill_Razumovsky_Tokke.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Kirill_Razumovski" title="Kirill Razumovski">Kirill Razumovski</a>, the last Hetman of left- and right-bank Ukraine 1750–1764 and the first person to declare Ukraine to be a sovereign state
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Lithuanians and Poles controlled vast estates in Ukraine, and were a law unto themselves. Judicial rulings from <a href="/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w" title="Kraków">Kraków</a> were routinely flouted, while peasants were heavily taxed and practically tied to the land as <a href="/wiki/Serfdom" title="Serfdom">serfs</a>. Occasionally the landowners battled each other using armies of Ukrainian peasants. The Poles and Lithuanians were Roman Catholics and tried with some success to convert the Orthodox lesser nobility. In 1596, they set up the "Greek-Catholic" or <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Greek_Catholic_Church" title="Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church">Uniate Church</a>; it dominates western Ukraine to this day. Religious differentiation left the Ukrainian Orthodox peasants leaderless, as they were reluctant to follow the Ukrainian nobles.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[62]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Cossacks led an uprising, called <a href="/wiki/Koliyivshchyna" title="Koliyivshchyna">Koliyivshchyna</a>, starting in the Ukrainian borderlands of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth in 1768. Ethnicity was one root cause of this revolt, which included the <a href="/wiki/Massacre_of_Uman" title="Massacre of Uman">Massacre of Uman</a> that killed tens of thousands of Poles and Jews. Religious warfare also broke out among Ukrainian groups. Increasing conflict between Uniate and Orthodox parishes along the newly reinforced Polish-Russian border on the <a href="/wiki/Dnieper" title="Dnieper">Dnieper</a> in the time of <a href="/wiki/Catherine_the_Great" title="Catherine the Great">Catherine the Great</a> set the stage for the uprising. As Uniate religious practices had become more Latinized, Orthodoxy in this region drew even closer into dependence on the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Orthodox_Church" title="Russian Orthodox Church">Russian Orthodox Church</a>. Confessional tensions also reflected opposing Polish and Russian political allegiances.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[63]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>After the <a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Empire" title="Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Empire">annexation of Crimea by the Russian Empire</a> in 1783, <a href="/wiki/Novorossiya" title="Novorossiya">Novorossiya</a> was settled by Ukrainians and Russians.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[64]</a></sup> Despite promises in the Treaty of Pereyaslav, the Ukrainian elite and the Cossacks never received the freedoms and the autonomy they had expected. However, within the Empire, Ukrainians rose to the highest Russian state and church offices.<sup class="reference" id="ref_Anone"><a href="#endnote_Anone">[a]</a></sup> In a later period, <a href="/wiki/Tsarist_autocracy" title="Tsarist autocracy">tsarists</a> established a policy of <a href="/wiki/Russification" title="Russification">Russification</a>, suppressing the use of the Ukrainian language in print and in public.<sup id="cite_ref-censor_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-censor-68">[65]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="19th_century.2C_World_War_I_and_revolution"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="19th_century,_World_War_I_and_revolution">19th century, World War I and revolution</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Southwestern_Krai" title="Southwestern Krai">Southwestern Krai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kharkov_Governorate" title="Kharkov Governorate">Kharkov Governorate</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Chernigov_Governorate" title="Chernigov Governorate">Chernigov Governorate</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Ukraine_during_World_War_I" title="Ukraine during World War I">Ukraine during World War I</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_War_of_Independence" title="Ukrainian War of Independence">Ukrainian War of Independence</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_Civil_War" title="Russian Civil War">Russian Civil War</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ukraine_after_the_Russian_Revolution" title="Ukraine after the Russian Revolution">Ukraine after the Russian Revolution</a>
      </div> 
      <p>In the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, the territory of today's Ukraine was included in the <a href="/wiki/Governorate_(Russia)" title="Governorate (Russia)">governorates</a> of <a href="/wiki/Chernigov_Governorate" title="Chernigov Governorate">Chernihiv (Chernigov in Russian)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kharkov_Governorate" title="Kharkov Governorate">Kharkiv (Kharkov)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kiev_Governorate_(1708%E2%80%931764)" title="Kiev Governorate (1708–1764)">Kyiv 1708–1764</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Little_Russia_Governorate_(1764%E2%80%931781)" title="Little Russia Governorate (1764–1781)">Little Russia 1764–1781</a>, <a href="/wiki/Podolian_Governorate" title="Podolian Governorate">Podillia (Podolie)</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Volhynian_Governorate" title="Volhynian Governorate">Volyn</a> (Volhynia)—with all but the first two informally grouped into the <a href="/wiki/Southwestern_Krai" title="Southwestern Krai">Southwestern Krai</a>. </p>
      <p>After the <a href="/wiki/Russo-Turkish_War_(1768%E2%80%931774)" title="Russo-Turkish War (1768–1774)">Russo-Turkish War (1768–1774)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Catherine_the_Great" title="Catherine the Great">Catherine the Great</a> and her immediate successors encouraged German immigration into Ukraine and especially <a href="/wiki/Crimea_Germans" title="Crimea Germans">into Crimea</a>, to thin the previously dominant Turk population and encourage agriculture.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[66]</a></sup> Numerous Ukrainians, Russians, Germans, <a href="/wiki/Bulgarians_in_Ukraine" title="Bulgarians in Ukraine">Bulgarians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Serbs_in_Ukraine" title="Serbs in Ukraine">Serbs</a> and <a href="/wiki/Greeks_in_Ukraine" title="Greeks in Ukraine">Greeks</a> moved into the northern <a href="/wiki/Pontic%E2%80%93Caspian_steppe" title="Pontic–Caspian steppe">Black Sea steppe</a> formerly known as the "<a href="/wiki/Wild_Fields" title="Wild Fields">Wild Fields</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[67]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[68]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>With growing urbanization and modernization, and a cultural trend toward <a href="/wiki/Romantic_nationalism" title="Romantic nationalism">romantic nationalism</a>, a Ukrainian <a href="/wiki/Intelligentsia" title="Intelligentsia">intelligentsia</a> committed to national rebirth and social justice emerged. The serf-turned-national-poet <a href="/wiki/Taras_Shevchenko" title="Taras Shevchenko">Taras Shevchenko</a> (1814–1861) and the political theorist <a href="/wiki/Mykhailo_Drahomanov" title="Mykhailo Drahomanov">Mykhailo Drahomanov</a> (1841–1895) led the growing nationalist movement.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[69]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[70]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:1904_Map_showing_Ukraine_region_before_unification.pdf" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/1904_Map_showing_Ukraine_region_before_unification.pdf/page1-220px-1904_Map_showing_Ukraine_region_before_unification.pdf.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="211" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/1904_Map_showing_Ukraine_region_before_unification.pdf/page1-330px-1904_Map_showing_Ukraine_region_before_unification.pdf.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/1904_Map_showing_Ukraine_region_before_unification.pdf/page1-440px-1904_Map_showing_Ukraine_region_before_unification.pdf.jpg 2x" data-file-width="718" data-file-height="688"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:1904_Map_showing_Ukraine_region_before_unification.pdf" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A map from 1904 showing <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_administrative_division_of_Russia" title="History of the administrative division of Russia">administrative units</a> of <a href="/wiki/Little_Russia" title="Little Russia">Little Russia</a>, South Russia and West Russia within the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian Empire</a> prior to Ukrainian independence
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Beginning in the 19th century, there was migration from Ukraine to distant areas of the Russian Empire. According to the 1897 census, there were 223,000 ethnic Ukrainians in <a href="/wiki/Siberia" title="Siberia">Siberia</a> and 102,000 in <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[71]</a></sup> An additional 1.6 million emigrated to the east in the ten years after the opening of the <a href="/wiki/Trans-Siberian_Railway" title="Trans-Siberian Railway">Trans-Siberian Railway</a> in 1906.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[72]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Russian_Far_East" title="Russian Far East">Far Eastern</a> areas with an ethnic Ukrainian population became known as <a href="/wiki/Green_Ukraine" title="Green Ukraine">Green Ukraine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[73]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Nationalist and socialist parties developed in the late 19th century. Austrian <a href="/wiki/Galicia_(eastern_Europe)" class="mw-redirect" title="Galicia (eastern Europe)">Galicia</a>, under the relatively lenient rule of the <a href="/wiki/Habsburgs" class="mw-redirect" title="Habsburgs">Habsburgs</a>, became the centre of the nationalist movement.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[74]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Ukrainians entered <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a> on the side of both the <a href="/wiki/Central_Powers" title="Central Powers">Central Powers</a>, under Austria, and the <a href="/wiki/Triple_Entente" title="Triple Entente">Triple Entente</a>, under Russia. 3.5 million Ukrainians fought with the <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_Imperial_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Military history of Imperial Russia">Imperial Russian Army</a>, while 250,000 fought for the <a href="/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_Army" title="Austro-Hungarian Army">Austro-Hungarian Army</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[75]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">Austro-Hungarian</a> authorities established the Ukrainian Legion to fight against the Russian Empire. This became the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Galician_Army" title="Ukrainian Galician Army">Ukrainian Galician Army</a> that fought against the Bolsheviks and Poles in the post-World War I period (1919–23). Those suspected of Russophile sentiments in Austria were treated harshly.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[76]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Polish_troops_in_Kiev.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Polish_troops_in_Kiev.jpg/220px-Polish_troops_in_Kiev.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="160" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Polish_troops_in_Kiev.jpg/330px-Polish_troops_in_Kiev.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Polish_troops_in_Kiev.jpg/440px-Polish_troops_in_Kiev.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="873"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Polish_troops_in_Kiev.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Kyiv_Offensive_(1920)" class="mw-redirect" title="Kyiv Offensive (1920)">Polish troops enter Kyiv</a> in May 1920 during the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Soviet_War" title="Polish–Soviet War">Polish–Soviet War</a> in which Ukrainians sided with Poland against the <a href="/wiki/Bolsheviks" title="Bolsheviks">Bolsheviks</a>. Following the <a href="/wiki/Peace_of_Riga" title="Peace of Riga">Peace of Riga</a> signed on 18 March 1921, Poland took control of modern-day western Ukraine while Soviet forces took control of eastern Ukraine.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>World War I destroyed both empires. The <a href="/wiki/Russian_Revolution_of_1917" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian Revolution of 1917">Russian Revolution of 1917</a> led to the founding of the Soviet Union under the <a href="/wiki/Bolshevik" class="mw-redirect" title="Bolshevik">Bolsheviks</a>, and subsequent <a href="/wiki/Civil_war_in_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Civil war in Russia">civil war in Russia</a>. A Ukrainian national movement for self-determination emerged, with heavy Communist and Socialist influence. Several Ukrainian states briefly emerged: the internationally recognized <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_People%27s_Republic" title="Ukrainian People's Republic">Ukrainian People's Republic</a> (<i>UNR</i>, the predecessor of modern Ukraine, was declared on 23 June 1917 proclaimed at first as a part of the Russian Republic; after the <a href="/wiki/Bolshevik_Revolution" class="mw-redirect" title="Bolshevik Revolution">Bolshevik Revolution</a>, the Ukrainian People's Republic proclaimed its independence on 25 January 1918), the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_State" title="Ukrainian State">Hetmanate</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Directorate_of_Ukraine" title="Directorate of Ukraine">Directorate</a> and the pro-Bolshevik <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic">Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic</a> (or Soviet Ukraine) successively established territories in the former Russian Empire; while the <a href="/wiki/West_Ukrainian_People%27s_Republic" title="West Ukrainian People's Republic">West Ukrainian People's Republic</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Hutsul_Republic" title="Hutsul Republic">Hutsul Republic</a> emerged briefly in the Ukrainian lands of former Austro-Hungarian territory.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[77]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The short lived <a href="/wiki/Act_Zluky" title="Act Zluky">Act Zluky</a> (Unification Act) was an agreement signed on 22 January 1919 by the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_People%27s_Republic" title="Ukrainian People's Republic">Ukrainian People's Republic</a> and the <a href="/wiki/West_Ukrainian_People%27s_Republic" title="West Ukrainian People's Republic">West Ukrainian People's Republic</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Saint_Sophia_Cathedral_in_Kyiv" class="mw-redirect" title="Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kyiv">St. Sophia Square</a> in <a href="/wiki/Kyiv" title="Kyiv">Kyiv</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Basilevsky2016_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Basilevsky2016-81">[78]</a></sup> This led to civil war, and an <a href="/wiki/Anarchism" title="Anarchism">anarchist</a> movement called the <a href="/wiki/Black_Guards" title="Black Guards">Black Army</a> (later renamed to <a href="/wiki/The_Revolutionary_Insurrectionary_Army_of_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="The Revolutionary Insurrectionary Army of Ukraine">The Revolutionary Insurrectionary Army of Ukraine</a>) developed in Southern Ukraine under the command of the anarchist <a href="/wiki/Nestor_Makhno" title="Nestor Makhno">Nestor Makhno</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Civil_War" title="Russian Civil War">Russian Civil War</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[79]</a></sup> They protected the operation of "<a href="/wiki/Soviet_(council)" title="Soviet (council)">free soviets</a>" and <a href="/wiki/Libertarian_socialism" title="Libertarian socialism">libertarian</a> <a href="/wiki/Communes" class="mw-redirect" title="Communes">communes</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Free_Territory" class="mw-redirect" title="Free Territory">Free Territory</a>, an attempt to form a <a href="/wiki/Stateless_society" title="Stateless society">stateless</a> <a href="/wiki/Anarchism" title="Anarchism">anarchist</a> society from 1918 to 1921 during the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_War_of_Independence" title="Ukrainian War of Independence">Ukrainian Revolution</a>, fighting both the tsarist <a href="/wiki/Armed_Forces_of_South_Russia" title="Armed Forces of South Russia">White Army</a> under <a href="/wiki/Anton_Denikin" title="Anton Denikin">Denikin</a> and later the <a href="/wiki/Red_Army" title="Red Army">Red Army</a> under <a href="/wiki/Leon_Trotsky" title="Leon Trotsky">Trotsky</a>, before being defeated by the latter in August 1921. </p>
      <p>Poland defeated Western Ukraine in the <a href="/wiki/Polish-Ukrainian_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Polish-Ukrainian War">Polish-Ukrainian War</a>, but failed against the Bolsheviks in <a href="/wiki/Kyiv_Offensive_(1920)" class="mw-redirect" title="Kyiv Offensive (1920)">an offensive against Kyiv</a>. According to the <a href="/wiki/Peace_of_Riga" title="Peace of Riga">Peace of Riga</a>, western Ukraine was incorporated into Poland, which in turn recognised the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic in March 1919. With establishment of the Soviet power, Ukraine lost half of its territory, while Moldavian autonomy was established on the left bank of the <a href="/wiki/Dniester" title="Dniester">Dniester</a> River. Ukraine became a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/Union_of_Soviet_Socialist_Republics" class="mw-redirect" title="Union of Soviet Socialist Republics">Union of Soviet Socialist Republics</a> in December 1922.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-83">[80]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="Western_Ukraine.2C_Carpathian_Ruthenia_and_Bukovina"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Western_Ukraine,_Carpathian_Ruthenia_and_Bukovina">Western Ukraine, Carpathian Ruthenia and Bukovina</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Ruthenians_and_Ukrainians_in_Czechoslovakia_(1918%E2%80%931938)" class="mw-redirect" title="Ruthenians and Ukrainians in Czechoslovakia (1918–1938)">Ruthenians and Ukrainians in Czechoslovakia (1918–1938)</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Huculy_1933,_Verkhovyna_district.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Huculy_1933%2C_Verkhovyna_district.jpg/170px-Huculy_1933%2C_Verkhovyna_district.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="209" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Huculy_1933%2C_Verkhovyna_district.jpg/255px-Huculy_1933%2C_Verkhovyna_district.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Huculy_1933%2C_Verkhovyna_district.jpg/340px-Huculy_1933%2C_Verkhovyna_district.jpg 2x" data-file-width="736" data-file-height="903"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Huculy_1933,_Verkhovyna_district.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Hutsuls" title="Hutsuls">Hutsuls</a> living in <a href="/wiki/Verkhovyna" title="Verkhovyna">Verkhovyna</a>, <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 1930</span>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The war in Ukraine continued for another two years; by 1921, however, most of Ukraine had been taken over by the Soviet Union, while Galicia and Volhynia (mostly today's <a href="/wiki/West_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="West Ukraine">West Ukraine</a>) were incorporated into the <a href="/wiki/Second_Polish_Republic" title="Second Polish Republic">Second Polish Republic</a>. Modern-day <a href="/wiki/Bukovina" title="Bukovina">Bukovina</a> was annexed by Romania and <a href="/wiki/Carpathian_Ruthenia" title="Carpathian Ruthenia">Carpathian Ruthenia</a> was admitted to the <a href="/wiki/First_Czechoslovak_Republic" title="First Czechoslovak Republic">Czechoslovak Republic</a> as an autonomy.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[81]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>A powerful underground Ukrainian nationalist movement arose in eastern Poland in the 1920s and 1930s, which was formed by Ukrainian veterans of the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian-Soviet_war" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukrainian-Soviet war">Ukrainian-Soviet war</a> (including <a href="/wiki/Yevhen_Konovalets" title="Yevhen Konovalets">Yevhen Konovalets</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andriy_Atanasovych_Melnyk" title="Andriy Atanasovych Melnyk">Andriy Melnyk</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Yuriy_Tyutyunyk" class="mw-redirect" title="Yuriy Tyutyunyk">Yuriy Tyutyunyk</a>) and was transformed into the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Military_Organization" title="Ukrainian Military Organization">Ukrainian Military Organization</a> and later the <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_Ukrainian_Nationalists" title="Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists">Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists (OUN)</a>. The movement attracted a militant following among students. Hostilities between Polish state authorities and the popular movement led to a substantial number of fatalities, and the autonomy which had been promised was never implemented. The pre-war Polish government also exercised <a href="/wiki/Anti-Ukrainian_sentiment" title="Anti-Ukrainian sentiment">anti-Ukrainian sentiment</a>; it restricted rights of people who declared Ukrainian nationality, belonged to the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox Church</a> and inhabited the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Borderlands" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Borderlands">Eastern Borderlands</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[82]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[83]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">Ukrainian language</a> was restricted in every field possible, especially in governmental institutions, and the term "Ruthenian" was enforced in an attempt to ban the use of the term "Ukrainian".<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[84]</a></sup> Despite this, a number of Ukrainian parties, the Ukrainian Catholic Church, an active press, and a business sector existed in Poland. Economic conditions improved in the 1920s, but the region suffered from the <a href="/wiki/Great_Depression" title="Great Depression">Great Depression</a> in the early 1930s.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[85]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Inter-war_Soviet_Ukraine">Inter-war Soviet Ukraine</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Holodomor" title="Holodomor">Holodomor</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:DneproGES.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/DneproGES.jpg/220px-DneproGES.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="145" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/DneproGES.jpg/330px-DneproGES.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/DneproGES.jpg/440px-DneproGES.jpg 2x" data-file-width="720" data-file-height="476"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:DneproGES.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Dnieper_Hydroelectric_Station" title="Dnieper Hydroelectric Station">Dnieper Hydroelectric Station</a> under construction, around 1930
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Russian_Civil_War" title="Russian Civil War">Russian Civil War</a> devastated the whole <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian Empire</a> including Ukraine. It left over 1.5 million people dead and hundreds of thousands homeless in the former Russian Empire territory. Soviet Ukraine also faced the <a href="/wiki/Russian_famine_of_1921" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian famine of 1921">Russian famine of 1921</a> (primarily affecting the Russian <a href="/wiki/Volga_Region" class="mw-redirect" title="Volga Region">Volga</a>-<a href="/wiki/Ural_(region)" title="Ural (region)">Ural</a> region).<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[86]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[87]</a></sup> During the 1920s,<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[88]</a></sup> under the Ukrainisation policy pursued by the national Communist leadership of <a href="/wiki/Mykola_Skrypnyk" title="Mykola Skrypnyk">Mykola Skrypnyk</a>, Soviet leadership encouraged a national renaissance in the <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="Culture of Ukraine">Ukrainian culture</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">language</a>. <a href="/wiki/Ukrainisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukrainisation">Ukrainisation</a> was part of the Soviet-wide policy of <a href="/wiki/Korenisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Korenisation">Korenisation</a> (literally <i>indigenisation</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_83-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-83">[80]</a></sup> The Bolsheviks were also committed to <a href="/wiki/Universal_health_care" title="Universal health care">universal health care</a>, education and social-security benefits, as well as the right to work and housing.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[89]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_rights" title="Women's rights">Women's rights</a> were greatly increased through new laws.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[90]</a></sup> Most of these policies were sharply reversed by the early 1930s after <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Stalin" title="Joseph Stalin">Joseph Stalin</a> became the <i>de facto</i> communist party leader.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs a reliable source (September 2015)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
