      <p>Starting from the late 1920s with a <a href="/wiki/First_five-year_plan" title="First five-year plan">centrally planned economy</a>, Ukraine was involved in <a href="/wiki/Industrialization_in_the_USSR" class="mw-redirect" title="Industrialization in the USSR">Soviet industrialisation</a> and the republic's industrial output quadrupled during the 1930s.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_83-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-83">[80]</a></sup> The peasantry suffered from the <a href="/wiki/Collectivisation_in_the_USSR" class="mw-redirect" title="Collectivisation in the USSR">programme of collectivisation</a> of agriculture which began during and was part of the <a href="/wiki/First_five-year_plan" title="First five-year plan">first five-year plan</a> and was enforced by regular troops and <a href="/wiki/Cheka" title="Cheka">secret police</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_83-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-83">[80]</a></sup> Those who resisted were <a href="/wiki/Population_transfer_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="Population transfer in the Soviet Union">arrested and deported</a> and agricultural productivity greatly declined. As members of the collective farms were sometimes not allowed to receive any grain until unrealistic quotas were met, millions starved to death in a <a href="/wiki/Droughts_and_famines_in_Russia_and_the_Soviet_Union" title="Droughts and famines in Russia and the Soviet Union">famine</a> known as the <a href="/wiki/Holodomor" title="Holodomor">Holodomor</a> or the "Great Famine".<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[91]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:HolodomorUcrania9.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/HolodomorUcrania9.jpg/220px-HolodomorUcrania9.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="163" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/HolodomorUcrania9.jpg/330px-HolodomorUcrania9.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/HolodomorUcrania9.jpg/440px-HolodomorUcrania9.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1188"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:HolodomorUcrania9.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A starved man on the streets of <a href="/wiki/Kharkiv" title="Kharkiv">Kharkiv</a>, 1933. <a href="/wiki/Collectivization" class="mw-redirect" title="Collectivization">Collectivization</a> of crops and their confiscation by Soviet authorities led to a major famine known as the <a href="/wiki/Holodomor" title="Holodomor">Holodomor</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Scholars are divided as to whether this famine fits the definition of <a href="/wiki/Genocide" title="Genocide">genocide</a>, but the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_parliament" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukrainian parliament">Ukrainian parliament</a> and the governments of other countries have acknowledged it as such.<sup class="reference" id="ref_Bnone"><a href="#endnote_Bnone">[b]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Communist leadership perceived famine as a means of class struggle and used starvation as a punishment tool to force peasants into collective farms.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[92]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Largely the same groups were responsible for the mass killing operations during the civil war, collectivisation, and the <a href="/wiki/Great_Purge" title="Great Purge">Great Terror</a>. These groups were associated with <a href="/wiki/Yefim_Yevdokimov" title="Yefim Yevdokimov">Yefim Yevdokimov</a> (1891–1939) and operated in the Secret Operational Division within General State Political Administration (<a href="/wiki/State_Political_Directorate" title="State Political Directorate">OGPU</a>) in 1929–31. Yevdokimov transferred into Communist Party administration in 1934, when he became Party secretary for <a href="/wiki/North_Caucasus_Krai" title="North Caucasus Krai">North Caucasus Krai</a>. He appears to have continued advising Joseph Stalin and <a href="/wiki/Nikolai_Yezhov" class="mw-redirect" title="Nikolai Yezhov">Nikolai Yezhov</a> on security matters, and the latter relied on Yevdokimov's former colleagues to carry out the mass killing operations that are known as the Great Terror in 1937–38.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[93]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On 13 January 2010, Kyiv Appellate Court posthumously found Stalin, <a href="/wiki/Lazar_Kaganovich" title="Lazar Kaganovich">Kaganovich</a> and other Soviet Communist Party functionaries guilty of <a href="/wiki/Genocide" title="Genocide">genocide</a> against Ukrainians during the Holodomor famine.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[94]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="World_War_II">World War II</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Front_(World_War_II)" title="Eastern Front (World War II)">Eastern Front (World War II)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Reichskommissariat_Ukraine" title="Reichskommissariat Ukraine">Reichskommissariat Ukraine</a>, and <a href="/wiki/The_Holocaust_in_Ukraine" title="The Holocaust in Ukraine">The Holocaust in Ukraine</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ukraine-growth.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Ukraine-growth.png/220px-Ukraine-growth.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="131" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Ukraine-growth.png/330px-Ukraine-growth.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Ukraine-growth.png/440px-Ukraine-growth.png 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="475"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ukraine-growth.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Territorial evolution of the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic">Ukrainian SSR</a>, 1922–1954
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Following the <a href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Poland" title="Invasion of Poland">Invasion of Poland</a> in September 1939, <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">German</a> and <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Army" title="Soviet Army">Soviet</a> troops divided the territory of Poland. Thus, Eastern <a href="/wiki/Galicia_(Eastern_Europe)" title="Galicia (Eastern Europe)">Galicia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Volhynia" title="Volhynia">Volhynia</a> with their Ukrainian population became part of Ukraine. For the first time in history, the nation was united.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[95]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[96]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 1940, the Soviets annexed <a href="/wiki/Bessarabia" title="Bessarabia">Bessarabia</a> and northern <a href="/wiki/Bukovina" title="Bukovina">Bukovina</a>. The Ukrainian SSR incorporated the northern and southern districts of Bessarabia, northern Bukovina, and the <a href="/wiki/Hertsa_region" class="mw-redirect" title="Hertsa region">Hertsa region</a>. But it ceded the western part of the <a href="/wiki/Moldavian_Autonomous_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Moldavian Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic">Moldavian Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic</a> to the newly created <a href="/wiki/Moldavian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Moldavian Soviet Socialist Republic">Moldavian Soviet Socialist Republic</a>. These territorial gains of the USSR were internationally recognized by the <a href="/wiki/Paris_Peace_Treaties,_1947" title="Paris Peace Treaties, 1947">Paris peace treaties of 1947</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2015)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:%D0%9C%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%88%D0%B0%D0%BB_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D1%8E%D0%B7%D0%B0_%D0%93%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D1%8E%D0%B7%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D0%B5%D0%BC%D1%91%D0%BD_%D0%9A%D0%BE%D0%BD%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%87_%D0%A2%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%BE%D1%88%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%BE.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/%D0%9C%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%88%D0%B0%D0%BB_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D1%8E%D0%B7%D0%B0_%D0%93%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D1%8E%D0%B7%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D0%B5%D0%BC%D1%91%D0%BD_%D0%9A%D0%BE%D0%BD%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%87_%D0%A2%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%BE%D1%88%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%BE.jpg/170px-%D0%9C%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%88%D0%B0%D0%BB_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D1%8E%D0%B7%D0%B0_%D0%93%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D1%8E%D0%B7%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D0%B5%D0%BC%D1%91%D0%BD_%D0%9A%D0%BE%D0%BD%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%87_%D0%A2%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%BE%D1%88%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%BE.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="229" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/%D0%9C%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%88%D0%B0%D0%BB_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D1%8E%D0%B7%D0%B0_%D0%93%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D1%8E%D0%B7%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D0%B5%D0%BC%D1%91%D0%BD_%D0%9A%D0%BE%D0%BD%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%87_%D0%A2%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%BE%D1%88%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%BE.jpg/255px-%D0%9C%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%88%D0%B0%D0%BB_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D1%8E%D0%B7%D0%B0_%D0%93%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D1%8E%D0%B7%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D0%B5%D0%BC%D1%91%D0%BD_%D0%9A%D0%BE%D0%BD%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%87_%D0%A2%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%BE%D1%88%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%BE.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/%D0%9C%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%88%D0%B0%D0%BB_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D1%8E%D0%B7%D0%B0_%D0%93%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D1%8E%D0%B7%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D0%B5%D0%BC%D1%91%D0%BD_%D0%9A%D0%BE%D0%BD%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%87_%D0%A2%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%BE%D1%88%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%BE.jpg/340px-%D0%9C%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%88%D0%B0%D0%BB_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D1%8E%D0%B7%D0%B0_%D0%93%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D1%8E%D0%B7%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D0%B5%D0%BC%D1%91%D0%BD_%D0%9A%D0%BE%D0%BD%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%87_%D0%A2%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%BE%D1%88%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%BE.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1553" data-file-height="2096"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:%D0%9C%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%88%D0%B0%D0%BB_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D1%8E%D0%B7%D0%B0_%D0%93%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_%D0%A1%D0%BE%D1%8E%D0%B7%D0%B0_%D0%A1%D0%B5%D0%BC%D1%91%D0%BD_%D0%9A%D0%BE%D0%BD%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%87_%D0%A2%D0%B8%D0%BC%D0%BE%D1%88%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%BE.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Marshal <a href="/wiki/Semyon_Timoshenko" title="Semyon Timoshenko">Timoshenko</a> (born in the <a href="/wiki/Budjak" title="Budjak">Budjak</a> region) commanded numerous fronts throughout the war, including the <a href="/wiki/Southwestern_Front_(Soviet_Union)" title="Southwestern Front (Soviet Union)">Southwestern Front</a> east of Kyiv in 1941.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Wehrmacht" title="Wehrmacht">German armies</a> <a href="/wiki/Operation_Barbarossa" title="Operation Barbarossa">invaded the Soviet Union</a> on 22 June 1941, initiating nearly four years of <a href="/wiki/Total_war" title="Total war">total war</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Axis_Powers" class="mw-redirect" title="Axis Powers">Axis</a> initially advanced against desperate but unsuccessful efforts of the <a href="/wiki/Red_Army" title="Red Army">Red Army</a>. In the encirclement <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Kyiv_(1941)" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle of Kyiv (1941)">battle of Kyiv</a>, the city was acclaimed as a "<a href="/wiki/Hero_City" title="Hero City">Hero City</a>", because of its fierce <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Kyiv_(1941)" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle of Kyiv (1941)">resistance</a>. More than 600,000 Soviet soldiers (or one-quarter of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Western_Front" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet Western Front">Soviet Western Front</a>) were killed or taken captive there, with many suffering <a href="/wiki/German_mistreatment_of_Soviet_prisoners_of_war" title="German mistreatment of Soviet prisoners of war">severe mistreatment</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[97]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[98]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Although the majority of Ukrainians fought in or alongside the Red Army and <a href="/wiki/Soviet_partisans" title="Soviet partisans">Soviet resistance</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-worldwars_102-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-worldwars-102">[99]</a></sup> in Western Ukraine an independent <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Insurgent_Army" title="Ukrainian Insurgent Army">Ukrainian Insurgent Army</a> movement arose (UPA, 1942). Created as armed forces of the underground (<a href="/wiki/Organization_of_Ukrainian_Nationalists" title="Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists">Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists</a>, OUN)<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[100]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-vedeneyev_104-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vedeneyev-104">[101]</a></sup> which had developed in <a href="/wiki/Second_Polish_Republic" title="Second Polish Republic">interwar Poland</a> as a reactionary nationalist organization. During the interwar period, the <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Ukrainian_minority_in_Poland#Policies_of_Józef_Piłsudski_and_the_&quot;Volhynia_Experiment&quot;" title="History of the Ukrainian minority in Poland">Polish government's policies towards the Ukrainian minority</a> were initially very accommodating, however by the late 1930s they became increasingly harsh due to civil unrest. Both organizations, OUN and UPA supported the goal of an <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_Ukrainian_Independence,_1941" class="mw-redirect" title="Declaration of Ukrainian Independence, 1941">independent Ukrainian state</a> on the territory with a Ukrainian ethnic majority. Although this brought conflict with Nazi Germany, at times the <a href="/wiki/Andriy_Atanasovych_Melnyk" title="Andriy Atanasovych Melnyk">Melnyk</a> wing of the OUN allied with the Nazi forces. Also, UPA divisions carried out <a href="/wiki/Massacres_of_Poles_in_Volhynia_and_Eastern_Galicia" title="Massacres of Poles in Volhynia and Eastern Galicia">massacres of ethnic Poles</a>, killing around 100,000 Polish civilians,<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[102]</a></sup> which brought reprisals.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[103]</a></sup> After the war, the UPA continued to fight the USSR until the 1950s.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[104]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[105]</a></sup> At the same time, the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Liberation_Army" title="Ukrainian Liberation Army">Ukrainian Liberation Army</a>, another nationalist movement, fought alongside the Nazis.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2015)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ruined_Kiev_in_WWII.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Ruined_Kiev_in_WWII.jpg/220px-Ruined_Kiev_in_WWII.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="140" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Ruined_Kiev_in_WWII.jpg/330px-Ruined_Kiev_in_WWII.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Ruined_Kiev_in_WWII.jpg/440px-Ruined_Kiev_in_WWII.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1925" data-file-height="1223"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ruined_Kiev_in_WWII.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Kyiv" title="Kyiv">Kyiv</a> suffered significant damage during <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Front_(World_War_II)" title="Eastern Front (World War II)">World War II</a>, and was occupied by the <a href="/wiki/Wehrmacht" title="Wehrmacht">Germans</a> from 19 September 1941 until 6 November 1943.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In total, the number of ethnic Ukrainians who fought in the ranks of the Soviet Army is estimated from 4.5&nbsp;million<sup id="cite_ref-worldwars_102-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-worldwars-102">[99]</a></sup> to 7&nbsp;million.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[106]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="ref_C1"><a href="#endnote_C1">[c]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Partisans" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet Partisans">pro-Soviet partisan</a> guerrilla resistance in Ukraine is estimated to number at 47,800 from the start of occupation to 500,000 at its peak in 1944, with about 50% being ethnic Ukrainians.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[107]</a></sup> Generally, the Ukrainian Insurgent Army's figures are unreliable, with figures ranging anywhere from 15,000 to as many as 100,000 fighters.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[108]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[109]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Most of the Ukrainian SSR was organised within the <a href="/wiki/Reichskommissariat_Ukraine" title="Reichskommissariat Ukraine">Reichskommissariat Ukraine</a>, with the intention of exploiting its resources and eventual German settlement. Some western Ukrainians, who had only joined the Soviet Union in 1939, hailed the Germans as liberators. Brutal German rule eventually turned their supporters against the Nazi administrators, who made little attempt to exploit dissatisfaction with Stalinist policies.<sup id="cite_ref-ww2_113-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ww2-113">[110]</a></sup> Instead, the Nazis preserved the collective-farm system, carried out <a href="/wiki/Mass_graves_in_the_Soviet_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Mass graves in the Soviet Union">genocidal policies</a> against <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Ukraine" title="History of the Jews in Ukraine">Jews</a>, <a href="/wiki/OST-Arbeiter" class="mw-redirect" title="OST-Arbeiter">deported millions of people to work in Germany</a>, and began a depopulation program to prepare for German colonisation.<sup id="cite_ref-ww2_113-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ww2-113">[110]</a></sup> They blockaded the transport of food on the Kyiv River.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[111]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The vast majority of the fighting in World War II took place on the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Front_(World_War_II)" title="Eastern Front (World War II)">Eastern Front</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[112]</a></sup> By some estimates, 93% of all German casualties took place there.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[113]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/World_War_II_casualties_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="World War II casualties of the Soviet Union">total losses</a> inflicted upon the Ukrainian population during the war are estimated at about 6 million,<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[114]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-dt-kul-dem-los_118-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dt-kul-dem-los-118">[115]</a></sup> including an estimated one and a half million Jews killed by the <a href="/wiki/Einsatzgruppen" title="Einsatzgruppen">Einsatzgruppen</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[116]</a></sup> sometimes with the help of local collaborators. Of the estimated 8.6 million Soviet troop losses,<sup id="cite_ref-peremoga7_120-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-peremoga7-120">[117]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[118]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Krivosheev_122-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Krivosheev-122">[119]</a></sup> 1.4&nbsp;million were ethnic <a href="/wiki/Ukrainians" title="Ukrainians">Ukrainians</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-peremoga7_120-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-peremoga7-120">[117]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Krivosheev_122-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Krivosheev-122">[119]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="ref_C2"><a href="#endnote_C2">[c]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="ref_Dnone"><a href="#endnote_Dnone">[d]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Victory_Day_(Eastern_Front)" class="mw-redirect" title="Victory Day (Eastern Front)">Victory Day</a> is celebrated as one of ten Ukrainian national holidays.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[120]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Post-World_War_II">Post-World War II</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic">Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Soviet_Union_(1953%E2%80%931964)" title="History of the Soviet Union (1953–1964)">History of the Soviet Union (1953–1964)</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Soviet_Union_(1964%E2%80%931982)" title="History of the Soviet Union (1964–1982)">History of the Soviet Union (1964–1982)</a>, and <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Soviet_Union_(1982%E2%80%931991)" title="History of the Soviet Union (1982–1991)">History of the Soviet Union (1982–1991)</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">

        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:%D0%A1%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B3%D0%B5%D0%B9_%D0%9F%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%87_%D0%9A%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%91%D0%B2_(%D0%BF%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%82).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Sergey_Korolyov" class="mw-redirect" title="Sergey Korolyov">Sergey Korolyov</a>, a native of <a href="/wiki/Zhytomyr" title="Zhytomyr">Zhytomyr</a>, the head <a href="/wiki/Soviet_space_program" title="Soviet space program">Soviet rocket engineer</a> and designer during the <a href="/wiki/Space_Race" title="Space Race">Space Race</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The republic was heavily damaged by the war, and it required significant efforts to recover. More than 700 cities and towns and 28,000 villages were destroyed.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[121]</a></sup> The situation was worsened by a <a href="/wiki/Famine" title="Famine">famine</a> in 1946–47, which was caused by a drought and the wartime destruction of infrastructure. The death toll of this famine varies, with even the lowest estimate in the tens of thousands.<sup id="cite_ref-dt-kul-dem-los_118-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dt-kul-dem-los-118">[115]</a></sup> In 1945, the Ukrainian SSR became one of the founding members of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> organization,<sup id="cite_ref-un_ukssr_125-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-un_ukssr-125">[122]</a></sup> part of a special agreement at the <a href="/wiki/Yalta_Conference" title="Yalta Conference">Yalta Conference</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[123]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Post-war <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_cleansing" title="Ethnic cleansing">ethnic cleansing</a> occurred in the newly expanded Soviet Union. As of 1 January 1953, Ukrainians were second only to Russians among adult "<a href="/wiki/Forced_settlements_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="Forced settlements in the Soviet Union">special deportees</a>", comprising 20% of the total.<sup id="cite_ref-Malynovska_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Malynovska-127">[124]</a></sup> In addition, over 450,000 ethnic <a href="/wiki/History_of_Germans_in_Russia,_Ukraine_and_the_Soviet_Union" title="History of Germans in Russia, Ukraine and the Soviet Union">Germans</a> from Ukraine and more than 200,000 <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Tatars" title="Crimean Tatars">Crimean Tatars</a> were victims of <a href="/wiki/Population_transfer_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="Population transfer in the Soviet Union">forced deportations</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Malynovska_127-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Malynovska-127">[124]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Khrushchev_and_Brezhnev.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c8/Khrushchev_and_Brezhnev.jpg/170px-Khrushchev_and_Brezhnev.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="295" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c8/Khrushchev_and_Brezhnev.jpg/255px-Khrushchev_and_Brezhnev.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c8/Khrushchev_and_Brezhnev.jpg/340px-Khrushchev_and_Brezhnev.jpg 2x" data-file-width="432" data-file-height="750"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Khrushchev_and_Brezhnev.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Two future leaders of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nikita_Khrushchev" title="Nikita Khrushchev">Nikita Khrushchev</a> (pre-war <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Communist Party of the Soviet Union">CPSU</a> chief in Ukraine) and <a href="/wiki/Leonid_Brezhnev" title="Leonid Brezhnev">Leonid Brezhnev</a> (an engineer from <a href="/wiki/Kamianske" title="Kamianske">Kamianske</a>), depicted together
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Following the death of <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Stalin" title="Joseph Stalin">Stalin</a> in 1953, <a href="/wiki/Nikita_Khrushchev" title="Nikita Khrushchev">Nikita Khrushchev</a> became the new leader of the USSR. Having served as First Secretary of the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_(Bolsheviks)_of_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="Communist Party (Bolsheviks) of Ukraine">Communist Party of Ukrainian SSR</a> in 1938–49, Khrushchev was intimately familiar with the republic; after taking power union-wide, he began to emphasize "the friendship" between the Ukrainian and Russian nations. In 1954, the 300th anniversary of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Pereyaslav" class="mw-redirect" title="Treaty of Pereyaslav">Treaty of Pereyaslav</a> was widely celebrated. <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Oblast" title="Crimean Oblast">Crimea</a> was <a href="/wiki/1954_transfer_of_Crimea" title="1954 transfer of Crimea">transferred</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Russian_SFSR" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian SFSR">Russian SFSR</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_SSR" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukrainian SSR">Ukrainian SSR</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[125]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>By 1950, the republic had fully surpassed pre-war levels of industry and production.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[126]</a></sup> During the 1946–1950 <a href="/wiki/Five-Year_Plan_(USSR)" class="mw-redirect" title="Five-Year Plan (USSR)">five-year plan</a>, nearly 20% of the Soviet budget was invested in Soviet Ukraine, a 5% increase from pre-war plans. As a result, the Ukrainian workforce rose 33.2% from 1940 to 1955 while industrial output grew 2.2 times in that same period.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2015)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Soviet Ukraine soon became a European leader in industrial production,<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[127]</a></sup> and an important centre of the Soviet <a href="/wiki/Arms_industry" title="Arms industry">arms industry</a> and high-tech research. Such an important role resulted in a major influence of the local elite. Many members of the Soviet leadership came from Ukraine, most notably <a href="/wiki/Leonid_Brezhnev" title="Leonid Brezhnev">Leonid Brezhnev</a>. He later ousted Khrushchev and became the Soviet leader from 1964 to 1982. Many prominent Soviet sports players, scientists, and artists came from Ukraine.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2015)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>On 26 April 1986, a reactor in the <a href="/wiki/Chernobyl_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant">Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant</a> exploded, resulting in the <a href="/wiki/Chernobyl_disaster" title="Chernobyl disaster">Chernobyl disaster</a>, the worst <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_reactor" title="Nuclear reactor">nuclear reactor</a> accident in history.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[128]</a></sup> This was the only accident to receive the highest possible rating of 7 by the <a href="/wiki/International_Nuclear_Event_Scale" title="International Nuclear Event Scale">International Nuclear Event Scale</a>, indicating a "major accident", until the <a href="/wiki/Fukushima_Daiichi_nuclear_disaster" title="Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster">Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster</a> in March 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[129]</a></sup> At the time of the accident, 7 million people lived in the contaminated territories, including 2.2 million in Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-Chernobyl.info_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chernobyl.info-133">[130]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>After the accident, the new city of <a href="/wiki/Slavutych" title="Slavutych">Slavutych</a> was built outside the exclusion zone to house and support the employees of the plant, which was decommissioned in 2000. A report prepared by the <a href="/wiki/International_Atomic_Energy_Agency" title="International Atomic Energy Agency">International Atomic Energy Agency</a> and <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a> attributed 56 direct deaths to the accident and estimated that there may have been 4,000 extra cancer deaths.<sup id="cite_ref-iaea_134-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iaea-134">[131]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Independence">Independence</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:RIAN_archive_848095_Signing_the_Agreement_to_eliminate_the_USSR_and_establish_the_Commonwealth_of_Independent_States.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/RIAN_archive_848095_Signing_the_Agreement_to_eliminate_the_USSR_and_establish_the_Commonwealth_of_Independent_States.jpg/220px-RIAN_archive_848095_Signing_the_Agreement_to_eliminate_the_USSR_and_establish_the_Commonwealth_of_Independent_States.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="145" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/RIAN_archive_848095_Signing_the_Agreement_to_eliminate_the_USSR_and_establish_the_Commonwealth_of_Independent_States.jpg/330px-RIAN_archive_848095_Signing_the_Agreement_to_eliminate_the_USSR_and_establish_the_Commonwealth_of_Independent_States.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/RIAN_archive_848095_Signing_the_Agreement_to_eliminate_the_USSR_and_establish_the_Commonwealth_of_Independent_States.jpg/440px-RIAN_archive_848095_Signing_the_Agreement_to_eliminate_the_USSR_and_establish_the_Commonwealth_of_Independent_States.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1438" data-file-height="945"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:RIAN_archive_848095_Signing_the_Agreement_to_eliminate_the_USSR_and_establish_the_Commonwealth_of_Independent_States.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Ukrainian President <a href="/wiki/Leonid_Kravchuk" title="Leonid Kravchuk">Leonid Kravchuk</a> and President of the Russian Federation <a href="/wiki/Boris_Yeltsin" title="Boris Yeltsin">Boris Yeltsin</a> signed the <a href="/wiki/Belavezha_Accords" class="mw-redirect" title="Belavezha Accords">Belavezha Accords</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Dissolution of the Soviet Union">dissolving the Soviet Union</a>, on 8 December 1991.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>On 16 July 1990, the new parliament adopted the <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_State_Sovereignty_of_Ukraine" title="Declaration of State Sovereignty of Ukraine">Declaration of State Sovereignty of Ukraine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[132]</a></sup> This established the principles of the self-determination, democracy, independence, and the priority of Ukrainian law over Soviet law. A month earlier, a <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_State_Sovereignty_of_the_Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic" title="Declaration of State Sovereignty of the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic">similar declaration</a> was adopted by the parliament of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_SFSR" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian SFSR">Russian SFSR</a>. This started a period of confrontation with the central Soviet authorities. In August 1991, a faction among the Communist leaders of the Soviet Union <a href="/wiki/Soviet_coup_attempt_of_1991" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet coup attempt of 1991">attempted a coup</a> to remove <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Gorbachev" title="Mikhail Gorbachev">Mikhail Gorbachev</a> and to restore the Communist party's power. After it failed, on 24 August 1991 the Ukrainian parliament adopted the <a href="/wiki/Act_of_Independence_of_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="Act of Independence of Ukraine">Act of Independence</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[133]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>A <a href="/wiki/1991_Ukrainian_independence_referendum" title="1991 Ukrainian independence referendum">referendum</a> and the <a href="/wiki/1991_Ukrainian_presidential_election" title="1991 Ukrainian presidential election">first presidential elections</a> took place on 1 December 1991. More than 90% of the electorate expressed their support for the Act of Independence, and they elected the chairman of the parliament, <a href="/wiki/Leonid_Kravchuk" title="Leonid Kravchuk">Leonid Kravchuk</a> as the first <a href="/wiki/President_of_Ukraine" title="President of Ukraine">President of Ukraine</a>. At the <a href="/wiki/Belavezha_Accords" class="mw-redirect" title="Belavezha Accords">meeting in Brest</a>, Belarus on 8 December, followed by the <a href="/wiki/Alma_Ata" class="mw-redirect" title="Alma Ata">Alma Ata</a> meeting on 21 December, the leaders of Belarus, Russia, and Ukraine formally dissolved the Soviet Union and formed the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Independent_States" title="Commonwealth of Independent States">Commonwealth of Independent States</a> (CIS).<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[134]</a></sup> On 26 December 1991 the Council of Republics of the USSR Supreme Council adapted declaration "In regards to creation of the Commonwealth of Independent States" (<a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian</a>: <span lang="ru">В связи с созданием Содружества Независимых Государств</span>) which de jure dissolved the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_flag" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet flag">Soviet flag</a> was lowered over <a href="/wiki/The_Kremlin" class="mw-redirect" title="The Kremlin">the Kremlin</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[135]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Ukraine was initially viewed as having favourable economic conditions in comparison to the other regions of the Soviet Union.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[136]</a></sup> However, the country experienced deeper economic slowdown than some of the other <a href="/wiki/Former_Soviet_Republics" class="mw-redirect" title="Former Soviet Republics">former Soviet Republics</a>. During the recession, Ukraine lost 60% of its GDP from 1991 to 1999,<sup id="cite_ref-IMF_140-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IMF-140">[137]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[138]</a></sup> and suffered five-digit inflation rates.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[139]</a></sup> Dissatisfied with the economic conditions, as well as the amounts of crime and <a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_Ukraine" title="Corruption in Ukraine">corruption in Ukraine</a>, Ukrainians protested and organized strikes.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[140]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Ukrainian economy stabilized by the end of the 1990s. A new currency, the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_hryvnia" title="Ukrainian hryvnia">hryvnia</a>, was introduced in 1996. After 2000, the country enjoyed steady <a href="/wiki/Real_GDP" class="mw-redirect" title="Real GDP">real economic growth</a> averaging about seven&nbsp;percent annually.<sup id="cite_ref-Macroindicators_NBU_144-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Macroindicators_NBU-144">[141]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[142]</a></sup> A new <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine" title="Constitution of Ukraine">Constitution of Ukraine</a> was adopted under second President <a href="/wiki/Leonid_Kuchma" title="Leonid Kuchma">Leonid Kuchma</a> in 1996, which turned Ukraine into a <a href="/wiki/Semi-presidential_republic" class="mw-redirect" title="Semi-presidential republic">semi-presidential republic</a> and established a stable political system. Kuchma was, however, criticised by opponents for corruption, <a href="/wiki/Electoral_fraud" title="Electoral fraud">electoral fraud</a>, discouraging free speech and concentrating too much power in his office.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[143]</a></sup> Ukraine also pursued full nuclear disarmament, giving up the third largest nuclear weapons stockpile in the world and dismantling or removing all strategic bombers on its territory in exchange for various assurances (main article: <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapons_and_Ukraine" title="Nuclear weapons and Ukraine">Nuclear weapons and Ukraine</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[144]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Orange_Revolution">Orange Revolution</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Orange_Revolution" title="Orange Revolution">Orange Revolution</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Joesjtsjenko_Marion_Kiev_2004.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Joesjtsjenko_Marion_Kiev_2004.jpg/220px-Joesjtsjenko_Marion_Kiev_2004.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Joesjtsjenko_Marion_Kiev_2004.jpg/330px-Joesjtsjenko_Marion_Kiev_2004.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Joesjtsjenko_Marion_Kiev_2004.jpg/440px-Joesjtsjenko_Marion_Kiev_2004.jpg 2x" data-file-width="600" data-file-height="450"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Joesjtsjenko_Marion_Kiev_2004.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Protesters at <a href="/wiki/Maidan_Nezalezhnosti" title="Maidan Nezalezhnosti">Independence Square</a> on the first day of the <a href="/wiki/Orange_Revolution" title="Orange Revolution">Orange Revolution</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 2004, <a href="/wiki/Viktor_Yanukovych" title="Viktor Yanukovych">Viktor Yanukovych</a>, then Prime Minister, was declared the winner of the <a href="/wiki/2004_Ukrainian_presidential_election" title="2004 Ukrainian presidential election">presidential elections</a>, which had been largely rigged, as the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Ukraine" title="Supreme Court of Ukraine">Supreme Court of Ukraine</a> later ruled.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[145]</a></sup> The results caused a public outcry in support of the opposition candidate, <a href="/wiki/Viktor_Yushchenko" title="Viktor Yushchenko">Viktor Yushchenko</a>, who challenged the outcome. During the tumultuous months of the revolution, candidate Yushchenko <a href="/wiki/Viktor_Yushchenko#Dioxin_poisoning" title="Viktor Yushchenko">suddenly became gravely ill</a>, and was soon found by multiple independent physician groups to have been poisoned by <a href="/wiki/2,3,7,8-Tetrachlorodibenzodioxin" title="2,3,7,8-Tetrachlorodibenzodioxin">TCDD dioxin</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CBS:_Yushchenko:_Live_And_Carry_On_149-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CBS:_Yushchenko:_Live_And_Carry_On-149">[146]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ref_j_150-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_j-150">[147]</a></sup> Yushchenko strongly suspected Russian involvement in his poisoning.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_2009c_151-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2009c-151">[148]</a></sup> All of this eventually resulted in the peaceful <a href="/wiki/Orange_Revolution" title="Orange Revolution">Orange Revolution</a>, bringing Viktor Yushchenko and <a href="/wiki/Yulia_Tymoshenko" title="Yulia Tymoshenko">Yulia Tymoshenko</a> to power, while casting Viktor Yanukovych in opposition.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[149]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:EPP_Summit_March_2011_(67).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/EPP_Summit_March_2011_%2867%29.jpg/220px-EPP_Summit_March_2011_%2867%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="176" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/EPP_Summit_March_2011_%2867%29.jpg/330px-EPP_Summit_March_2011_%2867%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/EPP_Summit_March_2011_%2867%29.jpg/440px-EPP_Summit_March_2011_%2867%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2564" data-file-height="2055"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:EPP_Summit_March_2011_(67).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Yulia_Tymoshenko" title="Yulia Tymoshenko">Yulia Tymoshenko</a> (right), <a href="/wiki/Angela_Merkel" title="Angela Merkel">Angela Merkel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Saakashvili" class="mw-redirect" title="Mikhail Saakashvili">Mikhail Saakashvili</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Activists of the Orange Revolution were funded and trained in tactics of political organisation and <a href="/wiki/Nonviolent_resistance" title="Nonviolent resistance">nonviolent resistance</a> by Western pollsters<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify"><span title="The text near this tag may need clarification or removal of jargon. (July 2015)">clarification needed</span></a></i>]</sup> and professional consultants<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch"><span title="The material near this tag possibly uses too-vague attribution or weasel words. (July 2015)">who?</span></a></i>]</sup> who were partly funded by Western government and non-government agencies but received most of their funding from domestic sources.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[nb 1]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ORRNC_153-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ORRNC-153">[150]</a></sup> According to <i><a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">The Guardian</a></i>, the foreign donors included the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_State" title="United States Department of State">U.S. State Department</a> and <a href="/wiki/United_States_Agency_for_International_Development" title="United States Agency for International Development">USAID</a> along with the <a href="/wiki/National_Democratic_Institute_for_International_Affairs" class="mw-redirect" title="National Democratic Institute for International Affairs">National Democratic Institute for International Affairs</a>, the <a href="/wiki/International_Republican_Institute" title="International Republican Institute">International Republican Institute</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Non-governmental_organisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Non-governmental organisation">NGO</a> <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">Freedom House</a> and <a href="/wiki/George_Soros" title="George Soros">George Soros</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Open_Society_Institute" class="mw-redirect" title="Open Society Institute">Open Society Institute</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[151]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/National_Endowment_for_Democracy" title="National Endowment for Democracy">National Endowment for Democracy</a> has supported democracy-building efforts in Ukraine since 1988.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[152]</a></sup> Writings on <a href="/wiki/Nonviolent_resistance" title="Nonviolent resistance">nonviolent struggle</a> by <a href="/wiki/Gene_Sharp" title="Gene Sharp">Gene Sharp</a> contributed in forming the strategic basis of the student campaigns.<sup id="cite_ref-APOR291011_157-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-APOR291011-157">[153]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Russian authorities provided support through advisers such as <a href="/wiki/Gleb_Pavlovsky" title="Gleb Pavlovsky">Gleb Pavlovsky</a>, consulting on blackening the image of Yushchenko through the state media, pressuring state-dependent voters to vote for Yanukovych and on vote-rigging techniques such as multiple '<a href="/wiki/Carousel_voting" title="Carousel voting">carousel voting</a>' and 'dead souls' voting.<sup id="cite_ref-ORRNC_153-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ORRNC-153">[150]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Yanukovych returned to power in 2006 as Prime Minister in the <a href="/wiki/Alliance_of_National_Unity" class="mw-redirect" title="Alliance of National Unity">Alliance of National Unity</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[154]</a></sup> until <a href="/wiki/2007_Ukrainian_parliamentary_election" title="2007 Ukrainian parliamentary election">snap elections in September 2007</a> made Tymoshenko Prime Minister again.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[155]</a></sup> Amid the <a href="/wiki/2008%E2%80%9309_Ukrainian_financial_crisis" class="mw-redirect" title="2008–09 Ukrainian financial crisis">2008–09 Ukrainian financial crisis</a> the Ukrainian economy plunged by 15%.<sup id="cite_ref-FT_2013_160-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FT_2013-160">[156]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93Ukraine_gas_disputes" title="Russia–Ukraine gas disputes">Disputes with Russia</a> briefly stopped all gas supplies to Ukraine in 2006 and again in 2009, leading to gas shortages in other countries.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[157]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[158]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Viktor_Yanukovych" title="Viktor Yanukovych">Viktor Yanukovych</a> was <a href="/wiki/2010_Ukrainian_presidential_election" title="2010 Ukrainian presidential election">elected President in 2010</a> with 48% of votes.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[159]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Euromaidan_and_2014_revolution">Euromaidan and 2014 revolution</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Euromaidan" title="Euromaidan">Euromaidan</a> and <a href="/wiki/2014_Ukrainian_revolution" class="mw-redirect" title="2014 Ukrainian revolution">2014 Ukrainian revolution</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information on the ongoing protests: <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_the_Euromaidan" title="Timeline of the Euromaidan">Timeline of the Euromaidan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Euromaidan_01.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Euromaidan_01.JPG/220px-Euromaidan_01.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Euromaidan_01.JPG/330px-Euromaidan_01.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Euromaidan_01.JPG/440px-Euromaidan_01.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3230" data-file-height="2154"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Euromaidan_01.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Pro-EU demonstration in Kyiv, 27 November 2013, during the <a href="/wiki/Euromaidan" title="Euromaidan">Euromaidan</a> protests
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Euromaidan" title="Euromaidan">Euromaidan</a> (<a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">Ukrainian</a>: <span lang="uk">Євромайдан</span>, literally "Eurosquare") protests started in November 2013 after the president, <a href="/wiki/Viktor_Yanukovych" title="Viktor Yanukovych">Viktor Yanukovych</a>, began moving away from an association agreement that had been in the works with the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> and instead chose to establish closer ties with the Russian Federation.<sup id="cite_ref-bbc20131217_164-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc20131217-164">[160]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[161]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[162]</a></sup> Some Ukrainians took to the streets to show their support for closer ties with Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[163]</a></sup> Meanwhile, in the predominantly Russian-speaking east, a large portion of the population opposed the <i>Euromaidan</i> protests, instead supporting the Yanukovych government.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[164]</a></sup> Over time, <i>Euromaidan</i> came to describe a wave of demonstrations and civil unrest in Ukraine,<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[165]</a></sup> the scope of which evolved to include calls for the resignation of President Yanukovych and <a href="/wiki/Second_Azarov_Government" class="mw-redirect" title="Second Azarov Government">his government</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-reuters20131212_170-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-reuters20131212-170">[166]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Violence escalated after 16 January 2014 when the government accepted new <a href="/wiki/Anti-protest_laws_in_Ukraine" title="Anti-protest laws in Ukraine">Anti-Protest Laws</a>. Violent anti-government demonstrators occupied buildings in the centre of Kyiv, including the Justice Ministry building, and riots left 98 dead with approximately fifteen thousand injured and 100 considered missing<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[167]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[168]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[169]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[170]</a></sup> from 18 to 20 February.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[171]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[172]</a></sup> On 21 February, President Yanukovych signed a compromise deal with opposition leaders that promised constitutional changes to restore certain powers to Parliament and called for early elections to be held by December.<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[173]</a></sup> However, Members of Parliament voted on 22 February to remove the president and set <a href="/wiki/2014_Ukrainian_presidential_election" title="2014 Ukrainian presidential election">an election</a> for 25 May to select his replacement.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[174]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Petro_Poroshenko" title="Petro Poroshenko">Petro Poroshenko</a>, running on a pro-European Union platform, won with over fifty percent of the vote, therefore not requiring a run-off election.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_179-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-179">[175]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-nytimes.com_180-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes.com-180">[176]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-RTVi_2014_181-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RTVi_2014-181">[177]</a></sup> Upon his election, Poroshenko announced that his immediate priorities would be to take action in the civil unrest in Eastern Ukraine and mend ties with the Russian Federation.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_179-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-179">[175]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-nytimes.com_180-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes.com-180">[176]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-RTVi_2014_181-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RTVi_2014-181">[177]</a></sup> Poroshenko was inaugurated as president on 7 June 2014, as previously announced by his spokeswoman Irina Friz in a low-key ceremony without a celebration on <a href="/wiki/Kyiv" title="Kyiv">Kyiv</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Maidan_Nezalezhnosti" title="Maidan Nezalezhnosti">Maidan Nezalezhnosti</a> (Independence Square, the centre of the <a href="/wiki/Euromaidan" title="Euromaidan">Euromaidan</a> protests<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[178]</a></sup>) for the ceremony.<sup id="cite_ref-to_Be_Inaugurated_June_7_183-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-to_Be_Inaugurated_June_7-183">[179]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[180]</a></sup> In October 2014 <a href="/wiki/2014_Ukrainian_parliamentary_election" title="2014 Ukrainian parliamentary election">Parliament elections</a>, <a href="/wiki/Petro_Poroshenko_Bloc_%22Solidarity%22" class="mw-redirect" title="Petro Poroshenko Bloc &quot;Solidarity&quot;">Petro Poroshenko Bloc "Solidarity"</a> won 132 of the 423 contested seats.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[181]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="Civil_unrest.2C_Russian_intervention.2C_and_annexation_of_Crimea"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Civil_unrest,_Russian_intervention,_and_annexation_of_Crimea">Civil unrest, Russian intervention, and annexation of Crimea</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/2014_pro-Russian_unrest_in_Ukraine" title="2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine">2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_military_intervention_in_Ukraine_(2014%E2%80%93present)" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian military intervention in Ukraine (2014–present)">Russian military intervention in Ukraine (2014–present)</a>, <a href="/wiki/War_in_Donbass" title="War in Donbass">War in Donbass</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation" title="Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation">Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation</a>
      </div> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:2014-03-09._%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D1%8B_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_022.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/2014-03-09._%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D1%8B_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_022.jpg/220px-2014-03-09._%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D1%8B_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_022.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/2014-03-09._%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D1%8B_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_022.jpg/330px-2014-03-09._%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D1%8B_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_022.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/2014-03-09._%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D1%8B_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_022.jpg/440px-2014-03-09._%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D1%8B_%D0%B2_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B5%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B5_022.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4928" data-file-height="3264"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">
           Pro-Russian protesters in <a href="/wiki/Donetsk" title="Donetsk">Donetsk</a>, 8 March 2014
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:2014_Russo-ukrainian-conflict_map.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/2014_Russo-ukrainian-conflict_map.svg/220px-2014_Russo-ukrainian-conflict_map.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="239" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/2014_Russo-ukrainian-conflict_map.svg/330px-2014_Russo-ukrainian-conflict_map.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/2014_Russo-ukrainian-conflict_map.svg/440px-2014_Russo-ukrainian-conflict_map.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="4126" data-file-height="4480"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">
           <a href="/wiki/Crimea" title="Crimea">Crimea</a>, which Russia annexed in 2014, is shown in pink. Pink in the <a href="/wiki/Donbass" title="Donbass">Donbass</a> area represents areas held by the <a href="/wiki/Donetsk_People%27s_Republic" title="Donetsk People's Republic">DPR</a>/<a href="/wiki/Lugansk_People%27s_Republic" class="mw-redirect" title="Lugansk People's Republic">LPR</a> separatists in September 2014 (cities in red).
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The ousting<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[182]</a></sup> of Yanukovych prompted Vladimir Putin to begin preparations to annex Crimea on 23 February 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[183]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[184]</a></sup> Using the Russian naval base at Sevastopol as cover, Putin directed Russian troops and intelligence agents to disarm Ukrainian forces and take control of Crimea.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[185]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">[186]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[187]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[188]</a></sup> After the troops entered Crimea,<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[189]</a></sup> a controversial <a href="/wiki/2014_Crimean_referendum" class="mw-redirect" title="2014 Crimean referendum">referendum</a> was held on 16 March 2014 and the official result was that 97 percent wished to join with Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[190]</a></sup> On 18 March 2014, Russia and the self-proclaimed Republic of Crimea signed a <a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation#Accession_treaty_and_aftermath" title="Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation">treaty of accession of the Republic of Crimea and Sevastopol</a> in the Russian Federation. The UN general assembly responded by passing <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_Resolution_68/262" title="United Nations General Assembly Resolution 68/262">resolution 68/262</a> that the referendum was invalid and supporting the territorial integrity of Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[191]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Separately, in the <a href="/wiki/Donetsk" title="Donetsk">Donetsk</a> and <a href="/wiki/Luhansk" title="Luhansk">Luhansk</a> regions, armed men declaring themselves as local militia supported with pro-Russian protesters<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[192]</a></sup> seized government buildings, police and special police stations in several cities and held unrecognised <a href="/wiki/2014_Donbass_status_referendums" title="2014 Donbass status referendums">status referendums</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[193]</a></sup> The insurgency was led by Russian emissaries <a href="/wiki/Igor_Girkin" title="Igor Girkin">Igor Girkin</a><sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">[194]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Borodai" title="Alexander Borodai">Alexander Borodai</a><sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[195]</a></sup> as well as militants from <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Arseny_Pavlov" class="mw-redirect" title="Arseny Pavlov">Arseny Pavlov</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">[196]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Talks in <a href="/wiki/Geneva" title="Geneva">Geneva</a> between the EU, Russia, Ukraine and USA yielded a Joint Diplomatic Statement referred to as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2014_Geneva_Pact&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2014 Geneva Pact (page does not exist)">2014 Geneva Pact</a><sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[197]</a></sup> in which the parties requested that all unlawful militias lay down their arms and vacate seized government buildings, and also establish a political dialogue that could lead to more autonomy for Ukraine's regions. When <a href="/wiki/Petro_Poroshenko" title="Petro Poroshenko">Petro Poroshenko</a> won the presidential election held on 25 May 2014, he vowed to continue the military operations by the Ukrainian government forces to end the armed insurgency.<sup id="cite_ref-G26514P_202-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-G26514P-202">[198]</a></sup> More than 9,000 people have been killed in the military campaign.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>In August 2014, a bilateral commission of leading scholars from the United States and Russia issued the Boisto Agenda indicating a 24-step plan to resolve the crisis in Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-Uri_Friedman_2014_203-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Uri_Friedman_2014-203">[199]</a></sup> The Boisto Agenda was organized into five imperative categories for addressing the crisis requiring stabilization identified as: (1) Elements of an Enduring, Verifiable Ceasefire; (2) Economic Relations; (3) Social and Cultural Issues; (4) Crimea; and, (5) International Status of Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-Uri_Friedman_2014_203-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Uri_Friedman_2014-203">[199]</a></sup> In late 2014, Ukraine ratified the <a href="/wiki/Ukraine%E2%80%93European_Union_Association_Agreement" title="Ukraine–European Union Association Agreement">Ukraine–European Union Association Agreement</a>, which Poroshenko described as Ukraine's "first but most decisive step" towards EU membership.<sup id="cite_ref-DW_16.09.2014_204-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DW_16.09.2014-204">[200]</a></sup> Poroshenko also set 2020 as the target for <a href="/wiki/Ukraine%E2%80%93European_Union_relations" title="Ukraine–European Union relations">EU membership application</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Reuters_Sep_25,_2014_205-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reuters_Sep_25,_2014-205">[201]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:OSCE_SMM_monitoring_the_movement_of_heavy_weaponry_in_eastern_Ukraine_(16705750566).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/OSCE_SMM_monitoring_the_movement_of_heavy_weaponry_in_eastern_Ukraine_%2816705750566%29.jpg/220px-OSCE_SMM_monitoring_the_movement_of_heavy_weaponry_in_eastern_Ukraine_%2816705750566%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/OSCE_SMM_monitoring_the_movement_of_heavy_weaponry_in_eastern_Ukraine_%2816705750566%29.jpg/330px-OSCE_SMM_monitoring_the_movement_of_heavy_weaponry_in_eastern_Ukraine_%2816705750566%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/OSCE_SMM_monitoring_the_movement_of_heavy_weaponry_in_eastern_Ukraine_%2816705750566%29.jpg/440px-OSCE_SMM_monitoring_the_movement_of_heavy_weaponry_in_eastern_Ukraine_%2816705750566%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="2002"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:OSCE_SMM_monitoring_the_movement_of_heavy_weaponry_in_eastern_Ukraine_(16705750566).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">OSCE</a> SMM monitoring the movement of heavy weaponry in eastern Ukraine, 4 March 2015
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In February 2015, after a summit hosted in Belarus, Poroshenko negotiated a ceasefire with the separatist troops. This included conditions such as the withdrawal of heavy weaponry from the front line and decentralisation of rebel regions by the end of 2015. It also included conditions such as Ukrainian control of the border with Russia in 2015 and the withdrawal of all foreign troops from Ukrainian territory. The ceasefire began at midnight on 15 February 2015. Participants in this ceasefire also agreed to attend regular meetings to ensure that the agreement is respected.<sup id="cite_ref-The_Guardian_Feb_12,_2015_206-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Guardian_Feb_12,_2015-206">[202]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On 1 January 2016, Ukraine joined the <a href="/wiki/Deep_and_Comprehensive_Free_Trade_Area" title="Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area">Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area</a> with European Union,<sup id="cite_ref-European_Commission_Trade_Ukraine_14-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-European_Commission_Trade_Ukraine-14">[11]</a></sup> which aims to modernize and develop Ukraine's economy, governance and rule of law to EU standards and gradually increase integration with the EU <a href="/wiki/Internal_market" class="mw-redirect" title="Internal market">Internal market</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-DCFTA_Ukr_207-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DCFTA_Ukr-207">[203]</a></sup> Then, on 11 May 2017 the European Union approved visa-free travel for Ukrainian citizens: this took effect from 11 June entitling Ukrainians to travel to the <a href="/wiki/Schengen_area" class="mw-redirect" title="Schengen area">Schengen area</a> for tourism, family visits and business reasons, with the only document required being a valid biometric passport.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[204]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="COVID-19">COVID-19</span></h3>
      <p><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Writing_better_articles#Stay_on_topic" title="Wikipedia:Writing better articles"><span title="The material near this tag may contain information that is not relevant to the article's main topic. (September 2020)">relevant?</span></a> <span class="metadata"> – <a href="/wiki/Talk:Ukraine" title="Talk:Ukraine">discuss</a></span></i>]</sup> </p>
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Ukraine" title="COVID-19 pandemic in Ukraine">COVID-19 pandemic in Ukraine</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The first case of <a href="/wiki/COVID-19" class="mw-redirect" title="COVID-19">COVID-19</a> in Ukraine was recorded on 3 March.<sup id="cite_ref-c19kp_209-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-c19kp-209">[205]</a></sup> On 13 March, the <a href="/wiki/National_Bank_of_Ukraine" title="National Bank of Ukraine">National Bank of Ukraine</a> cut interest rates from 11% to 10% to help stop the coronavirus panic.<sup id="cite_ref-c19fe_210-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-c19fe-210">[206]</a></sup> On 17 March the passage of Law No. 3219, "On Amending Certain Legislative Acts of Ukraine aimed at Preventing the Occurrence and Spread of Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19)" modified the <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Ukraine#Criminal_law" title="Law of Ukraine">Criminal Code of Ukraine</a> to include rules of behaviour designed to halt the spread of the disease,<sup id="cite_ref-c19iu_211-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-c19iu-211">[207]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-c19ukri_212-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-c19ukri-212">[208]</a></sup> and attributed the measures in law to <a href="/wiki/Force_majeure" title="Force majeure">force majeure</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-c19iu_211-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-c19iu-211">[207]</a></sup> a total of 344 deputies out of 450 in the <a href="/wiki/Verkhovna_Rada" title="Verkhovna Rada">Verkhovna Rada</a> voted in favour of Law No. 3219.<sup id="cite_ref-c19iu_211-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-c19iu-211">[207]</a></sup> On 17 March, the international border was closed to foreigners.<sup id="cite_ref-c19rt_213-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-c19rt-213">[209]</a></sup> Other measures included shuttering, at least until 3 April, all "cafes, restaurants, gyms, shopping malls, and entertainment venues",<sup id="cite_ref-c19rt_213-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-c19rt-213">[209]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Ukrzaliznytsia" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukrzaliznytsia">Ukrzaliznytsia passenger rail service</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-c19ro_214-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-c19ro-214">[210]</a></sup> all domestic flights, and public intercity transportation such as the metro in Kyiv, Dnipro, and Kharkiv.<sup id="cite_ref-c19rt_213-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-c19rt-213">[209]</a></sup> The ban on travel in the Kyiv metro caused chaos, as commuters were forced to assemble instead at bus stops.<sup id="cite_ref-c19vid_215-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-c19vid-215">[211]</a></sup> The government also placed on the right to assembly a limit of 10 individuals.<sup id="cite_ref-c19rt_213-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-c19rt-213">[209]</a></sup> As of 19 March, the number of infections had risen to 21, and three deaths had been reported.<sup id="cite_ref-c19rt_213-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-c19rt-213">[209]</a></sup> On 22 March, Zelensky asked <a href="/wiki/IMF" class="mw-redirect" title="IMF">IMF</a> Managing Director <a href="/wiki/Kristalina_Georgieva" title="Kristalina Georgieva">Kristalina Georgieva</a> for permission to participate in the $1 trillion IMF coronavirus bailout fund.<sup id="cite_ref-dtuzg_216-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dtuzg-216">[212]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On 29 May, Ukraine opened its borders with its neighbours in the EU and <a href="/wiki/Moldova" title="Moldova">Moldova</a>, but not with <a href="/wiki/Belarus" title="Belarus">Belarus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-bsuk_217-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bsuk-217">[213]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Ukraine" title="Geography of Ukraine">Geography of Ukraine</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:%D0%93%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BB%D0%B0_%D0%B7_%D0%9A%D1%83%D0%BA%D1%83%D0%BB%D0%B0.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/%D0%93%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BB%D0%B0_%D0%B7_%D0%9A%D1%83%D0%BA%D1%83%D0%BB%D0%B0.jpg/220px-%D0%93%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BB%D0%B0_%D0%B7_%D0%9A%D1%83%D0%BA%D1%83%D0%BB%D0%B0.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/%D0%93%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BB%D0%B0_%D0%B7_%D0%9A%D1%83%D0%BA%D1%83%D0%BB%D0%B0.jpg/330px-%D0%93%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BB%D0%B0_%D0%B7_%D0%9A%D1%83%D0%BA%D1%83%D0%BB%D0%B0.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/%D0%93%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BB%D0%B0_%D0%B7_%D0%9A%D1%83%D0%BA%D1%83%D0%BB%D0%B0.jpg/440px-%D0%93%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BB%D0%B0_%D0%B7_%D0%9A%D1%83%D0%BA%D1%83%D0%BB%D0%B0.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2300" data-file-height="1533"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:%D0%93%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BB%D0%B0_%D0%B7_%D0%9A%D1%83%D0%BA%D1%83%D0%BB%D0%B0.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>View of <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Carpathian_mountains" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukrainian Carpathian mountains">Carpathian National Park</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hoverla" title="Hoverla">Hoverla</a> at 2,061&nbsp;m (6,762&nbsp;ft), the highest mountain in Ukraine
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>At 603,628 square kilometres (233,062&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi) and with a coastline of 2,782 kilometres (1,729&nbsp;mi), Ukraine is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_European_countries_by_area" title="List of European countries by area">second-largest country by area</a> in <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a>, and the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_outlying_territories_by_area" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries and outlying territories by area">46th-largest country</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_41-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-41">[38]</a></sup> It lies between latitudes <a href="/wiki/44th_parallel_north" title="44th parallel north">44°</a> and <a href="/wiki/53rd_parallel_north" title="53rd parallel north">53° N</a>, and longitudes <a href="/wiki/22nd_meridian_east" title="22nd meridian east">22°</a> and <a href="/wiki/41st_meridian_east" title="41st meridian east">41° E</a>. </p>
      <p>The landscape of Ukraine consists mostly of fertile plains (or <a href="/wiki/Steppes" class="mw-redirect" title="Steppes">steppes</a>) and plateaus, crossed by rivers such as the <a href="/wiki/Dnieper_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Dnieper River">Dnieper</a> (<i lang="uk-Latn" title="Ukrainian-language text">Dnipro</i>), <a href="/wiki/Seversky_Donets" class="mw-redirect" title="Seversky Donets">Seversky Donets</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dniester" title="Dniester">Dniester</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Bug" title="Southern Bug">Southern Bug</a> as they flow south into the <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a> and the smaller <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Azov" title="Sea of Azov">Sea of Azov</a>.
