To the southwest, the <a href="/wiki/Danube_Delta" title="Danube Delta">delta</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Danube" title="Danube">Danube</a> forms the border with Romania. Ukraine's various regions have diverse geographic features ranging from the highlands to the lowlands. The country's only mountains are the <a href="/wiki/Carpathian_Mountains" title="Carpathian Mountains">Carpathian Mountains</a> in the west, of which the highest is the <a href="/wiki/Hora_Hoverla" class="mw-redirect" title="Hora Hoverla">Hora Hoverla</a> at 2,061 metres (6,762&nbsp;ft), and the <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Mountains" title="Crimean Mountains">Crimean Mountains</a> on Crimea, in the extreme south along the coast.<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[214]</a></sup> However Ukraine also has a number of highland regions such as the <a href="/wiki/Volhynian-Podolian_Upland" title="Volhynian-Podolian Upland">Volyn-Podillia Upland</a> (in the west) and the Near-Dnipro Upland (on the right bank of Dnieper); to the east there are the south-western spurs of the <a href="/wiki/Central_Russian_Upland" title="Central Russian Upland">Central Russian Upland</a> over which runs the border with the Russian Federation. Near the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Azov" title="Sea of Azov">Sea of Azov</a> can be found the Donets Ridge and the Near Azov Upland. The <a href="/wiki/Snow_melt" class="mw-redirect" title="Snow melt">snow melt</a> from the mountains feeds the rivers, and natural changes in altitude form sudden drops in elevation and give rise to <a href="/wiki/Waterfalls_of_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="Waterfalls of Ukraine">waterfalls</a>. </p>
      <p>Significant natural resources in Ukraine include iron ore, coal, manganese, natural gas, oil, salt, sulphur, graphite, titanium, magnesium, kaolin, nickel, mercury, timber and an abundance of arable land. Despite this, the country faces a number of major environmental issues such as inadequate supplies of potable water; air- and water-pollution and deforestation, as well as radiation contamination in the north-east from the <a href="/wiki/Chernobyl_disaster" title="Chernobyl disaster">1986 accident at the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant</a>. <a href="/wiki/Hazardous_Waste_Recycling" class="mw-redirect" title="Hazardous Waste Recycling">Recycling toxic household waste</a> is still in its infancy in Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[215]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Soil">Soil</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:%D0%9A%D1%96%D0%BD%D0%B1%D1%83%D1%80%D0%BD%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D0%BA%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%B0_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/%D0%9A%D1%96%D0%BD%D0%B1%D1%83%D1%80%D0%BD%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D0%BA%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%B0_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8.jpg/220px-%D0%9A%D1%96%D0%BD%D0%B1%D1%83%D1%80%D0%BD%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D0%BA%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%B0_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/%D0%9A%D1%96%D0%BD%D0%B1%D1%83%D1%80%D0%BD%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D0%BA%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%B0_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8.jpg/330px-%D0%9A%D1%96%D0%BD%D0%B1%D1%83%D1%80%D0%BD%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D0%BA%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%B0_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/%D0%9A%D1%96%D0%BD%D0%B1%D1%83%D1%80%D0%BD%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D0%BA%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%B0_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8.jpg/440px-%D0%9A%D1%96%D0%BD%D0%B1%D1%83%D1%80%D0%BD%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D0%BA%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%B0_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4282" data-file-height="2844"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:%D0%9A%D1%96%D0%BD%D0%B1%D1%83%D1%80%D0%BD%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D0%BA%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%B0_%D0%B2%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Kinburn_Spit" title="Kinburn Spit">Kinburn sandbar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ochakiv" title="Ochakiv">Ochakiv</a> Raion, <a href="/wiki/Mykolaiv_Oblast" title="Mykolaiv Oblast">Mykolaiv Oblast</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>From northwest to southeast the soils of Ukraine may be divided into three major aggregations:<sup id="cite_ref-britannica.com_220-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britannica.com-220">[216]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8F_%D0%BF%D1%96%D0%B4_%D0%9A%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%BE%D1%8E_%D0%B3%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%8E.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8F_%D0%BF%D1%96%D0%B4_%D0%9A%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%BE%D1%8E_%D0%B3%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%8E.jpg/220px-%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8F_%D0%BF%D1%96%D0%B4_%D0%9A%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%BE%D1%8E_%D0%B3%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%8E.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8F_%D0%BF%D1%96%D0%B4_%D0%9A%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%BE%D1%8E_%D0%B3%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%8E.jpg/330px-%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8F_%D0%BF%D1%96%D0%B4_%D0%9A%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%BE%D1%8E_%D0%B3%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%8E.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8F_%D0%BF%D1%96%D0%B4_%D0%9A%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%BE%D1%8E_%D0%B3%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%8E.jpg/440px-%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8F_%D0%BF%D1%96%D0%B4_%D0%9A%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%BE%D1%8E_%D0%B3%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%8E.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4000" data-file-height="2667"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8F_%D0%BF%D1%96%D0%B4_%D0%9A%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%BE%D1%8E_%D0%B3%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%8E.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Agricultural works in <a href="/wiki/Ivano-Frankivsk_Oblast" title="Ivano-Frankivsk Oblast">Ivano-Frankivsk Oblast</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <ul>
       <li>a zone of sandy <a href="/wiki/Podzol" title="Podzol">podzolized</a> soils</li> 
       <li>a central belt consisting of the extremely fertile Ukrainian black earth (<a href="/wiki/Chornozem" class="mw-redirect" title="Chornozem">chernozems</a>)</li> 
       <li>a zone of chestnut and <a href="/wiki/Soil_salinity" title="Soil salinity">salinized soils</a></li>
      </ul> 
      <p>As much as two-thirds of the country's surface land consists of the so-called black earth, a resource that has made Ukraine one of the most fertile regions in the world and well known as a "breadbasket".<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[217]</a></sup> These soils may be divided into three broad groups: </p> 
      <ul>
       <li>in the north a belt of the so-called deep chernozems, about 5 feet (1.5 metres) thick and rich in humus</li> 
       <li>south and east of the former, a zone of prairie, or ordinary, chernozems, which are equally rich in humus but only about 3 feet (0.91 metres) thick</li> 
       <li>the southernmost belt, which is even thinner and has still less humus</li>
      </ul> 
      <p>Interspersed in various uplands and along the northern and western perimeters of the deep chernozems are mixtures of gray forest soils and podzolized black-earth soils, which together occupy much of Ukraine's remaining area. All these soils are very fertile when sufficient water is available. However, their intensive cultivation, especially on steep slopes, has led to widespread soil erosion and gullying. </p>
      <p>The smallest proportion of the soil cover consists of the chestnut soils of the southern and eastern regions. They become increasingly salinized to the south as they approach the Black Sea.<sup id="cite_ref-britannica.com_220-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britannica.com-220">[216]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="Climate of Ukraine">Climate of Ukraine</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ukraine_map_of_K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Ukraine_map_of_K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification.svg/220px-Ukraine_map_of_K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="159" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Ukraine_map_of_K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification.svg/330px-Ukraine_map_of_K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Ukraine_map_of_K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification.svg/440px-Ukraine_map_of_K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1900" data-file-height="1375"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ukraine_map_of_K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Köppen climate classification of Ukraine
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Ukraine has a mostly <a href="/wiki/Temperate_climate" title="Temperate climate">temperate climate</a>, with the exception of the southern coast of Crimea which has a <a href="/wiki/Subtropical_climate" class="mw-redirect" title="Subtropical climate">subtropical climate</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-faoclimate_222-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-faoclimate-222">[218]</a></sup> The climate is influenced by moderately warm, humid air coming from the Atlantic Ocean.<sup id="cite_ref-ebclimate_223-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ebclimate-223">[219]</a></sup> Average annual temperatures range from 5.5–7&nbsp;°C (41.9–44.6&nbsp;°F) in the north, to 11–13&nbsp;°C (51.8–55.4&nbsp;°F) in the south.<sup id="cite_ref-ebclimate_223-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ebclimate-223">[219]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Precipitation_(meteorology)" class="mw-redirect" title="Precipitation (meteorology)">Precipitation</a> is disproportionately distributed; it is highest in the west and north and lowest in the east and southeast.<sup id="cite_ref-ebclimate_223-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ebclimate-223">[219]</a></sup> Western Ukraine, particularly in the Carpathian Mountains, receives around 1,200 millimetres (47.2&nbsp;in) of precipitation annually, while Crimea and the coastal areas of the Black Sea receive around 400 millimetres (15.7&nbsp;in).<sup id="cite_ref-ebclimate_223-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ebclimate-223">[219]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Ukraine" title="Wildlife of Ukraine">Wildlife of Ukraine</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Ukraine contains six terrestrial ecoregions: <a href="/wiki/Central_European_mixed_forests" title="Central European mixed forests">Central European mixed forests</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Submediterranean_forest_complex" title="Crimean Submediterranean forest complex">Crimean Submediterranean forest complex</a>, <a href="/wiki/East_European_forest_steppe" title="East European forest steppe">East European forest steppe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pannonian_mixed_forests" title="Pannonian mixed forests">Pannonian mixed forests</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carpathian_montane_conifer_forests" title="Carpathian montane conifer forests">Carpathian montane conifer forests</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pontic_steppe" class="mw-redirect" title="Pontic steppe">Pontic steppe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-DinersteinOlson2017_224-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DinersteinOlson2017-224">[220]</a></sup> The country had a 2019 <a href="/wiki/Forest_Landscape_Integrity_Index" title="Forest Landscape Integrity Index">Forest Landscape Integrity Index</a> mean score of 3.3/10, ranking it 151st globally out of 172 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-FLII-Supplementary_225-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FLII-Supplementary-225">[221]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Ukraine is home to a diverse assemblage of animals, fungi, microorganisms and plants. </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Animals">Animals</span></h4> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_fish_in_Ukraine" title="List of fish in Ukraine">List of fish in Ukraine</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_fish_of_the_Black_Sea" title="List of fish of the Black Sea">List of fish of the Black Sea</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:377px;max-width:377px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:186px;max-width:186px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Spermophilus_suslicus2.JPG" class="image"><img alt="speckled ground squirrel" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Spermophilus_suslicus2.JPG/184px-Spermophilus_suslicus2.JPG" decoding="async" width="184" height="123" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Spermophilus_suslicus2.JPG/276px-Spermophilus_suslicus2.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Spermophilus_suslicus2.JPG/368px-Spermophilus_suslicus2.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3544" data-file-height="2372"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The <a href="/wiki/Speckled_ground_squirrel" title="Speckled ground squirrel">speckled ground squirrel</a> is a native of the east Ukrainian steppes.
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:187px;max-width:187px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:%D0%91%D1%83%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%BB_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%BE._%D0%A1%D0%B2%D1%96%D1%82%D1%8F%D0%B7%D1%8C.jpg" class="image"><img alt="White storks danube" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/%D0%91%D1%83%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%BB_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%BE._%D0%A1%D0%B2%D1%96%D1%82%D1%8F%D0%B7%D1%8C.jpg/185px-%D0%91%D1%83%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%BB_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%BE._%D0%A1%D0%B2%D1%96%D1%82%D1%8F%D0%B7%D1%8C.jpg" decoding="async" width="185" height="123" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/%D0%91%D1%83%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%BB_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%BE._%D0%A1%D0%B2%D1%96%D1%82%D1%8F%D0%B7%D1%8C.jpg/278px-%D0%91%D1%83%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%BB_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%BE._%D0%A1%D0%B2%D1%96%D1%82%D1%8F%D0%B7%D1%8C.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/%D0%91%D1%83%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%BB_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%BE._%D0%A1%D0%B2%D1%96%D1%82%D1%8F%D0%B7%D1%8C.jpg/370px-%D0%91%D1%83%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%BB_%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%BE._%D0%A1%D0%B2%D1%96%D1%82%D1%8F%D0%B7%D1%8C.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1500" data-file-height="1000"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/White_stork" title="White stork">White storks</a> are native to south-western and north-western Ukraine.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Ukraine falls into two main zoological areas. One of these areas, in the west of the country, is made up of the borderlands of Europe, where there are species typical of mixed forests, the other is located in eastern Ukraine, where steppe-dwelling species thrive. In the forested areas of the country it is not uncommon to find lynxes, wolves, wild boar and martens, as well as many other similar species; this is especially true of the <a href="/wiki/Carpathian_Mountains" title="Carpathian Mountains">Carpathian Mountains</a>, where many predatory mammals make their home, as well as a contingent of brown bears. Around Ukraine's lakes and rivers beavers, otters and mink make their home, whilst in the waters carp, bream and catfish are the most commonly found species of fish. In the central and eastern parts of the country, rodents such as hamsters and gophers are found in large numbers. </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Fungi">Fungi</span></h4> 
      <p>More than 6,600 <a href="/wiki/Species" title="Species">species</a> of <a href="/wiki/Fungus" title="Fungus">fungi</a> (including <a href="/wiki/Lichen" title="Lichen">lichen</a>-forming species) have been recorded from Ukraine,<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[222]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">[223]</a></sup> but this number is far from complete. The true total number of fungal species occurring in Ukraine, including species not yet recorded, is likely to be far higher, given the generally accepted estimate that only about 7% of all fungi worldwide have so far been discovered.<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[224]</a></sup> Although the amount of available information is still very small, a first effort has been made to estimate the number of fungal species endemic to Ukraine, and 2217 such species have been tentatively identified.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[225]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Ukraine" title="Politics of Ukraine">Politics of Ukraine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Ukraine" title="Government of Ukraine">Government of Ukraine</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_Ukraine" title="Elections in Ukraine">Elections in Ukraine</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/2014_Russian_military_intervention_in_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="2014 Russian military intervention in Ukraine">2014 Russian military intervention in Ukraine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation" title="Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation">Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation</a>, and <a href="/wiki/War_in_Donbass" title="War in Donbass">War in Donbass</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Ukraine is a republic under a mixed semi-parliamentary <a href="/wiki/Semi-presidential_system" title="Semi-presidential system">semi-presidential system</a> with separate <a href="/wiki/Legislative_branch" class="mw-redirect" title="Legislative branch">legislative</a>, <a href="/wiki/Executive_branch" class="mw-redirect" title="Executive branch">executive</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Judicial_branch" class="mw-redirect" title="Judicial branch">judicial branches</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Constitution_of_Ukraine">Constitution of Ukraine</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine" title="Constitution of Ukraine">Constitution of Ukraine</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ukrainian_parliamentary_election,_2007.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Ukrainian_parliamentary_election%2C_2007.jpg/220px-Ukrainian_parliamentary_election%2C_2007.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="205" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Ukrainian_parliamentary_election%2C_2007.jpg/330px-Ukrainian_parliamentary_election%2C_2007.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Ukrainian_parliamentary_election%2C_2007.jpg/440px-Ukrainian_parliamentary_election%2C_2007.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="744"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ukrainian_parliamentary_election,_2007.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>In the modern era, Ukraine has become a more democratic country.<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">[226]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">[227]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">[228]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[229]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>With the proclamation of its independence on 24 August 1991, and adoption of a constitution on 28 June 1996, Ukraine became a semi-presidential republic. However, in 2004, deputies introduced changes to the Constitution, which tipped the balance of power in favour of a <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">parliamentary system</a>. From 2004 to 2010, the legitimacy of the 2004 Constitutional amendments had official sanction, both with the Constitutional Court of Ukraine, and most major political parties.<sup id="cite_ref-1oct_234-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1oct-234">[230]</a></sup> Despite this, on 30 September 2010 the Constitutional Court ruled that the amendments were null and void, forcing a return to the terms of the 1996 Constitution and again making Ukraine's political system more presidential in character. </p>
      <p>The ruling on the 2004 Constitutional amendments became a major topic of political discourse. Much of the concern was based on the fact that neither the Constitution of 1996 nor the Constitution of 2004 provided the ability to "undo the Constitution", as the decision of the Constitutional Court would have it, even though the 2004 constitution arguably has an exhaustive list of possible procedures for constitutional amendments (articles 154–159). In any case, the current Constitution could be modified by a vote in Parliament.<sup id="cite_ref-1oct_234-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1oct-234">[230]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">[231]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">[232]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify"><span title="The text near this tag may need clarification or removal of jargon. (October 2011)">clarification needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>On 21 February 2014 an agreement between President Viktor Yanukovych and opposition leaders saw the country return to the 2004 Constitution. The historic agreement, brokered by the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>, followed protests that began in late November 2013 and culminated in a week of violent clashes in which scores of protesters were killed. In addition to returning the country to the 2004 Constitution, the deal provided for the formation of a coalition government, the calling of early elections, and the release of former Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Yulia_Tymoshenko" title="Yulia Tymoshenko">Yulia Tymoshenko</a> from prison.<sup id="cite_ref-Ukraine2014protests_237-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ukraine2014protests-237">[233]</a></sup> A day after the agreement was reached the Ukraine parliament dismissed Yanukovych and installed its speaker <a href="/wiki/Oleksandr_Turchynov" title="Oleksandr Turchynov">Oleksandr Turchynov</a> as interim president<sup id="cite_ref-UkrainePresidentReplaced_238-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UkrainePresidentReplaced-238">[234]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Arseniy_Yatsenyuk" title="Arseniy Yatsenyuk">Arseniy Yatsenyuk</a> as the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Ukraine" title="Prime Minister of Ukraine">Prime Minister of Ukraine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">[235]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="President.2C_parliament_and_government"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="President,_parliament_and_government">President, parliament and government</span></h3> 
      <table class="wikitable floatright" style="text-align:center;"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/File:Volodymyr_Zelensky_Official_portrait.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Volodymyr Zelensky Official portrait.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Volodymyr_Zelensky_Official_portrait.jpg/141px-Volodymyr_Zelensky_Official_portrait.jpg" decoding="async" width="141" height="191" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Volodymyr_Zelensky_Official_portrait.jpg/212px-Volodymyr_Zelensky_Official_portrait.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Volodymyr_Zelensky_Official_portrait.jpg/282px-Volodymyr_Zelensky_Official_portrait.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3488" data-file-height="4724"></a> </td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%81_%D0%A8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D0%B3%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C_2020_3_(cropped).jpg" class="image"><img alt="Денис Шмигаль 2020 3 (cropped).jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%81_%D0%A8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D0%B3%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C_2020_3_%28cropped%29.jpg/143px-%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%81_%D0%A8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D0%B3%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C_2020_3_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="143" height="191" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%81_%D0%A8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D0%B3%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C_2020_3_%28cropped%29.jpg/215px-%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%81_%D0%A8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D0%B3%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C_2020_3_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%81_%D0%A8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D0%B3%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C_2020_3_%28cropped%29.jpg/286px-%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%81_%D0%A8%D0%BC%D0%B8%D0%B3%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C_2020_3_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="602" data-file-height="803"></a> </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr class="nowrap"> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Volodymyr_Zelensky" title="Volodymyr Zelensky">Volodymyr Zelensky</a><br><small><a href="/wiki/President_of_Ukraine" title="President of Ukraine">President</a></small> </td> 
         <td><a href="/wiki/Denys_Shmyhal" title="Denys Shmyhal">Denys Shmyhal</a><br><small><a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Ukraine" title="Prime Minister of Ukraine">Prime Minister</a></small> </td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/President_of_Ukraine" title="President of Ukraine">President</a> is elected by popular vote for a five-year term and is the formal <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[236]</a></sup> Ukraine's legislative branch includes the 450-seat <a href="/wiki/Unicameral" class="mw-redirect" title="Unicameral">unicameral</a> parliament, the <a href="/wiki/Verkhovna_Rada" title="Verkhovna Rada">Verkhovna Rada</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[237]</a></sup> The parliament is primarily responsible for the formation of the executive branch and the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Ministers_of_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine">Cabinet of Ministers</a>, headed by the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Ukraine" title="Prime Minister of Ukraine">Prime Minister</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[238]</a></sup> However, the President still retains the authority to nominate the Ministers of the Foreign Affairs and of Defence for parliamentary approval, as well as the power to appoint the <a href="/wiki/Prosecutor_General_of_Ukraine" title="Prosecutor General of Ukraine">Prosecutor General</a> and the head of the <a href="/wiki/Security_Service_of_Ukraine" title="Security Service of Ukraine">Security Service</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Pechersk_28_09_13_077.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Pechersk_28_09_13_077.jpg/220px-Pechersk_28_09_13_077.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="164" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Pechersk_28_09_13_077.jpg/330px-Pechersk_28_09_13_077.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Pechersk_28_09_13_077.jpg/440px-Pechersk_28_09_13_077.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4173" data-file-height="3109"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Pechersk_28_09_13_077.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Government_of_Ukraine" title="Government of Ukraine">Cabinet of Ministers</a> building
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Laws, acts of the parliament and the cabinet, presidential decrees, and acts of the <a href="/wiki/Verkhovna_Rada_of_Crimea" title="Verkhovna Rada of Crimea">Crimean parliament</a> may be abrogated by the <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Ukraine" title="Constitutional Court of Ukraine">Constitutional Court</a>, should they be found to violate the constitution. Other normative acts are subject to judicial review. The <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Ukraine" title="Supreme Court of Ukraine">Supreme Court</a> is the main body in the system of courts of general jurisdiction. Local self-government is officially guaranteed. Local councils and city mayors are popularly elected and exercise control over local budgets. The heads of regional and district administrations are appointed by the President in accordance with the proposals of the Prime Minister. This system virtually requires an agreement between the President and the Prime Minister, and has in the past led to problems, such as when President Yushchenko exploited a perceived loophole by appointing so-called 'temporarily acting' officers, instead of actual governors or local leaders, thus evading the need to seek a compromise with the Prime Minister. This practice was controversial and was subject to Constitutional Court review. </p>
      <p>Ukraine has many political parties, many of which have tiny memberships and are unknown to the general public.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2014)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Small parties often join in multi-party coalitions (electoral blocs) for the purpose of participating in parliamentary elections. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Courts_and_law_enforcement">Courts and law enforcement</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Judicial_system_of_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="Judicial system of Ukraine">Judicial system of Ukraine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="Law enforcement in Ukraine">Law enforcement in Ukraine</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Klov_Palace._Listed_ID_80-382-0462._-_8_Pylypa_Orlyka_Street,_Pechersk_Raion,_Kiev._-_Pechersk_28_09_13_396.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Klov_Palace._Listed_ID_80-382-0462._-_8_Pylypa_Orlyka_Street%2C_Pechersk_Raion%2C_Kiev._-_Pechersk_28_09_13_396.jpg/220px-Klov_Palace._Listed_ID_80-382-0462._-_8_Pylypa_Orlyka_Street%2C_Pechersk_Raion%2C_Kiev._-_Pechersk_28_09_13_396.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="132" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Klov_Palace._Listed_ID_80-382-0462._-_8_Pylypa_Orlyka_Street%2C_Pechersk_Raion%2C_Kiev._-_Pechersk_28_09_13_396.jpg/330px-Klov_Palace._Listed_ID_80-382-0462._-_8_Pylypa_Orlyka_Street%2C_Pechersk_Raion%2C_Kiev._-_Pechersk_28_09_13_396.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Klov_Palace._Listed_ID_80-382-0462._-_8_Pylypa_Orlyka_Street%2C_Pechersk_Raion%2C_Kiev._-_Pechersk_28_09_13_396.jpg/440px-Klov_Palace._Listed_ID_80-382-0462._-_8_Pylypa_Orlyka_Street%2C_Pechersk_Raion%2C_Kiev._-_Pechersk_28_09_13_396.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3900" data-file-height="2338"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Klov_Palace._Listed_ID_80-382-0462._-_8_Pylypa_Orlyka_Street,_Pechersk_Raion,_Kiev._-_Pechersk_28_09_13_396.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Klov_Palace" title="Klov Palace">Klovsky Palace</a>, home to the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Ukraine" title="Supreme Court of Ukraine">Supreme Court of Ukraine</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The courts enjoy legal, financial and constitutional freedom guaranteed by Ukrainian law since 2002. Judges are largely well protected from dismissal (except in the instance of gross misconduct). Court justices are appointed by presidential decree for an initial period of five years, after which Ukraine's Supreme Council confirms their positions for life. Although there are still problems, the system is considered to have been much improved since Ukraine's independence in 1991. The Supreme Court is regarded as an independent and impartial body, and has on several occasions ruled against the Ukrainian government. The <a href="/wiki/World_Justice_Project" title="World Justice Project">World Justice Project</a> ranks Ukraine 66 out of 99 countries surveyed in its annual Rule of Law Index.<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">[239]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Prosecutor" title="Prosecutor">Prosecutors</a> in Ukraine have greater powers than in most European countries, and according to the <a href="/wiki/European_Commission_for_Democracy_through_Law" class="mw-redirect" title="European Commission for Democracy through Law">European Commission for Democracy through Law</a> 'the role and functions of the Prosecutor's Office is not in accordance with <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a> standards".<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">[240]</a></sup> The criminal judicial system maintains an average <a href="/wiki/Conviction_rate" title="Conviction rate">conviction rate</a> of over 99%,<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">[241]</a></sup> equal to the conviction rate of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>, with<sup id="cite_ref-Moskal_246-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Moskal-246">[242]</a></sup> suspects often being incarcerated for long periods before trial.<sup id="cite_ref-rotten_247-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rotten-247">[243]</a></sup> On 24 March 2010, President Yanukovych formed an expert group to make recommendations how to "clean up the current mess and adopt a law on court organization".<sup id="cite_ref-rotten_247-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rotten-247">[243]</a></sup> One day later, he stated "We can no longer disgrace our country with such a court system."<sup id="cite_ref-rotten_247-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rotten-247">[243]</a></sup> The criminal judicial system and the prison system of Ukraine remain quite punitive. </p>
      <p>Since 1 January 2010 it has been permissible to hold court proceedings in Russian by mutual consent of the parties. Citizens unable to speak <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">Ukrainian</a> or Russian may use their native language or the services of a translator.<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">[244]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">[245]</a></sup> Previously all court proceedings had to be held in Ukrainian. </p>
      <p>Law enforcement agencies in Ukraine are organised under the authority of the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Internal_Affairs_of_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="Ministry of Internal Affairs of Ukraine">Ministry of Internal Affairs</a>. They consist primarily of the national police force <i>(<a href="/wiki/Militsiya" title="Militsiya">Мiлiцiя</a>)</i> and various specialised units and agencies such as the <a href="/wiki/State_Border_Guard_Service_of_Ukraine" title="State Border Guard Service of Ukraine">State Border Guard</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Sea_Guard" title="Ukrainian Sea Guard">Coast Guard</a> services. Law enforcement agencies, particularly the police, faced criticism for their heavy handling of the 2004 <a href="/wiki/Orange_Revolution" title="Orange Revolution">Orange Revolution</a>. Many thousands of police officers were stationed throughout the capital, primarily to dissuade protesters from challenging the state's authority but also to provide a quick reaction force in case of need; most officers were armed.<sup id="cite_ref-NYTSBU_250-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYTSBU-250">[246]</a></sup> Bloodshed was only avoided when Lt. Gen. <a href="/wiki/Sergei_Popkov" title="Sergei Popkov">Sergei Popkov</a> heeded his colleagues' calls to withdraw. </p>
      <p>The Ministry of Internal Affairs is also responsible for the maintenance of the <a href="/wiki/Security_Service_of_Ukraine" title="Security Service of Ukraine">State Security Service</a>; Ukraine's domestic intelligence agency, which has on occasion been accused of acting like a <a href="/wiki/Secret_police" title="Secret police">secret police</a> force serving to protect the country's political elite from media criticism. On the other hand, however, it is widely accepted that members of the service provided vital information about government plans to the leaders of the Orange Revolution to prevent the collapse of the movement. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Ukraine" title="Foreign relations of Ukraine">Foreign relations of Ukraine</a>, <a href="/wiki/International_membership_of_Ukraine" title="International membership of Ukraine">International membership of Ukraine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ukraine%E2%80%93European_Union_relations" title="Ukraine–European Union relations">Ukraine–European Union relations</a>, and <a href="/wiki/The_World_Bank_in_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="The World Bank in Ukraine">The World Bank in Ukraine</a>
      </div> 
      <p>In 1999–2001, Ukraine served as a non-permanent member of the <a href="/wiki/UN_Security_Council" class="mw-redirect" title="UN Security Council">UN Security Council</a>. Historically, Soviet Ukraine joined the United Nations in 1945 as one of the original members following a Western compromise with the Soviet Union, which had asked for seats for all 15 of its union republics. Ukraine has consistently supported peaceful, negotiated settlements to disputes. It has participated in the quadripartite talks on the conflict in Moldova and promoted a peaceful resolution to conflict in the post-Soviet state of Georgia. Ukraine also has made a substantial contribution to UN <a href="/wiki/Peacekeeping" title="Peacekeeping">peacekeeping</a> operations since 1992. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Normandy_format_talks_in_Minsk_(February_2015)_03_cropped.jpeg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Normandy_format_talks_in_Minsk_%28February_2015%29_03_cropped.jpeg/220px-Normandy_format_talks_in_Minsk_%28February_2015%29_03_cropped.jpeg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Normandy_format_talks_in_Minsk_%28February_2015%29_03_cropped.jpeg/330px-Normandy_format_talks_in_Minsk_%28February_2015%29_03_cropped.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Normandy_format_talks_in_Minsk_%28February_2015%29_03_cropped.jpeg/440px-Normandy_format_talks_in_Minsk_%28February_2015%29_03_cropped.jpeg 2x" data-file-width="500" data-file-height="334"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Normandy_format_talks_in_Minsk_(February_2015)_03_cropped.jpeg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Leaders of <a href="/wiki/Belarus" title="Belarus">Belarus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a>, <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a>, and Ukraine at the <a href="/wiki/Minsk_II" class="mw-redirect" title="Minsk II">Minsk II</a> summit, 2015
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:EU_DCFTA_EFTA.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/EU_DCFTA_EFTA.svg/220px-EU_DCFTA_EFTA.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="168" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/EU_DCFTA_EFTA.svg/330px-EU_DCFTA_EFTA.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/EU_DCFTA_EFTA.svg/440px-EU_DCFTA_EFTA.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="680" data-file-height="520"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:EU_DCFTA_EFTA.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>In January 2016, Ukraine joined the <a href="/wiki/Deep_and_Comprehensive_Free_Trade_Area" title="Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area">Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area</a> (green) with the EU (blue), established by the <a href="/wiki/Ukraine%E2%80%93European_Union_Association_Agreement" title="Ukraine–European Union Association Agreement">Ukraine–European Union Association Agreement</a>, opening its path towards <a href="/wiki/European_integration" title="European integration">European integration</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Ukraine currently considers Euro-Atlantic integration its primary foreign policy objective,<sup id="cite_ref-result_of_Russia_251-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-result_of_Russia-251">[247]</a></sup> but in practice it has always balanced its relationship with the European Union and the United States with strong ties to Russia. The <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Partnership_and_Cooperation_Agreement" class="mw-redirect" title="Partnership and Cooperation Agreement">Partnership and Cooperation Agreement</a> (PCA) with Ukraine went into force on 1 March 1998. The European Union (EU) has encouraged Ukraine to implement the PCA fully before discussions begin on an association agreement, issued at the EU Summit in December 1999 in <a href="/wiki/Helsinki" title="Helsinki">Helsinki</a>, recognizes Ukraine's long-term aspirations but does not discuss association. On 31 January 1992, Ukraine joined the then-Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe (now the <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Cooperation_in_Europe" class="mw-redirect" title="Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe">Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe</a> (OSCE)), and on 10 March 1992, it became a member of the <a href="/wiki/North_Atlantic_Cooperation_Council" class="mw-redirect" title="North Atlantic Cooperation Council">North Atlantic Cooperation Council</a>. <a href="/wiki/Ukraine%E2%80%93NATO_relations" title="Ukraine–NATO relations">Ukraine–NATO relations</a> are close and the country has declared interest in eventual membership.<sup id="cite_ref-result_of_Russia_251-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-result_of_Russia-251">[247]</a></sup> This was removed from the government's foreign policy agenda upon election of <a href="/wiki/Viktor_Yanukovych" title="Viktor Yanukovych">Viktor Yanukovych</a> to the presidency, in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-result_of_Russia_251-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-result_of_Russia-251">[247]</a></sup> But after February 2014's <a href="/wiki/2014_Ukrainian_revolution" class="mw-redirect" title="2014 Ukrainian revolution">Yanukovych ouster</a> and the (denied by Russia) following Russian military intervention in Ukraine Ukraine renewed its drive for NATO membership.<sup id="cite_ref-result_of_Russia_251-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-result_of_Russia-251">[247]</a></sup> Ukraine is the most active member of the <a href="/wiki/Partnership_for_Peace" title="Partnership for Peace">Partnership for Peace</a> (PfP). All major political parties in Ukraine support full eventual integration into the European Union. The Association Agreement with the EU was expected to be signed and put into effect by the end of 2011, but the process was suspended by 2012 because of the political developments of that time.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">[248]</a></sup> The Association Agreement between Ukraine and the European Union was signed in 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">[249]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Ukraine long had close ties with all its neighbours, but <a href="/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93Ukraine_relations" title="Russia–Ukraine relations">Russia–Ukraine relations</a> became difficult in 2014 by the <a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation" title="Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation">annexation of Crimea</a>, energy dependence and payment disputes. There are also tensions with <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">Poland</a><sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[250]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Hungary" title="Hungary">Hungary</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">[251]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Deep_and_Comprehensive_Free_Trade_Area" title="Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area">Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area</a> (DCFTA), which entered into force in January 2016 following the ratification of the <a href="/wiki/Ukraine%E2%80%93European_Union_Association_Agreement" title="Ukraine–European Union Association Agreement">Ukraine–European Union Association Agreement</a>, formally integrates Ukraine into the <a href="/wiki/European_Single_Market" title="European Single Market">European Single Market</a> and the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Area" title="European Economic Area">European Economic Area</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">[252]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">[253]</a></sup> Ukraine receives further support and assistance for its <a href="/wiki/Future_enlargement_of_the_European_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Future enlargement of the European Union">EU-accession</a> aspirations from the International Visegrád Fund of the <a href="/wiki/Visegr%C3%A1d_Group" title="Visegrád Group">Visegrád Group</a> that consists of <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central European</a> <a href="/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union" title="Member state of the European Union">EU members</a> the Czech Republic, Poland, Hungary and Slovakia.<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">[254]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Ukraine" title="Administrative divisions of Ukraine">Administrative divisions of Ukraine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_historical_regions" title="Ukrainian historical regions">Ukrainian historical regions</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Political_status_of_Crimea_and_Sevastopol" class="mw-redirect" title="Political status of Crimea and Sevastopol">Political status of Crimea and Sevastopol</a> and <a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation" title="Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation">Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The system of Ukrainian subdivisions reflects the country's status as a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary state</a> (as stated in the country's constitution) with unified legal and <a href="/wiki/Local_government" title="Local government">administrative</a> regimes for each unit. </p>
      <p>Including Sevastopol and the Autonomous Republic of Crimea that were annexed by the Russian Federation in 2014, Ukraine consists of 27 regions: twenty-four <a href="/wiki/Oblast" title="Oblast">oblasts</a> (provinces), one <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_republic" title="Autonomous republic">autonomous republic</a> (<a href="/wiki/Autonomous_Republic_of_Crimea" title="Autonomous Republic of Crimea">Autonomous Republic of Crimea</a>), and two cities of special status – <a href="/wiki/Kyiv" title="Kyiv">Kyiv</a>, the capital, and <a href="/wiki/Sevastopol" title="Sevastopol">Sevastopol</a>. The 24 oblasts and Crimea are subdivided into 136<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">[255]</a></sup> <i lang="uk-Latn" title="Ukrainian-language text"><a href="/wiki/Raion" title="Raion">raions</a></i> (districts) and city municipalities of regional significance, or second-level administrative units. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Populated_places_in_Ukraine" title="Populated places in Ukraine">Populated places in Ukraine</a> are split into two categories: urban and rural. Urban populated places are split further into cities and <a href="/wiki/Urban-type_settlement" title="Urban-type settlement">urban-type settlements</a> (a Soviet administrative invention), while rural populated places consist of villages and settlements (a generally used term). All cities have certain degree of self-rule depending on their significance such as national significance (as in the case of Kyiv and Sevastopol), regional significance (within each oblast or autonomous republic) or district significance (all the rest of cities). A city's significance depends on several factors such as its population, socio-economic and historical importance, infrastructure and others. </p> 
      <table class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto;"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td>
          <div style="text-shadow:white 0em 0em 0.4em; font-family:Cambria, Georgia, Times, 'Times New Roman', serif;">

             <a href="/wiki/Zakarpattia_Oblast" title="Zakarpattia Oblast"><img alt="Zakarpattia Oblast" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Karpatska_Ukraina-2_COA.svg/20px-Karpatska_Ukraina-2_COA.svg.png" decoding="async" width="20" height="24" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Karpatska_Ukraina-2_COA.svg/30px-Karpatska_Ukraina-2_COA.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Karpatska_Ukraina-2_COA.svg/40px-Karpatska_Ukraina-2_COA.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="488" data-file-height="594"></a>&nbsp;
             <br><a href="/wiki/Zakarpattia_Oblast" title="Zakarpattia Oblast">Zakarpattia</a>
