      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Armed_forces">Armed forces</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Armed_Forces_of_Ukraine" title="Armed Forces of Ukraine">Armed Forces of Ukraine</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Kissing_the_flag.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Kissing_the_flag.jpg/220px-Kissing_the_flag.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="163" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Kissing_the_flag.jpg/330px-Kissing_the_flag.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Kissing_the_flag.jpg/440px-Kissing_the_flag.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1090" data-file-height="810"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kissing_the_flag.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Henadii Lachkov, commander of the Ukrainian contingent in <a href="/wiki/Multi-National_Force_%E2%80%93_Iraq" title="Multi-National Force – Iraq">Multi-National Force – Iraq</a>, kisses his country's flag
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>After the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Ukraine inherited a 780,000-man military force on its territory, equipped with the third-largest <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapons_and_Ukraine" title="Nuclear weapons and Ukraine">nuclear weapons arsenal</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-milgov_260-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-milgov-260">[256]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">[257]</a></sup> In May 1992, Ukraine signed the <a href="/wiki/Lisbon_Protocol" title="Lisbon Protocol">Lisbon Protocol</a> in which the country agreed to give up all nuclear weapons to Russia for disposal and to join the <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_Non-Proliferation_Treaty" class="mw-redirect" title="Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty">Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty</a> as a non-nuclear weapon state. Ukraine ratified the treaty in 1994, and by 1996 the country became free of nuclear weapons.<sup id="cite_ref-milgov_260-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-milgov-260">[256]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Ukraine took consistent steps toward reduction of conventional weapons. It signed the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_Conventional_Armed_Forces_in_Europe" title="Treaty on Conventional Armed Forces in Europe">Treaty on Conventional Armed Forces in Europe</a>, which called for reduction of tanks, artillery, and armoured vehicles (army forces were reduced to 300,000). The country plans to convert the current <a href="/wiki/Conscript" class="mw-redirect" title="Conscript">conscript</a>-based military into a professional <a href="/wiki/Volunteer_military" title="Volunteer military">volunteer military</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-wbook06_262-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wbook06-262">[258]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Het%27man_Sahaidachnyi_ide_na_chornomu_mori_2012-07-17.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Het%27man_Sahaidachnyi_ide_na_chornomu_mori_2012-07-17.jpg/220px-Het%27man_Sahaidachnyi_ide_na_chornomu_mori_2012-07-17.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Het%27man_Sahaidachnyi_ide_na_chornomu_mori_2012-07-17.jpg/330px-Het%27man_Sahaidachnyi_ide_na_chornomu_mori_2012-07-17.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Het%27man_Sahaidachnyi_ide_na_chornomu_mori_2012-07-17.jpg/440px-Het%27man_Sahaidachnyi_ide_na_chornomu_mori_2012-07-17.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5320" data-file-height="3540"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Het%27man_Sahaidachnyi_ide_na_chornomu_mori_2012-07-17.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Ukrainian frigate <a href="/wiki/Hetman_Sahaydachniy_(U130)" class="mw-redirect" title="Hetman Sahaydachniy (U130)"><i>Hetman Sahaydachniy</i> (U130)</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Ukraine has been playing an increasingly larger role in peacekeeping operations. On Friday 3 January 2014, the Ukrainian frigate <i>Hetman Sagaidachniy</i> joined the European Union's counter piracy <a href="/wiki/Operation_Atalanta" title="Operation Atalanta">Operation Atalanta</a> and will be part of the EU Naval Force off the coast of <a href="/wiki/Somalia" title="Somalia">Somalia</a> for two months.<sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">[259]</a></sup> Ukrainian troops are deployed in <a href="/wiki/Kosovo" title="Kosovo">Kosovo</a> as part of the <a href="/wiki/Polish-Ukrainian_Peace_Force_Battalion" class="mw-redirect" title="Polish-Ukrainian Peace Force Battalion">Ukrainian-Polish Battalion</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">[260]</a></sup> A Ukrainian unit was deployed in <a href="/wiki/Lebanon" title="Lebanon">Lebanon</a>, as part of <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Interim_Force_in_Lebanon" title="United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon">UN Interim Force</a> enforcing the mandated ceasefire agreement. There was also a maintenance and training battalion deployed in <a href="/wiki/Sierra_Leone" title="Sierra Leone">Sierra Leone</a>. In 2003–05, a Ukrainian unit was deployed as part of the <a href="/wiki/Multinational_force_in_Iraq" class="mw-redirect" title="Multinational force in Iraq">Multinational force in Iraq</a> under Polish command. The total Ukrainian armed forces deployment around the world is 562 servicemen.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">[261]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Military units of other states participate in multinational military exercises with Ukrainian forces in Ukraine regularly, including <a href="/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces" title="United States Armed Forces">U.S. military</a> forces.<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">[262]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Following independence, Ukraine declared itself a neutral state.<sup id="cite_ref-gska2.rada.gov.ua_13-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gska2.rada.gov.ua-13">[10]</a></sup> The country has had a limited military partnership with Russian Federation, other CIS countries and a <a href="/wiki/Partnership_for_Peace" title="Partnership for Peace">partnership with NATO</a> since 1994. In the 2000s, the government was leaning towards NATO, and a deeper cooperation with the alliance was set by the NATO-Ukraine Action Plan signed in 2002. It was later agreed that the question of joining NATO should be answered by a national referendum at some point in the future.<sup id="cite_ref-wbook06_262-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wbook06-262">[258]</a></sup> Recently deposed <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_President" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukrainian President">President</a> <a href="/wiki/Viktor_Yanukovych" title="Viktor Yanukovych">Viktor Yanukovych</a> considered the current level of co-operation between <a href="/wiki/Ukraine%E2%80%93NATO_relations" title="Ukraine–NATO relations">Ukraine and NATO</a> sufficient, and was against Ukraine joining NATO. During the <a href="/wiki/2008_Bucharest_summit" title="2008 Bucharest summit">2008 Bucharest summit</a>, NATO declared that Ukraine would eventually become a member of NATO when it meets the criteria for the accession. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Ukraine" title="Economy of Ukraine">Economy of Ukraine</a>
      </div> 
      <table class="box-Update plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Update" role="presentation">
       <tbody>
        <tr>
         <td class="mbox-image">
          <div style="width:52px">
           <img alt="Ambox current red Asia Australia.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg/42px-Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg.png" decoding="async" width="42" height="34" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg/63px-Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg/84px-Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="360" data-file-height="290">
          </div></td>
         <td class="mbox-text">
          <div class="mbox-text-span">
           This section needs to be <b>updated</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please update this article to reflect recent events or newly available information.</span> <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">October 2014</span>)</i></small>
          </div></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:402px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ukraine%27s_GDP_per_capita_compared_to_the_World_(2020).png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Ukraine%27s_GDP_per_capita_compared_to_the_World_%282020%29.png/400px-Ukraine%27s_GDP_per_capita_compared_to_the_World_%282020%29.png" decoding="async" width="400" height="221" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Ukraine%27s_GDP_per_capita_compared_to_the_World_%282020%29.png/600px-Ukraine%27s_GDP_per_capita_compared_to_the_World_%282020%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Ukraine%27s_GDP_per_capita_compared_to_the_World_%282020%29.png/800px-Ukraine%27s_GDP_per_capita_compared_to_the_World_%282020%29.png 2x" data-file-width="6110" data-file-height="3369"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ukraine%27s_GDP_per_capita_compared_to_the_World_(2020).png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Ukraine's GDP per capita compared to the World (2020)<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">[263]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In Soviet times, the economy of Ukraine was the second largest in the Soviet Union, being an important industrial and agricultural component of the country's <a href="/wiki/Planned_economy" title="Planned economy">planned economy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_41-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-41">[38]</a></sup> With the <a href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Dissolution of the Soviet Union">dissolution of the Soviet system</a>, the country moved from a planned economy to a <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">market economy</a>. The transition was difficult for the majority of the population which plunged into poverty.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">[264]</a></sup> Ukraine's economy contracted severely in the years after the Soviet dissolution. Day-to-day life for the average person living in Ukraine was a struggle. A significant number of citizens in rural Ukraine survived by growing their own food, often working two or more jobs and buying the basic necessities through the <a href="/wiki/Barter_economy" class="mw-redirect" title="Barter economy">barter economy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">[265]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 1991, the government liberalised most prices to combat widespread product shortages, and was successful in overcoming the problem. At the same time, the government continued to subsidise state-run industries and agriculture by uncovered monetary emission. The loose monetary policies of the early 1990s pushed inflation to <a href="/wiki/Hyperinflation" title="Hyperinflation">hyperinflationary</a> levels. For the year 1993, Ukraine holds the world record for inflation in one calendar year.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">[266]</a></sup> Those living on fixed incomes suffered the most.<sup id="cite_ref-Britannica_83-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-83">[80]</a></sup> Prices stabilised only after the introduction of new currency, the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_hryvnia" title="Ukrainian hryvnia">hryvnia</a>, in 1996. The country was also slow in implementing structural reforms. Following independence, the government formed a legal framework for <a href="/wiki/Privatisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Privatisation">privatisation</a>. However, widespread resistance to reforms within the government and from a significant part of the population soon stalled the reform efforts. Many state-owned enterprises were exempt from privatisation. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:National_Bank_of_Ukraine_new.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/National_Bank_of_Ukraine_new.jpg/220px-National_Bank_of_Ukraine_new.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="145" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/National_Bank_of_Ukraine_new.jpg/330px-National_Bank_of_Ukraine_new.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/National_Bank_of_Ukraine_new.jpg/440px-National_Bank_of_Ukraine_new.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4340" data-file-height="2867"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:National_Bank_of_Ukraine_new.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/National_Bank_of_Ukraine" title="National Bank of Ukraine">National Bank of Ukraine</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In the meantime, by 1999, the GDP had fallen to less than 40% of the 1991 level.<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">[267]</a></sup> It recovered considerably in the following years.<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">[268]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">[269]</a></sup> Ukraine was hit by the <a href="/wiki/Economic_crisis_of_2008" class="mw-redirect" title="Economic crisis of 2008">economic crisis of 2008</a> and in November 2008, the IMF approved a stand-by loan of $16.5 billion for the country.<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">[270]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2019 the average nominal salary in Ukraine reached 10,000 &nbsp;hryvnias per month or around €300,<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">[271]</a></sup> while in 2018, Ukraine's median wealth per adult was <a href="/wiki/USD" class="mw-redirect" title="USD">$</a>40.<sup id="cite_ref-Global_Wealth_Report_276-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Global_Wealth_Report-276">[272]</a></sup> In 2017, Ukraine's <a href="/wiki/Government_debt" title="Government debt">government debt</a> was 75%.<sup id="cite_ref-stratfor_277-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stratfor-277">[273]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:An-225_Mriya.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/An-225_Mriya.jpg/220px-An-225_Mriya.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/An-225_Mriya.jpg/330px-An-225_Mriya.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/An-225_Mriya.jpg/440px-An-225_Mriya.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3200" data-file-height="2134"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:An-225_Mriya.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Antonov_An-225_Mriya" title="Antonov An-225 Mriya">Antonov An-225 Mriya</a> has the largest wingspan of any aircraft in operational service.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Ukraine produces nearly all types of transportation vehicles and <a href="/wiki/National_Space_Agency_of_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="National Space Agency of Ukraine">spacecraft</a>. <a href="/wiki/Antonov" title="Antonov">Antonov</a> airplanes and <a href="/wiki/KrAZ" title="KrAZ">KrAZ</a> trucks are exported to many countries. The majority of Ukrainian exports are marketed to the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> and <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Independent_States" title="Commonwealth of Independent States">CIS</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">[274]</a></sup> Since independence, Ukraine has maintained its own space agency, the <a href="/wiki/National_Space_Agency_of_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="National Space Agency of Ukraine">National Space Agency of Ukraine</a> (NSAU). Ukraine became an active participant in scientific space exploration and remote sensing missions. Between 1991 and 2007, Ukraine has launched six self made <a href="/wiki/Satellites" class="mw-redirect" title="Satellites">satellites</a> and 101 <a href="/wiki/Launch_vehicle" title="Launch vehicle">launch vehicles</a>, and continues to design spacecraft.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">[275]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">[276]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">[277]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The country imports most energy supplies, especially oil and natural gas and, to a large extent, depends on Russia as its energy supplier. While 25% of the natural gas in Ukraine comes from internal sources, about 35% comes from Russia and the remaining 40% from Central Asia through transit routes that Russia controls. At the same time, 85% of the Russian gas is delivered to <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">Western Europe</a> through Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">[278]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ukraine,_Trends_in_the_Human_Development_Index_1970-2010.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Ukraine%2C_Trends_in_the_Human_Development_Index_1970-2010.png/220px-Ukraine%2C_Trends_in_the_Human_Development_Index_1970-2010.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="79" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Ukraine%2C_Trends_in_the_Human_Development_Index_1970-2010.png/330px-Ukraine%2C_Trends_in_the_Human_Development_Index_1970-2010.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/dd/Ukraine%2C_Trends_in_the_Human_Development_Index_1970-2010.png 2x" data-file-width="440" data-file-height="158"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ukraine,_Trends_in_the_Human_Development_Index_1970-2010.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Trends in the Human Development Index of Ukraine, 1970–2010
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ukraine_salary_by_region_2016.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Ukraine_salary_by_region_2016.svg/220px-Ukraine_salary_by_region_2016.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="160" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Ukraine_salary_by_region_2016.svg/330px-Ukraine_salary_by_region_2016.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Ukraine_salary_by_region_2016.svg/440px-Ukraine_salary_by_region_2016.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="550" data-file-height="400"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ukraine_salary_by_region_2016.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Ukrainian administrative divisions by <a href="/wiki/List_of_Ukrainian_oblasts_and_territories_by_salary" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Ukrainian oblasts and territories by salary">monthly salary</a>. All figures are in the Ukrainian hryvnia.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Growing sectors of the Ukrainian economy include the information technology (IT) market.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">[279]</a></sup> In 2013, Ukraine ranked fourth in the world in number of certified <a href="/wiki/Information_technology" title="Information technology">IT</a> professionals after the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>, <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> and <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ITUkrM2013_284-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ITUkrM2013-284">[280]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Ukraine's 2010 GDP, as calculated by the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>, was around $136&nbsp;billion, 2011 GDP – around $163&nbsp;billion, 2012 – $176.6&nbsp;billion, 2013 – $177.4&nbsp;billion.<sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">[281]</a></sup> In 2014 and 2015, the Ukrainian currency was the world's worst performing currency, having dropped 80 percent of its value since April 2014 since the <a href="/wiki/War_in_Donbass" title="War in Donbass">War in Donbass</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation" title="Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation">annexation of Crimea</a> by Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">[282]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">[283]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a> classifies Ukraine as a middle-income state.<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">[284]</a></sup> Significant issues include underdeveloped infrastructure and transportation, corruption and bureaucracy. The public will to fight against corrupt officials and business elites culminated in a strong wave of public demonstrations against the Victor Yanukovych's regime in November 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289">[285]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Transparency_International" title="Transparency International">Transparency International</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Corruption_Perceptions_Index" title="Corruption Perceptions Index">Corruption Perceptions Index</a>, Ukraine was ranked 120th with a score of 32 out of 100 in 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">[286]</a></sup> In the first quarter of 2017, the level of <a href="/wiki/Shadow_economy" class="mw-redirect" title="Shadow economy">shadow economy</a> in Ukraine amounted to 37% of GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">[287]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the 2000s Ukraine managed to achieve certain progress in reducing absolute poverty, ensuring access to primary and secondary education, improving maternal health and reducing child mortality.<sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">[288]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The economy of Ukraine overcame the heavy crisis caused by <a href="/wiki/War_in_Donbass" title="War in Donbass">armed conflict in southeast</a> part of country. At the same time, 200% devaluation of Ukrainian hryvnia (national currency) in 2014–2015 made Ukrainian goods and services cheaper and more сompetitive.<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">[289]</a></sup> In 2016, for the first time since 2010, the economy grew more than 2%. According to <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a> statement growth is projected at 2% in 2017 and 3.5% in 2018. </p>
      <p>As of 2017, according to major economic classifications of countries such as gross domestic product (at purchasing power parity) or the Human Development Index, Ukraine is the second poorest country in Europe, after Moldova.<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">[290]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">[291]</a></sup> Ukraine has one of the most equal income distribution as measured by the <a href="/wiki/Gini_index" class="mw-redirect" title="Gini index">Gini index</a> and <a href="/wiki/Income_inequality_metrics" title="Income inequality metrics">Palma ratio</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">[292]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Corporations">Corporations</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Sea_Launch_01.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Sea_Launch_01.jpg/220px-Sea_Launch_01.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="204" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Sea_Launch_01.jpg/330px-Sea_Launch_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Sea_Launch_01.jpg/440px-Sea_Launch_01.jpg 2x" data-file-width="860" data-file-height="797"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Sea_Launch_01.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A launch of the <a href="/wiki/Zenit-3SL" title="Zenit-3SL">Zenit-3SL</a> rocket from the <a href="/wiki/Sea_Launch" title="Sea Launch">Sea Launch</a> platform <i><a href="/wiki/Ocean_Odyssey" class="mw-redirect" title="Ocean Odyssey">Ocean Odyssey</a></i>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Ukraine has a very large heavy-industry base and is one of the largest refiners of metallurgical products in Eastern Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">[293]</a></sup> However, the country is also well known for its production of high-technological goods and transport products, such as <a href="/wiki/Antonov" title="Antonov">Antonov</a> aircraft and various private and commercial vehicles.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> The country's largest and most competitive firms are components of the <a href="/wiki/PFTS_index" title="PFTS index">PFTS index</a>, traded on the <a href="/wiki/PFTS_Ukraine_Stock_Exchange" title="PFTS Ukraine Stock Exchange">PFTS Ukraine Stock Exchange</a>. </p>
      <p>Well-known Ukrainian brands include <a href="/wiki/Naftogaz_Ukrainy" class="mw-redirect" title="Naftogaz Ukrainy">Naftogaz Ukrainy</a>, <a href="/wiki/AvtoZAZ" title="AvtoZAZ">AvtoZAZ</a>, <a href="/wiki/PrivatBank" title="PrivatBank">PrivatBank</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roshen" title="Roshen">Roshen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yuzhmash" title="Yuzhmash">Yuzhmash</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nemiroff" title="Nemiroff">Nemiroff</a>, <a href="/wiki/Motor_Sich" title="Motor Sich">Motor Sich</a>, <a href="/wiki/Khortytsia_(company)" title="Khortytsia (company)">Khortytsia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kyivstar" title="Kyivstar">Kyivstar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Aerosvit" class="mw-redirect" title="Aerosvit">Aerosvit</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">[294]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Ukraine is regarded as a developing economy with high potential for future success, though such a development is thought likely only with new all-encompassing economic and legal reforms.<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">[295]</a></sup> Although <a href="/wiki/Foreign_Direct_Investment" class="mw-redirect" title="Foreign Direct Investment">Foreign Direct Investment</a> in Ukraine remained relatively strong since <a href="/wiki/Early_1990s_recession" title="Early 1990s recession">recession of the early 1990s</a>, the country has had trouble maintaining stable economic growth. The reasons are the takeover and monopolisation of traditional heavy industries by wealthy individuals such as <a href="/wiki/Rinat_Akhmetov" title="Rinat Akhmetov">Rinat Akhmetov</a>, the enduring failure to broaden the nation's economic base and a lack of effective legal protection for investors and their products.<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">[296]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Ukraine" title="Transport in Ukraine">Transport in Ukraine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Railways" title="Ukrainian Railways">Ukrainian Railways</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:411px;max-width:411px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:%D0%A1%D0%BA%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B4_%22%D0%A5%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B4%D0%B0%D0%B9%22.jpg" class="image"><img alt="HRCS2 unit" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/%D0%A1%D0%BA%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B4_%22%D0%A5%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B4%D0%B0%D0%B9%22.jpg/200px-%D0%A1%D0%BA%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B4_%22%D0%A5%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B4%D0%B0%D0%B9%22.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="144" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/%D0%A1%D0%BA%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B4_%22%D0%A5%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B4%D0%B0%D0%B9%22.jpg/300px-%D0%A1%D0%BA%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B4_%22%D0%A5%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B4%D0%B0%D0%B9%22.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/%D0%A1%D0%BA%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B4_%22%D0%A5%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B4%D0%B0%D0%B9%22.jpg/400px-%D0%A1%D0%BA%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B4_%22%D0%A5%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B4%D0%B0%D0%B9%22.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2232" data-file-height="1611"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/HRCS2_multiple_unit" class="mw-redirect" title="HRCS2 multiple unit">HRCS2 multiple unit</a>. <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Railways" title="Ukrainian Railways">Rail transport</a> is heavily utilised in Ukraine.
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:205px;max-width:205px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:%D0%A1%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%BE%D0%B6%D0%B0%D0%BD%D1%89%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B0_(%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B4).jpg" class="image"><img alt="Couchette" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/%D0%A1%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%BE%D0%B6%D0%B0%D0%BD%D1%89%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B0_%28%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B4%29.jpg/203px-%D0%A1%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%BE%D0%B6%D0%B0%D0%BD%D1%89%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B0_%28%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B4%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="203" height="143" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/%D0%A1%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%BE%D0%B6%D0%B0%D0%BD%D1%89%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B0_%28%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B4%29.jpg/305px-%D0%A1%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%BE%D0%B6%D0%B0%D0%BD%D1%89%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B0_%28%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B4%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/%D0%A1%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%BE%D0%B6%D0%B0%D0%BD%D1%89%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B0_%28%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B4%29.jpg/406px-%D0%A1%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%BE%D0%B6%D0%B0%D0%BD%D1%89%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B0_%28%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%B4%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="722"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           A typical Ukrainian <a href="/wiki/Couchette" class="mw-redirect" title="Couchette">couchette</a> for long distance trains
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In total, Ukrainian paved roads stretch for 164,732 kilometres (102,360&nbsp;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-cia_41-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-41">[38]</a></sup> Major routes, marked with the letter 'M' for 'International' <i>(<a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Language" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukrainian Language">Ukrainian</a>: Міжнародний</i>), extend nationwide and connect all major cities of Ukraine, and provide cross-border routes to the country's neighbours. There are only two true <a href="/wiki/Motorway" class="mw-redirect" title="Motorway">motorway</a> standard highways in Ukraine; a 175-kilometre (109-mile) stretch of motorway from <a href="/wiki/Kharkiv" title="Kharkiv">Kharkiv</a> to <a href="/wiki/Dnipro" title="Dnipro">Dnipro</a> and a section of the M03 which extends 18&nbsp;km (11&nbsp;mi) from <a href="/wiki/Kyiv" title="Kyiv">Kyiv</a> to <a href="/wiki/Boryspil" title="Boryspil">Boryspil</a>, where the city's <a href="/wiki/Boryspil_Airport" class="mw-redirect" title="Boryspil Airport">international airport</a> is located.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="Statistics (which includes distances) need citations. (July 2013)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Ukraine" title="Rail transport in Ukraine">Rail transport in Ukraine</a> connects all major urban areas, port facilities and <a href="/wiki/Manufacturing" title="Manufacturing">industrial centres</a> with neighbouring countries. The heaviest concentration of <a href="/wiki/Railway_track" class="mw-redirect" title="Railway track">railway track</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Donbas" class="mw-redirect" title="Donbas">Donbas</a> region of Ukraine. Although <a href="/wiki/Rail_freight_transport" title="Rail freight transport">rail freight transport</a> fell in the 1990s, Ukraine is still one of the <a href="/wiki/Rail_usage_statistics_by_country" class="mw-redirect" title="Rail usage statistics by country">world's highest rail users</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">[297]</a></sup> The total amount of railroad track in Ukraine extends for 22,473 kilometres (13,964&nbsp;mi), of which 9,250 kilometres (5,750&nbsp;mi) was electrified in the 2000s.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_41-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-41">[38]</a></sup> Currently the state has a monopoly on the provision of passenger rail transport, and all trains, other than those with cooperation of other foreign companies on international routes, are operated by its company '<a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Railways" title="Ukrainian Railways">Ukrzaliznytsia</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:M18_Valki_Interchange_(Parclo)_Ukraine.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/M18_Valki_Interchange_%28Parclo%29_Ukraine.jpg/220px-M18_Valki_Interchange_%28Parclo%29_Ukraine.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/M18_Valki_Interchange_%28Parclo%29_Ukraine.jpg/330px-M18_Valki_Interchange_%28Parclo%29_Ukraine.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/M18_Valki_Interchange_%28Parclo%29_Ukraine.jpg/440px-M18_Valki_Interchange_%28Parclo%29_Ukraine.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1365"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:M18_Valki_Interchange_(Parclo)_Ukraine.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The Kharkiv–Dnipro motorway (M18)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Transport by air is developing quickly, with a visa-free programme for EU nationals and citizens of a number of other Western nations,<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">[298]</a></sup> the nation's aviation sector is handling a significantly increased number of travellers. The <a href="/wiki/Euro_2012" class="mw-redirect" title="Euro 2012">Euro 2012</a> football tournament, held in Poland and Ukraine as joint hosts, prompted the government to invest heavily in transport infrastructure, and in particular airports.<sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">[299]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Donetsk_International_Airport" title="Donetsk International Airport">Donetsk airport</a>, completed for <a href="/wiki/Euro_2012" class="mw-redirect" title="Euro 2012">Euro 2012</a>, was destroyed by the end of 2014 because of the ongoing war between the government and the separatist movement.<sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">[300]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Boryspil_International_Airport" title="Boryspil International Airport">Kyiv Boryspil</a> is the county's largest international airport; it has three main passenger terminals and is the base for the country's flag carrier, <a href="/wiki/Ukraine_International_Airlines" title="Ukraine International Airlines">Ukraine International Airlines</a>. Other large airports in the country include those in <a href="/wiki/Kharkiv_International_Airport" title="Kharkiv International Airport">Kharkiv</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lviv_International_Airport" class="mw-redirect" title="Lviv International Airport">Lviv</a> and <a href="/wiki/Donetsk_International_Airport" title="Donetsk International Airport">Donetsk</a> (now destroyed), whilst those in <a href="/wiki/Dnipropetrovsk_International_Airport" title="Dnipropetrovsk International Airport">Dnipro</a> and <a href="/wiki/Odessa_International_Airport" class="mw-redirect" title="Odessa International Airport">Odessa</a> have plans for terminal upgrades in the near future. In addition to its flag carrier, Ukraine has a number of airlines including <a href="/wiki/Windrose_Airlines" title="Windrose Airlines">Windrose Airlines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dniproavia" title="Dniproavia">Dniproavia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Azur_Air_Ukraine" title="Azur Air Ukraine">Azur Air Ukraine</a>, and <a href="/wiki/AtlasGlobal_Ukraine" title="AtlasGlobal Ukraine">AtlasGlobal Ukraine</a>. <a href="/wiki/Antonov_Airlines" title="Antonov Airlines">Antonov Airlines</a>, a subsidiary of the Antonov Aerospace Design Bureau is the only operator of the world's largest fixed wing aircraft, the <a href="/wiki/An-225" class="mw-redirect" title="An-225">An-225</a>. </p>
      <p>International maritime travel is mainly provided through the <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Odessa" title="Port of Odessa">Port of Odessa</a>, from where ferries sail regularly to <a href="/wiki/Istanbul" title="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>, <a href="/wiki/Varna" title="Varna">Varna</a> and <a href="/wiki/Haifa" title="Haifa">Haifa</a>. The largest ferry company presently operating these routes is <a href="/wiki/UkrFerry" title="UkrFerry">Ukrferry</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305">[301]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Ukraine" title="Energy in Ukraine">Energy in Ukraine</a>
      </div> 
      <p>In 2014, Ukraine was ranked number 19 on the Emerging Market Energy Security Growth Prosperity Index, published by the <a href="/wiki/Think_tank" title="Think tank">think tank</a> Bisignis Institute, which ranks emerging market countries using government corruption, GDP growth and oil reserve information.<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">[302]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Ukraine produces and processes its own natural gas and <a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">petroleum</a>. However, the majority of these commodities are imported. Eighty percent of Ukrainian natural gas supplies are imported, mainly from <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307">[303]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Natural gas is heavily utilised not only in energy production but also by <a href="/wiki/Steel_industry" class="mw-redirect" title="Steel industry">steel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chemical_industry" title="Chemical industry">chemical</a> industries of the country, as well as by the <a href="/wiki/District_heating" title="District heating">district heating</a> sector. In 2012, <a href="/wiki/Royal_Dutch_Shell" title="Royal Dutch Shell">Shell</a> started exploration drilling for <a href="/wiki/Shale_gas" title="Shale gas">shale gas</a> in Ukraine—a project aimed at the nation's total gas supply independence.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2014)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Following the armed conflict in the Donbass, Ukraine was cut off from half of coal and all of its <a href="/wiki/Anthracite" title="Anthracite">anthracite</a> extraction, dropping Ukrainian coal production by 22 percent in 2014. Russia was Ukraine's largest coal supplier, and in 2014 Russia blocked its coal supplies, forcing 22 Ukrainian power plants to shut down temporarily. </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Power_generation">Power generation</span></h4> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Kernkraftwerk_Saporischschja.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Kernkraftwerk_Saporischschja.JPG/220px-Kernkraftwerk_Saporischschja.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="159" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Kernkraftwerk_Saporischschja.JPG/330px-Kernkraftwerk_Saporischschja.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Kernkraftwerk_Saporischschja.JPG/440px-Kernkraftwerk_Saporischschja.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3790" data-file-height="2737"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kernkraftwerk_Saporischschja.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Zaporizhzhia_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant">Zaporizhzhia nuclear station</a>, the largest nuclear power plant in Europe
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Ukraine has been a net <a href="/wiki/Electricity_market" title="Electricity market">energy exporting</a> country, for example in 2011, 3.3% of electricity produced were exported,<sup id="cite_ref-mpe.kmu.gov.ua_308-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mpe.kmu.gov.ua-308">[304]</a></sup> but also one of Europe's largest <a href="/wiki/Electricity" title="Electricity">energy</a> consumers.<sup id="cite_ref-eia_309-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eia-309">[305]</a></sup> As of 2011<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ukraine&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, 47.6% of total electricity generation was from <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power" title="Nuclear power">nuclear power</a><sup id="cite_ref-mpe.kmu.gov.ua_308-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mpe.kmu.gov.ua-308">[304]</a></sup> The largest <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_plant" title="Nuclear power plant">nuclear power plant</a> in Europe, the <a href="/wiki/Zaporizhzhia_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant">Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant</a>, is located in Ukraine. Until the 2010s, all of Ukraine's nuclear fuel was coming from Russia. In 2008 <a href="/wiki/Westinghouse_Electric_Company" title="Westinghouse Electric Company">Westinghouse Electric Company</a> won a five-year contract selling nuclear fuel to three Ukrainian reactors starting in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">[306]</a></sup> Following <a href="/wiki/Euromaidan" title="Euromaidan">Euromaidan</a> then President <a href="/wiki/Viktor_Yanukovych" title="Viktor Yanukovych">Viktor Yanukovych</a> introduced a ban on <a href="/wiki/Rosatom" title="Rosatom">Rosatom</a> nuclear fuel shipments to Europe via Ukraine, which was in effect from 28 January until 6 March 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">[307]</a></sup> By 2016, Russia's share was down to 55 percent, <a href="/wiki/Westinghouse_Electric_Company" title="Westinghouse Electric Company">Westinghouse</a> supplying nuclear fuel for six of Ukraine's <a href="/wiki/VVER-1000" class="mw-redirect" title="VVER-1000">VVER-1000</a> nuclear reactors.<sup id="cite_ref-enimp_312-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-enimp-312">[308]</a></sup> After the Russian annexation of Crimea in April 2014, the National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine <a href="/wiki/Energoatom" title="Energoatom">Energoatom</a> and Westinghouse extended the contract for fuel deliveries through 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">[309]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Coal" title="Coal">Coal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">gas</a>-fired <a href="/wiki/Thermal_power_station" title="Thermal power station">thermal power stations</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hydro_power" class="mw-redirect" title="Hydro power">hydroelectricity</a> are the second and third largest kinds of power generation in the country.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (April 2014)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Renewable_energy_use">Renewable energy use</span></h4> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy_in_Ukraine" title="Renewable energy in Ukraine">Renewable energy in Ukraine</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Perovosolarstation.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Perovosolarstation.jpg/220px-Perovosolarstation.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="103" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Perovosolarstation.jpg/330px-Perovosolarstation.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Perovosolarstation.jpg/440px-Perovosolarstation.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="469"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Perovosolarstation.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Perovo_Solar_Park" title="Perovo Solar Park">Perovo Solar Park</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The share of <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy" title="Renewable energy">renewables</a> within the total energy mix is still very small, but is growing fast. Total installed capacity of renewable energy installations more than doubled in 2011 and as of 2012<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ukraine&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> stands at 397&nbsp;MW.<sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314">[310]</a></sup> In 2011 several large <a href="/wiki/Solar_energy" title="Solar energy">solar power stations</a> were opened in Ukraine, among them Europe's largest solar park in Perovo, (Crimea).<sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315">[311]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Economic Bank for Reconstruction and Development estimated in 2012 that Ukraine had great renewable energy potential: the technical potential for wind energy is estimated at 40 TWh/year, small hydropower stations at 8.3 TWh/year, biomass at 120 TWh/year, and solar energy at 50 TWh/year.<sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316">[312]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Internet_and_IT">Internet and IT</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Internet_in_Ukraine" title="Internet in Ukraine">Internet in Ukraine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Telecommunications_in_Ukraine" title="Telecommunications in Ukraine">Telecommunications in Ukraine</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Ukraine has a large and steadily growing <a href="/wiki/Internet" title="Internet">Internet</a> sector, mostly uninfluenced by the <a href="/wiki/Financial_crisis_of_2007%E2%80%9308" class="mw-redirect" title="Financial crisis of 2007–08">financial crisis of 2007–08</a>. As of June&nbsp;2014<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ukraine&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, there were 18.2 million desktop Internet users, which is 56% of the adult population. The core of the audience is the 25 to 34-year-old age bracket, representing 29% of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317">[313]</a></sup> Ukraine ranks 8th among the world's top ten countries with the fastest <a href="/wiki/Internet_access" title="Internet access">Internet access</a> speed.<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">[314]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to A.T. Kearney Global Services Location Index,<sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">[315]</a></sup> Ukraine ranks 24th among the best outsourcing locations, and is among the top 20 offshore services locations in EMEA, according to Gartner.<sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">[316]</a></sup> In the first six months of 2017, the volume of export of computer and information services reached $1.256 billion, which is an 18.3% increase compared to the same period in 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">[317]</a></sup> The IT industry ranks third in the export structure of Ukraine after agro-industry and metallurgy. </p>
      <p>Ukraine's IT sector employs close to 100,000 workers, including 50,000 software developers. This number is expected to surpass the 200,000 mark by 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-auto1_322-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-322">[318]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers"><span title="The date of the event predicted near this tag has passed. (January 2021)">needs update</span></a></i>]</sup> There are over 1,000 IT companies in Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323">[319]</a></sup> In 2017, 13 of them made it to the list of 100 best outsourcing service providers in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-324" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-324">[320]</a></sup> More than 100 multinational tech companies have R&amp;D labs in Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-auto1_322-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-322">[318]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Ukraine ranks first worldwide in the number of <a href="/wiki/C%2B%2B" title="C++">C++</a> and <a href="/wiki/Unity3D" class="mw-redirect" title="Unity3D">Unity3D</a> developers, and second in the number of <a href="/wiki/JavaScript" title="JavaScript">JavaScript</a>, Scala, and Magento engineers.<sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325">[321]</a></sup> 78% of Ukrainian tech workers report having an intermediate or higher level of English proficiency.<sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326">[322]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Ukraine" title="Tourism in Ukraine">Tourism in Ukraine</a>
      </div> 
      <p>In 2007 Ukraine occupied 8th place in Europe by the number of tourists visiting, according to the <a href="/wiki/World_Tourism_Organization" title="World Tourism Organization">World Tourism Organization</a> <a href="/wiki/World_Tourism_rankings" title="World Tourism rankings">rankings</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327">[323]</a></sup> Ukraine has numerous tourist attractions: mountain ranges suitable for <a href="/wiki/Skiing" title="Skiing">skiing</a>, hiking and fishing: the <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a> coastline as a popular summer destination; <a href="/wiki/Nature_reserve" title="Nature reserve">nature reserves</a> of different <a href="/wiki/Ecosystem" title="Ecosystem">ecosystems</a>; churches, <a href="/wiki/Castle" title="Castle">castle</a> ruins and other architectural and park landmarks; various <a href="/wiki/Outdoor_activity" class="mw-redirect" title="Outdoor activity">outdoor activity</a> points. <a href="/wiki/Kyiv" title="Kyiv">Kyiv</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lviv" title="Lviv">Lviv</a>, <a href="/wiki/Odessa" title="Odessa">Odessa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kamyanets-Podilskyi" class="mw-redirect" title="Kamyanets-Podilskyi">Kamyanets-Podilskyi</a> are Ukraine's principal tourist centres each offering many historical landmarks as well as formidable <a href="/wiki/Hospitality" title="Hospitality">hospitality</a> infrastructure. Tourism used to be the mainstay of Crimea's economy but there has been a major fall in visitor numbers following the Russian annexation in 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-328" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-328">[324]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Seven_Wonders_of_Ukraine" title="Seven Wonders of Ukraine">Seven Wonders of Ukraine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Seven_Natural_Wonders_of_Ukraine" title="Seven Natural Wonders of Ukraine">Seven Natural Wonders of Ukraine</a> are the selection of the most important landmarks of Ukraine, chosen by the general public through an Internet-based vote. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Population_of_Ukraine_from_1950_(untitled).svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Population_of_Ukraine_from_1950_%28untitled%29.svg/310px-Population_of_Ukraine_from_1950_%28untitled%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="310" height="207" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Population_of_Ukraine_from_1950_%28untitled%29.svg/465px-Population_of_Ukraine_from_1950_%28untitled%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Population_of_Ukraine_from_1950_%28untitled%29.svg/620px-Population_of_Ukraine_from_1950_%28untitled%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="600"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Population_of_Ukraine_from_1950_(untitled).svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Population of Ukraine from 1950 to 2019
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Ukraine" title="Demographics of Ukraine">Demographics of Ukraine</a>
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Population">Population</span></h3> 
      <p>Post <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> Ukraine's population gradually increased to a peak of 51.9 million in 1993. From 1993 to 2014, the last year the populations in Donbas and Crimea were included, population had decreased by 6.6 million, or 12.8%. The decline was caused by a reduction in birth rate, emigration, and a slight increase in death rate, largely attributed to poor living conditions and low-quality health care.<sup id="cite_ref-nw-20260217_329-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nw-20260217-329">[325]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ukrstat-population_330-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ukrstat-population-330">[326]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Throughout the 19th and 20th centuries, millions of Ukrainians migrated to <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Canadians" title="Ukrainian Canadians">Canada</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Americans" title="Ukrainian Americans">United States</a>, or other parts of the Russian Empire and the Soviet Union, creating a large <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_diaspora" title="Ukrainian diaspora">Ukrainian diaspora</a>. There are about 3 million Ukrainians living in <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331">[327]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332">[328]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Since about 2015 there has been a growing number of Ukrainians working in the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>, particularly <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">Poland</a>. <a href="/wiki/Eurostat" title="Eurostat">Eurostat</a> reported that 662,000 Ukrainians received EU residence permits in 2017, with 585,439 being to Poland. <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a> statistics show that money remittances back to Ukraine have roughly doubled from 2015 to 2018, worth about 4% of GDP. It is unclear if those moving to work in the EU intend this to be temporary of permanent.<sup id="cite_ref-bl-20190220_333-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bl-20190220-333">[329]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-wilsoncenter-20190514_334-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wilsoncenter-20190514-334">[330]</a></sup> There are over 2 million Ukrainians working and living in Poland.<sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335">[331]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-336" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-336">[332]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The industrial regions in the east and southeast are the most heavily populated, and about 67.2% of the population lives in urban areas.<sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337">[333]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnic_composition">Ethnic composition</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ukraine_census_2001_Ukrainians.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Ukraine_census_2001_Ukrainians.svg/220px-Ukraine_census_2001_Ukrainians.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="169" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Ukraine_census_2001_Ukrainians.svg/330px-Ukraine_census_2001_Ukrainians.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Ukraine_census_2001_Ukrainians.svg/440px-Ukraine_census_2001_Ukrainians.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="605" data-file-height="465"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ukraine_census_2001_Ukrainians.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Percentage of ethnic Ukrainians by subdivision according to the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Census_(2001)" title="Ukrainian Census (2001)">2001 census</a> (by oblast)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="barbox tleft" style="overflow-x: auto;"> 
       <div style="border:1px solid silver; font-size:88%; padding:0.4em; width:220px; background: white;">

            <div style="background:#0057b8; width:1%; overflow: hidden;">

            <div style="background:#0057b8; width:3%; overflow: hidden;">

           <td colspan="5" style="padding:5px; text-align:left;"><small>Source: <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20111217151026/http://2001.ukrcensus.gov.ua/eng/results/general/nationality/">Ethnic composition of the population of Ukraine, 2001 Census</a></small></td>
          </tr> 
         </tbody>
        </table> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Census_(2001)" title="Ukrainian Census (2001)">Ukrainian Census of 2001</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ukrainians" title="Ukrainians">Ukrainians</a> make up 77.8% of the population. Other significant ethnic groups include <a href="/wiki/Russians" title="Russians">Russians</a> (17.3%), <a href="/wiki/Belarusians" title="Belarusians">Belarusians</a> (0.6%), <a href="/wiki/Moldovans" title="Moldovans">Moldovans</a> (0.5%), <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Tatars" title="Crimean Tatars">Crimean Tatars</a> (0.5%), <a href="/wiki/Bulgarians" title="Bulgarians">Bulgarians</a> (0.4%), <a href="/wiki/Hungarians" title="Hungarians">Hungarians</a> (0.3%), <a href="/wiki/Romanians" title="Romanians">Romanians</a> (0.3%), <a href="/wiki/Poles" title="Poles">Poles</a> (0.3%), <a href="/wiki/Jews" title="Jews">Jews</a> (0.3%), <a href="/wiki/Armenians" title="Armenians">Armenians</a> (0.2%), <a href="/wiki/Greeks" title="Greeks">Greeks</a> (0.2%) and <a href="/wiki/Tatars" title="Tatars">Tatars</a> (0.2%).<sup id="cite_ref-Ethnic_composition_of_the_population_of_Ukraine,_2001_Census_3-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ethnic_composition_of_the_population_of_Ukraine,_2001_Census-3">[3]</a></sup> It is also estimated that there are about 50,000 ethnic <a href="/wiki/Koreans" title="Koreans">Koreans</a> (0.12%) in Ukraine that belong to the <a href="/wiki/Koryo-saram" title="Koryo-saram">Koryo-saram</a> group. Their number may be as high as 100,000, as many ethnic Koreans were assimilated into the majority population.<sup id="cite_ref-338" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-338">[334]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339">[335]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Language">Language</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">Ukrainian language</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_language_in_Ukraine" title="Russian language in Ukraine">Russian language in Ukraine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Ukraine" title="Languages of Ukraine">Languages of Ukraine</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Ukraine" title="Name of Ukraine">Name of Ukraine</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ukraine_census_2001_Russian.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Ukraine_census_2001_Russian.svg/220px-Ukraine_census_2001_Russian.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="169" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Ukraine_census_2001_Russian.svg/330px-Ukraine_census_2001_Russian.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Ukraine_census_2001_Russian.svg/440px-Ukraine_census_2001_Russian.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="621" data-file-height="477"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ukraine_census_2001_Russian.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Percentage of native Russian speakers by subdivision according to the 2001 census (by oblast)<sup class="reference" id="ref_F3"><a href="#endnote_F3">[f]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>According to the constitution, the <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">state language</a> of Ukraine is Ukrainian.<sup id="cite_ref-SerhyYUBoaMN_340-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SerhyYUBoaMN-340">[336]</a></sup> Russian is widely spoken, especially in eastern and southern Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-SerhyYUBoaMN_340-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SerhyYUBoaMN-340">[336]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Census_(2001)" title="Ukrainian Census (2001)">2001 census</a>, 67.5&nbsp;percent of the population declared Ukrainian as their native language and 29.6&nbsp;percent declared Russian.<sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341">[337]</a></sup> Most native Ukrainian speakers know Russian as a second language.<sup id="cite_ref-SerhyYUBoaMN_340-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SerhyYUBoaMN-340">[336]</a></sup> Russian was the <i>de facto</i> dominant language of the Soviet Union but Ukrainian also held official status<sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342">[338]</a></sup> and in the schools of the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_SSR" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukrainian SSR">Ukrainian SSR</a> learning Ukrainian was mandatory.<sup id="cite_ref-SerhyYUBoaMN_340-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SerhyYUBoaMN-340">[336]</a></sup> Effective in August 2012, <a href="/wiki/Legislation_on_languages_in_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="Legislation on languages in Ukraine">a new law on regional languages</a> entitles any local language spoken by at least a 10&nbsp;percent minority be declared official within that area.<sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343">[339]</a></sup> Russian was within weeks declared as a regional language in several southern and eastern <a href="/wiki/Oblasts_of_Ukraine" title="Oblasts of Ukraine">oblasts</a> (provinces) and cities.<sup id="cite_ref-344" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-344">[340]</a></sup> Russian can now be used in these cities'/oblasts' administrative office work and documents.<sup id="cite_ref-NewUklang2892012_345-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NewUklang2892012-345">[341]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346">[342]</a></sup> On 23 February 2014, following the <a href="/wiki/2014_Ukrainian_revolution" class="mw-redirect" title="2014 Ukrainian revolution">2014 Ukrainian revolution</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Parliament" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukrainian Parliament">Ukrainian Parliament</a> voted to repeal the law on regional languages, making Ukrainian the sole state language at all levels; however, the repeal was not signed by acting <a href="/wiki/Oleksandr_Turchynov" title="Oleksandr Turchynov">President Turchynov</a> or by President Poroshenko.<sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347">[343]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348">[344]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349">[345]</a></sup> In February 2019, the law allowing for regional languages was found unconstitutional.<sup id="cite_ref-350" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-350">[346]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Ukrainian is mainly spoken in western and central Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-SerhyYUBoaMN_340-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SerhyYUBoaMN-340">[336]</a></sup> In western Ukraine, Ukrainian is also the dominant language in cities (such as <a href="/wiki/Lviv" title="Lviv">Lviv</a>). In central Ukraine, Ukrainian and Russian are both equally used in cities, with Russian being more common in <a href="/wiki/Kyiv" title="Kyiv">Kyiv</a>,<sup class="reference" id="ref_F2"><a href="#endnote_F2">[f]</a></sup> while Ukrainian is the dominant language in rural communities. In eastern and southern Ukraine, Russian is primarily used in cities, and Ukrainian is used in rural areas. These details result in a significant difference across different survey results, as even a small restating of a question switches responses of a significant group of people.<sup class="reference" id="ref_F1"><a href="#endnote_F1">[f]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_language" title="Hungarian language">Hungarian</a> is spoken in the <a href="/wiki/Zakarpattia_Oblast" title="Zakarpattia Oblast">Zakarpattia Oblast</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-351" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-351">[347]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>For a large part of the Soviet era, the number of Ukrainian speakers declined from generation to generation, and by the mid-1980s, the usage of the Ukrainian language in public life had decreased significantly.<sup id="cite_ref-Shamshur_352-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Shamshur-352">[348]</a></sup> Following independence, the government of Ukraine began restoring the image and usage of Ukrainian language through a policy of <a href="/wiki/Ukrainisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukrainisation">Ukrainisation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-353" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-353">[349]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354">[350]</a></sup> Today, most foreign films and TV programs, including Russian ones, are subtitled or dubbed in Ukrainian.<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355">[351]</a></sup> Ukraine's 2017 <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Ukraine" title="Education in Ukraine">education law</a> bars primary education in public schools in grade five and up in any language but Ukrainian.<sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356">[352]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-357" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-357">[353]</a></sup> The <i><a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Independent_Information_Agency" title="Ukrainian Independent Information Agency">Unian</a></i> reported that "A ban on the use of cultural products, namely movies, books, songs, etc., in the Russian language in the public has been introduced" in the <a href="/wiki/Lviv_Oblast" title="Lviv Oblast">Lviv Oblast</a> in September 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-358" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-358">[354]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to the Constitution of the <a href="/wiki/Crimea" title="Crimea">Autonomous Republic of Crimea</a>, Ukrainian is the only state language of the republic. However, the republic's constitution specifically recognises Russian as the language of the majority of its population and guarantees its usage 'in all spheres of public life'. Similarly, the <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Tatar_language" title="Crimean Tatar language">Crimean Tatar language</a> (the language of 12&nbsp;percent of population of Crimea)<sup id="cite_ref-Census2001CrimeaNationality_359-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Census2001CrimeaNationality-359">[355]</a></sup> is guaranteed a special state protection as well as the 'languages of other ethnicities'. Russian speakers constitute an overwhelming majority of the Crimean population (77&nbsp;percent), with Crimean Tatar speakers 11.4&nbsp;percent and Ukrainian speakers comprising just 10.1&nbsp;percent.<sup id="cite_ref-Census2001CrimeaLanguage_360-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Census2001CrimeaLanguage-360">[356]</a></sup> But in everyday life the majority of Crimean Tatars and Ukrainians in Crimea use Russian.<sup id="cite_ref-Belitser_361-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Belitser-361">[357]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Ukraine" title="Religion in Ukraine">Religion in Ukraine</a>
      </div>
