      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Kij%C3%B3w_-_Sob%C3%B3r_M%C4%85dro%C5%9Bci_Bo%C5%BCej_01.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Kij%C3%B3w_-_Sob%C3%B3r_M%C4%85dro%C5%9Bci_Bo%C5%BCej_01.jpg/220px-Kij%C3%B3w_-_Sob%C3%B3r_M%C4%85dro%C5%9Bci_Bo%C5%BCej_01.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="166" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Kij%C3%B3w_-_Sob%C3%B3r_M%C4%85dro%C5%9Bci_Bo%C5%BCej_01.jpg/330px-Kij%C3%B3w_-_Sob%C3%B3r_M%C4%85dro%C5%9Bci_Bo%C5%BCej_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Kij%C3%B3w_-_Sob%C3%B3r_M%C4%85dro%C5%9Bci_Bo%C5%BCej_01.jpg/440px-Kij%C3%B3w_-_Sob%C3%B3r_M%C4%85dro%C5%9Bci_Bo%C5%BCej_01.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3498" data-file-height="2647"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kij%C3%B3w_-_Sob%C3%B3r_M%C4%85dro%C5%9Bci_Bo%C5%BCej_01.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Saint_Sophia%27s_Cathedral,_Kyiv" class="mw-redirect" title="Saint Sophia's Cathedral, Kyiv">Saint Sophia Cathedral in Kyiv</a>, a <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362">[358]</a></sup> is one of the main Christian cathedrals in Ukraine
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:St._Nicholas_Roman_Catholic_Cathedral,_Kyiv_3.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/St._Nicholas_Roman_Catholic_Cathedral%2C_Kyiv_3.jpg/220px-St._Nicholas_Roman_Catholic_Cathedral%2C_Kyiv_3.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/St._Nicholas_Roman_Catholic_Cathedral%2C_Kyiv_3.jpg/330px-St._Nicholas_Roman_Catholic_Cathedral%2C_Kyiv_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/St._Nicholas_Roman_Catholic_Cathedral%2C_Kyiv_3.jpg/440px-St._Nicholas_Roman_Catholic_Cathedral%2C_Kyiv_3.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="2003"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:St._Nicholas_Roman_Catholic_Cathedral,_Kyiv_3.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/St._Nicholas_Roman_Catholic_Cathedral,_Kyiv" title="St. Nicholas Roman Catholic Cathedral, Kyiv">St. Nicholas Roman Catholic Cathedral</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Ukraine has the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodoxy_by_country" title="Eastern Orthodoxy by country">world's second largest Eastern Orthodox population</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-363" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-363">[359]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-364" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-364">[360]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>A 2016 survey conducted by the <a href="/wiki/Razumkov_Centre" title="Razumkov Centre">Razumkov Centre</a> found that 70% of Ukrainians declared themselves believers in some religion, while 10.1% were uncertain whether they believed or not, 7.2% were uninterested in beliefs, 6.3% were unbelievers, 2.7% were <a href="/wiki/Atheists" class="mw-redirect" title="Atheists">atheists</a>, and a further 3.9% found it difficult to answer the question.<sup id="cite_ref-Razumkov2016Page27_365-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Razumkov2016Page27-365">[361]</a></sup> The level of religiosity in Ukraine is greatest in <a href="/wiki/Western_Ukraine" title="Western Ukraine">Western Ukraine</a> (91%), and lowest in <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Ukraine" title="Eastern Ukraine">Eastern Ukraine</a> (56%) and the <a href="/wiki/Donbass" title="Donbass">Donbass</a> (57%).<sup id="cite_ref-Razumkov2016Page27_365-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Razumkov2016Page27-365">[361]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Of the Ukrainian population, 81.9% were Christians, comprising a 65.4% who declared to be <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Orthodox</a>, 7.1% simply <a href="/wiki/Christians" title="Christians">Christians</a>, 6.5% <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Greek_Catholic_Church" title="Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church">Greek Rite Catholics</a>, and 1.9% <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestants</a>. A further 1.1% were <a href="/wiki/Muslim" class="mw-redirect" title="Muslim">Muslims</a> and 1.0% <a href="/wiki/Latin_Church" title="Latin Church">Latin Rite Catholics</a>. <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Judaism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a> were the religions of 0.2% of the population each. A further 16.3% of the population did not identify in one of those listed hitherto.<sup id="cite_ref-Razumkov2016Page29_366-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Razumkov2016Page29-366">[362]</a></sup> According to the surveys conducted by Razumkov in the 2000s and early 2010s, such numbers have remained relatively constant throughout the last decade.<sup id="cite_ref-Razumkov2016Page29_366-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Razumkov2016Page29-366">[362]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Among those Ukrainians who declared to believe in Orthodoxy, 38.1% declared to be members of the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Orthodox_Church_%E2%80%93_Kyiv_Patriarchate" title="Ukrainian Orthodox Church – Kyiv Patriarchate">Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the Kyivan Patriarchate</a> (a body that is not canonically recognized by the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox Church</a>), while 23.0% declared to be members of the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Orthodox_Church_(Moscow_Patriarchate)" title="Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)">Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the Moscovian Patriarchate</a> (which is an <a href="/wiki/Autonomy_(Eastern_Christianity)" class="mw-redirect" title="Autonomy (Eastern Christianity)">autonomous</a> Orthodox church under the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Orthodox_Church" title="Russian Orthodox Church">Russian Orthodox Church</a>). A further 2.7% were members of the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Autocephalous_Orthodox_Church" title="Ukrainian Autocephalous Orthodox Church">Ukrainian Autocephalous Orthodox Church</a>, which, like the Kyivan Patriarchate, is not recognized by the Eastern Orthodox Church.<sup id="cite_ref-derzhkomrelig_367-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-derzhkomrelig-367">[363]</a></sup> Among the remaining Orthodox Ukrainians, 32.3% declared to be "simply Orthodox", without affiliation to any patriarchate, while a further 3.1% declared that they "did not know" which patriarchate or Orthodox church they belonged to.<sup id="cite_ref-Razumkov2016Page31_368-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Razumkov2016Page31-368">[364]</a></sup> On 15 December 2018 the Ukrainian Orthodox Church – Kyiv Patriarchate (UOC-KP) and the Ukrainian Autocephalous Orthodox Church (UAOC), and some members of the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Orthodox_Church_(Moscow_Patriarchate)" title="Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)">Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)</a> (UOC-MP) united to form the Orthodox Church of Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-369" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-369">[365]</a></sup> The Ecumenical Patriarch granted the status of autocephaly to the new Church the following month on 5 January 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-370" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-370">[366]</a></sup> The Patriarch of Moscow retaliated by severing relations with Constantinople. The union of the Ukrainian Churches has not been recognized by other Orthodox Churches. </p>
      <p>The second largest Christian group in Ukraine, <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholicism</a>, is predominantly represented by the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Greek_Catholic_Church" title="Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church">Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church</a>, an <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Catholic" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Catholic">Eastern Catholic</a> Church in <a href="/wiki/Full_communion" title="Full communion">communion</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Holy See</a> of the Roman Catholic Church. It recognizes the primacy of the <a href="/wiki/Pope" title="Pope">Pope</a> as head of the Church while still maintaining a similar <a href="/wiki/Liturgy" title="Liturgy">liturgical</a> and spiritual tradition as Eastern Orthodoxy.<sup id="cite_ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371">[367]</a></sup> Additionally, there are a small number of <a href="/wiki/Latin_Rite" class="mw-redirect" title="Latin Rite">Latin Rite</a> Catholic communities (1.0%).<sup id="cite_ref-Razumkov2016Page29_366-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Razumkov2016Page29-366">[362]</a></sup> The church consists mainly of ethnic <a href="/wiki/Poles" title="Poles">Poles</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hungarians" title="Hungarians">Hungarians</a>, who live predominantly in the western regions of the country.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> According to the 2018 survey, 'Religion in Ukraine,' by Razumkov the declared religion population is 9.4% <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Greek_Catholic_Church" title="Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church">Ukrainian Byzantine Rite Catholics</a> and 0.8% <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Latin Rite Catholics</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Razumkov2016Page29_366-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Razumkov2016Page29-366">[362]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Protestants_in_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="Protestants in Ukraine">Protestants in Ukraine</a> make up 1.9% of the population as of 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-Razumkov2016Page29_366-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Razumkov2016Page29-366">[362]</a></sup> Protestants had increased to 2.2% in the 2018 Razumkov Center survey. A further 7.1% of the population declares to be simply Christian.<sup id="cite_ref-Razumkov2016Page29_366-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Razumkov2016Page29-366">[362]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Razumov Center surveys reported an increase of those who declared themselves Orthodox in 2018 at 67.3% up 1.9% from 2016 while declared Catholics rose from 7.5% to 10.6% in the same two-year period. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Health_in_Ukraine" title="Health in Ukraine">Health in Ukraine</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Red_Cross_Society" title="Ukrainian Red Cross Society">Ukrainian Red Cross Society</a> was established in April 1918 in <a href="/wiki/Kyiv" title="Kyiv">Kyiv</a> as an independent humanitarian society of the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_People%27s_Republic" title="Ukrainian People's Republic">Ukrainian People's Republic</a>. Its immediate tasks were to help refugees and prisoners of war, care for handicapped people and orphaned children, fight famine and epidemics, support and organize sick quarters, hospitals and public canteens. At present, society involves more than 6.3 million supporters and activists. Its Visiting Nurses Service has 3,200 qualified nurses. The organization takes part in more than 40 humanitarian programmes all over Ukraine, which are mostly funded by public donation and corporate partnerships. By its own estimates, the Society annually provides services to more than 105,000 lonely, elderly people, about 23,000 people disabled during the Second World War and handicapped workers, more than 25,000 war veterans, and more than 8,000 adults handicapped since childhood. Assistance for orphaned and disabled children is also rendered. </p>
      <p>Ukraine's healthcare system is state subsidised and freely available to all Ukrainian citizens and registered residents. However, it is not compulsory to be treated in a state-run hospital as a number of private medical complexes do exist nationwide.<sup id="cite_ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372">[368]</a></sup> The public sector employs most healthcare professionals, with those working for private medical centres typically also retaining their state employment as they are mandated to provide care at public health facilities on a regular basis. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:%D0%9C%D1%96%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D0%B4%D0%B8%D1%82%D1%8F%D1%87%D0%B0_%D0%BB%D1%96%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BD%D1%8F_(%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%87%D1%83%D0%BA)_-_04.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/%D0%9C%D1%96%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D0%B4%D0%B8%D1%82%D1%8F%D1%87%D0%B0_%D0%BB%D1%96%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BD%D1%8F_%28%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%87%D1%83%D0%BA%29_-_04.JPG/200px-%D0%9C%D1%96%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D0%B4%D0%B8%D1%82%D1%8F%D1%87%D0%B0_%D0%BB%D1%96%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BD%D1%8F_%28%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%87%D1%83%D0%BA%29_-_04.JPG" decoding="async" width="200" height="150" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/%D0%9C%D1%96%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D0%B4%D0%B8%D1%82%D1%8F%D1%87%D0%B0_%D0%BB%D1%96%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BD%D1%8F_%28%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%87%D1%83%D0%BA%29_-_04.JPG/300px-%D0%9C%D1%96%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D0%B4%D0%B8%D1%82%D1%8F%D1%87%D0%B0_%D0%BB%D1%96%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BD%D1%8F_%28%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%87%D1%83%D0%BA%29_-_04.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/%D0%9C%D1%96%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D0%B4%D0%B8%D1%82%D1%8F%D1%87%D0%B0_%D0%BB%D1%96%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BD%D1%8F_%28%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%87%D1%83%D0%BA%29_-_04.JPG/400px-%D0%9C%D1%96%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D0%B4%D0%B8%D1%82%D1%8F%D1%87%D0%B0_%D0%BB%D1%96%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BD%D1%8F_%28%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%87%D1%83%D0%BA%29_-_04.JPG 2x" data-file-width="4320" data-file-height="3240"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:%D0%9C%D1%96%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D0%B4%D0%B8%D1%82%D1%8F%D1%87%D0%B0_%D0%BB%D1%96%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BD%D1%8F_(%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%87%D1%83%D0%BA)_-_04.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The municipal children's hospital in <a href="/wiki/Kremenchuk" title="Kremenchuk">Kremenchuk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Poltava_Oblast" title="Poltava Oblast">Poltava Oblast</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>All of the country's medical service providers and hospitals are subordinate to the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Healthcare_(Ukraine)" title="Ministry of Healthcare (Ukraine)">Ministry of Healthcare</a>, which provides oversight and scrutiny of general medical practice as well as being responsible for the day-to-day administration of the healthcare system. Despite this, standards of hygiene and patient-care have fallen.<sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373">[369]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Hospitals in Ukraine are organised along the same lines as most European nations, according to the regional administrative structure; as a result most towns have their own hospital <i>(Міська Лікарня)</i> and many also have district hospitals <i>(Районна Лікарня)</i>. Larger and more specialised medical complexes tend only to be found in major cities, with some even more specialised units located only in the capital, <a href="/wiki/Kyiv" title="Kyiv">Kyiv</a>. However, all <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Ukraine" title="Administrative divisions of Ukraine">oblasts</a> have their own network of general hospitals which are able to deal with almost all medical problems and are typically equipped with major trauma centres; such hospitals are called 'regional hospitals' <i>(Обласна Лікарня)</i>. </p>
      <p>Ukraine currently faces a number of major public health issues and is considered to be in a demographic crisis because of its high death rate and low birth rate (the current Ukrainian birth rate is 11 births/1,000 population, and the death rate is 16.3 deaths/1,000 population). A factor contributing to the high death rate is a high <a href="/wiki/Mortality_rate" title="Mortality rate">mortality rate</a> among working-age males from preventable causes such as <a href="/wiki/Alcohol_poisoning" class="mw-redirect" title="Alcohol poisoning">alcohol poisoning</a> and smoking.<sup id="cite_ref-worldbank1_374-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-worldbank1-374">[370]</a></sup> In 2008, the country's population was one of the fastest declining in the world at −5% growth.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2002_375-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2002-375">[371]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376">[372]</a></sup> The UN warned that Ukraine's population could fall by as much as 10 million by 2050 if trends did not improve.<sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377">[373]</a></sup> In addition, obesity, systemic high blood pressure and the HIV endemic are all major challenges facing the Ukrainian healthcare system. </p>
      <p>As of March 2009 the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_government" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukrainian government">Ukrainian government</a> is reforming the health care system, by the creation of a national network of <a href="/wiki/Family_doctor" class="mw-redirect" title="Family doctor">family doctors</a> and improvements in the <a href="/wiki/Emergency_medical_services" title="Emergency medical services">medical emergency services</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-378" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-378">[374]</a></sup> In November 2009, former <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Prime_Minister" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukrainian Prime Minister">Prime Minister</a> <a href="/wiki/Yulia_Tymoshenko" title="Yulia Tymoshenko">Yulia Tymoshenko</a> proposed introducing a public healthcare system based on health insurance in the spring of 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379">[375]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Active reformation of Ukraine's healthcare system was initiated right after the appointment of <a href="/wiki/Ulana_Suprun" title="Ulana Suprun">Ulana Suprun</a> as a head of the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Healthcare_(Ukraine)" title="Ministry of Healthcare (Ukraine)">Ministry of Healthcare</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Rada_Reform_380-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rada_Reform-380">[376]</a></sup> Assisted by deputy Pavlo Kovtoniuk, Suprun first changed the distribution of finances in healthcare.<sup id="cite_ref-Kovtoniuk_381-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kovtoniuk-381">[377]</a></sup> Funds must follow the patient. General practitioners will provide basic care for patients. The patient will have the right to choose one. Emergency medical service is considered to be fully funded by the state. <a href="/wiki/Emergency_Medicine_Reform_in_Ukraine_since_2016" class="mw-redirect" title="Emergency Medicine Reform in Ukraine since 2016">Emergency Medicine Reform</a> is also an important part of the healthcare reform. In addition, patients who suffer from chronic diseases, which cause a high toll of disability and mortality, are provided with free or low price medicine.<sup id="cite_ref-Drugs_382-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Drugs-382">[378]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Ukraine" title="Education in Ukraine">Education in Ukraine</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_in_Ukraine" title="List of universities in Ukraine">List of universities in Ukraine</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Universidad_Roja_de_Kiev.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Universidad_Roja_de_Kiev.jpg/200px-Universidad_Roja_de_Kiev.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="133" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Universidad_Roja_de_Kiev.jpg/300px-Universidad_Roja_de_Kiev.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Universidad_Roja_de_Kiev.jpg/400px-Universidad_Roja_de_Kiev.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3888" data-file-height="2592"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The <a href="/wiki/Taras_Shevchenko_National_University_of_Kyiv" title="Taras Shevchenko National University of Kyiv">University of Kyiv</a> is one of Ukraine's most important educational institutions.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Chernivtsi_University.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Chernivtsi_University.jpg/200px-Chernivtsi_University.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="68" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Chernivtsi_University.jpg/300px-Chernivtsi_University.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Chernivtsi_University.jpg/400px-Chernivtsi_University.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2147" data-file-height="731"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The <a href="/wiki/Residence_of_Bukovinian_and_Dalmatian_Metropolitans" title="Residence of Bukovinian and Dalmatian Metropolitans">Residence of Bukovinian and Dalmatian Metropolitans</a> by <a href="/wiki/Josef_Hl%C3%A1vka" title="Josef Hlávka">Josef Hlávka</a>, 1882, now <a href="/wiki/Chernivtsi_University" title="Chernivtsi University">Chernivtsi University</a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Ukraine" title="Constitution of Ukraine">Ukrainian constitution</a>, access to free education is granted to all citizens. Complete general secondary education is compulsory in the state schools which constitute the overwhelming majority. Free higher education in state and communal educational establishments is provided on a competitive basis.<sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383">[379]</a></sup> There is also a small number of accredited private secondary and higher education institutions. </p>
      <p>Because of the Soviet Union's emphasis on total access of education for all citizens, which continues today, the <a href="/wiki/Literacy_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="Literacy rate">literacy rate</a> is an estimated 99.4%.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_41-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-41">[38]</a></sup> Since 2005, an eleven-year school programme has been replaced with a twelve-year one: primary education takes four years to complete (starting at age six), middle education (secondary) takes five years to complete; upper secondary then takes three years.<sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384">[380]</a></sup> In the 12th grade, students take Government tests, which are also referred to as school-leaving exams. These tests are later used for university admissions. </p>
      <p>The first higher education institutions (HEIs) emerged in Ukraine during the late 16th and early 17th centuries. The first Ukrainian higher education institution was the <a href="/wiki/Ostroh_Academy" title="Ostroh Academy">Ostrozka School</a>, or Ostrozkiy Greek-Slavic-Latin Collegium, similar to Western European higher education institutions of the time. Established in 1576 in the town of <a href="/wiki/Ostroh" title="Ostroh">Ostrog</a>, the Collegium was the first higher education institution in the <a href="/wiki/East_Slavic_peoples" class="mw-redirect" title="East Slavic peoples">Eastern Slavic</a> territories. The oldest university was the <a href="/wiki/National_University_of_Kyiv-Mohyla_Academy" title="National University of Kyiv-Mohyla Academy">Kyiv Mohyla Academy</a>, first established in 1632 and in 1694 officially recognised by the government of <a href="/wiki/Imperial_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Imperial Russia">Imperial Russia</a> as a higher education institution. Among the oldest is also the <a href="/wiki/Lviv_University" class="mw-redirect" title="Lviv University">Lviv University</a>, founded in 1661. More higher education institutions were set up in the 19th century, beginning with universities in <a href="/wiki/Kharkiv_University" class="mw-redirect" title="Kharkiv University">Kharkiv</a> (1805), <a href="/wiki/Taras_Shevchenko_National_University_of_Kyiv" title="Taras Shevchenko National University of Kyiv">Kyiv</a> (1834), <a href="/wiki/Odessa_University" title="Odessa University">Odessa</a> (1865) and <a href="/wiki/Chernivtsi_University" title="Chernivtsi University">Chernivtsi</a> (1875) and a number of professional higher education institutions, e.g.: <a href="/wiki/Nizhyn_Pedagogical_University" class="mw-redirect" title="Nizhyn Pedagogical University">Nizhyn Historical and Philological Institute</a> (originally established as the Gymnasium of Higher Sciences in 1805), a Veterinary Institute (1873) and a <a href="/wiki/Kharkiv_Polytechnical_Institute" class="mw-redirect" title="Kharkiv Polytechnical Institute">Technological Institute</a> (1885) in <a href="/wiki/Kharkiv" title="Kharkiv">Kharkiv</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Igor_Sikorsky_Kyiv_Polytechnic_Institute" title="Igor Sikorsky Kyiv Polytechnic Institute">Polytechnic Institute</a> in <a href="/wiki/Kyiv" title="Kyiv">Kyiv</a> (1898) and a Higher Mining School (1899) in <a href="/wiki/Dnipro" title="Dnipro">Katerynoslav</a>. Rapid growth followed in the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic">Soviet</a> period. By 1988 a number of higher education institutions increased to 146 with over 850,000 students.<sup id="cite_ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385">[381]</a></sup> Most HEIs established after 1990 are those owned by private organisations. </p>
      <p>The Ukrainian higher education system comprises higher educational establishments, <a href="/wiki/Scientific" class="mw-redirect" title="Scientific">scientific</a> and <a href="/wiki/Methodological" class="mw-redirect" title="Methodological">methodological</a> facilities under national, <a href="/wiki/Municipal_government" class="mw-redirect" title="Municipal government">municipal</a> and self-governing bodies in charge of education.<sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386">[382]</a></sup> The organisation of higher education in Ukraine is built up in accordance with the structure of education of the world's higher <a href="/wiki/Developed_countries" class="mw-redirect" title="Developed countries">developed countries</a>, as is defined by <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> and the UN.<sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387">[383]</a></sup> Ukraine has more than 800 higher education institutions and in 2010 the number of graduates reached 654,700 people.<sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388">[384]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Ukraine produces the fourth largest number of <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_education" title="Tertiary education">post-secondary graduates</a> in Europe, while being ranked seventh in population. <a href="/wiki/Higher_education_in_Ukraine" title="Higher education in Ukraine">Higher education</a> is either state funded or private. Students that study at state expense receive a standard scholarship if their average marks at the end-of-term exams and differentiated test suffice; this rule may be different in some universities. For highest grades, the scholarship is increased by 25%. For most students the government subsidy is not sufficient to cover their basic living expenses. Most universities provide subsidised housing for out-of-city students. Also, it is common for libraries to supply required books for all registered students. Ukrainian universities confer two degrees: the bachelor's degree (4&nbsp;years) and the master's degree (5–6th&nbsp;year), in accordance with the <a href="/wiki/Bologna_process" class="mw-redirect" title="Bologna process">Bologna process</a>. Historically, <a href="/wiki/Specialist_degree" title="Specialist degree">Specialist degree</a> (usually 5 years) is still also granted; it was the only degree awarded by universities in the Soviet times. </p>
      <p>The Law of Ukraine <i>On Higher Education</i> came into force on 6 September 2014. It was approved in Ukrainian Parliament on 1 July 2014. The main changes in the system of higher education:<sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389">[385]</a></sup> a separate collegiate body to monitor the quality of education was established (Ukrainian: Національне агентство із забезпечення якості вищої освіти); each higher education institution has the right to implement its own educational and research programs; role of the student government was increased; higher education institution has the right to freely administer own revenues; 5 following types of higher education qualifications were established: Junior Bachelor, Bachelor, Master, Doctor of Philosophy (PhD) and Doctor of Science; load on lecturers and students was reduced; academic mobility for faculty and students etc. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Regional_differences">Regional differences</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Ukraine#Regional_differences" title="Demographics of Ukraine">Demographics of Ukraine §&nbsp;Regional differences</a>, <a href="/wiki/Central_Ukraine" title="Central Ukraine">Central Ukraine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Ukraine" title="Eastern Ukraine">Eastern Ukraine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Southern_Ukraine" title="Southern Ukraine">Southern Ukraine</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Western_Ukraine" title="Western Ukraine">Western Ukraine</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ukr_elections_2012_multimandate_okruhs.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Ukr_elections_2012_multimandate_okruhs.png/220px-Ukr_elections_2012_multimandate_okruhs.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="156" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Ukr_elections_2012_multimandate_okruhs.png/330px-Ukr_elections_2012_multimandate_okruhs.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Ukr_elections_2012_multimandate_okruhs.png/440px-Ukr_elections_2012_multimandate_okruhs.png 2x" data-file-width="3508" data-file-height="2480"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ukr_elections_2012_multimandate_okruhs.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Results of the <a href="/wiki/2012_Ukrainian_parliamentary_election" title="2012 Ukrainian parliamentary election">2012 parliamentary election</a> with Yanukovych's <a href="/wiki/Party_of_Regions" title="Party of Regions">Party of Regions</a> in blue and <a href="/wiki/All-Ukrainian_Union_%22Fatherland%22" title="All-Ukrainian Union &quot;Fatherland&quot;">Batkivshchyna</a> in purple
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">Ukrainian</a> is the dominant language in <a href="/wiki/Western_Ukraine" title="Western Ukraine">Western Ukraine</a> and in <a href="/wiki/Central_Ukraine" title="Central Ukraine">Central Ukraine</a>, while <a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian</a> is the dominant language in the cities of <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Ukraine" title="Eastern Ukraine">Eastern Ukraine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Southern_Ukraine" title="Southern Ukraine">Southern Ukraine</a>. In the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_SSR" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukrainian SSR">Ukrainian SSR</a> schools, learning <a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian</a> was mandatory; currently in modern Ukraine, schools with Ukrainian as the language of instruction offer classes in Russian and in the other minority languages.<sup id="cite_ref-SerhyYUBoaMN_340-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SerhyYUBoaMN-340">[336]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-390" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-390">[386]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-RatingJuly12_391-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RatingJuly12-391">[387]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392">[388]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On the <a href="/wiki/Russian_language_in_Ukraine" title="Russian language in Ukraine">Russian language</a>, on <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_nationalism" title="Ukrainian nationalism">Ukrainian nationalism</a>, opinion in Eastern Ukraine and Southern Ukraine tends to be the exact opposite of those in Western Ukraine; while opinions in Central Ukraine on these topics tend be less extreme.<sup id="cite_ref-RatingJuly12_391-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RatingJuly12-391">[387]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393">[389]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394">[390]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-KIISS1313_395-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KIISS1313-395">[391]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Similar historical cleavages also remain evident at the level of individual social identification. Attitudes toward the most important political issue, relations with <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>, differed strongly between <a href="/wiki/Lviv" title="Lviv">Lviv</a>, identifying more with <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_nationalism" title="Ukrainian nationalism">Ukrainian nationalism</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Greek_Catholic_Church" title="Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church">Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Donetsk" title="Donetsk">Donetsk</a>, predominantly Russian orientated and favourable to the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_era" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet era">Soviet era</a>, while in central and southern Ukraine, as well as <a href="/wiki/Kyiv" title="Kyiv">Kyiv</a>, such divisions were less important and there was less antipathy toward people from other regions (a poll by the <a href="/wiki/Research_%26_Branding_Group" title="Research &amp; Branding Group">Research &amp; Branding Group</a> held March 2010 showed that the attitude of the citizens of Donetsk to the citizens of Lviv was 79% positive and that the attitude of the citizens of Lviv to the citizens of Donetsk was 88% positive).<sup id="cite_ref-antipathy_396-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-antipathy-396">[392]</a></sup> However, all were united by an overarching Ukrainian identity based on shared economic difficulties, showing that other attitudes are determined more by culture and politics than by demographic differences.<sup id="cite_ref-antipathy_396-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-antipathy-396">[392]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-397" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-397">[393]</a></sup> Surveys of regional identities in Ukraine have shown that the feeling of belonging to a "Soviet identity" is strongest in the <a href="/wiki/Donbas" class="mw-redirect" title="Donbas">Donbas</a> (about 40%) and the Crimea (about 30%).<sup id="cite_ref-398" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-398">[394]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>During <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_Ukraine" title="Elections in Ukraine">elections</a> voters of Western and Central Ukrainian <a href="/wiki/Oblasts_of_Ukraine" title="Oblasts of Ukraine">oblasts</a> (provinces) vote mostly for parties (<a href="/wiki/Our_Ukraine%E2%80%93People%27s_Self-Defense_Bloc" title="Our Ukraine–People's Self-Defense Bloc">Our Ukraine</a>, <a href="/wiki/All-Ukrainian_Union_%22Fatherland%22" title="All-Ukrainian Union &quot;Fatherland&quot;">Batkivshchyna</a>)<sup id="cite_ref-399" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-399">[395]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-400" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-400">[396]</a></sup> and presidential candidates (<a href="/wiki/Viktor_Yuschenko" class="mw-redirect" title="Viktor Yuschenko">Viktor Yuschenko</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yulia_Tymoshenko" title="Yulia Tymoshenko">Yulia Tymoshenko</a>) with a <a href="/wiki/Pro-Western" class="mw-redirect" title="Pro-Western">pro-Western</a> and state reform <a href="/wiki/Political_platform" class="mw-redirect" title="Political platform">platform</a>, while voters in Southern and Eastern oblasts vote for parties (<a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Ukraine" title="Communist Party of Ukraine">CPU</a>, <a href="/wiki/Party_of_Regions" title="Party of Regions">Party of Regions</a>) and presidential candidates (<a href="/wiki/Viktor_Yanukovych" title="Viktor Yanukovych">Viktor Yanukovych</a>) with a <a href="/wiki/Pro-Russian" class="mw-redirect" title="Pro-Russian">pro-Russian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Status_quo" title="Status quo">status quo</a> platform.<sup id="cite_ref-EWparties_401-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EWparties-401">[397]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Umland_402-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Umland-402">[398]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-403" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-403">[399]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-404" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-404">[400]</a></sup> However, this geographical division is decreasing.<sup id="cite_ref-405" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-405">[401]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406">[402]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407">[403]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Urbanisation">Urbanisation</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Ukraine" title="List of cities in Ukraine">List of cities in Ukraine</a>
      </div> 
      <p>In total, Ukraine has 457 cities, 176 of them are labelled oblast-class, 279 smaller <i lang="uk-Latn" title="Ukrainian-language text">raion</i>-class cities, and two special legal status cities. These are followed by 886 urban-type settlements and 28,552 villages.<sup id="cite_ref-oblasts_408-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oblasts-408">[404]</a></sup> </p> 
      <table class="navbox"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <th colspan="10" class="navbox-title">
          <div style="float:right; width:6em; height:2.6em">
           &nbsp;
          </div><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r992953826">.mw-parser-output .navbar{display:inline;font-size:88%;font-weight:normal}.mw-parser-output .navbar-collapse{float:left;text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .navbar-boxtext{word-spacing:0}.mw-parser-output .navbar ul{display:inline-block;white-space:nowrap;line-height:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::before{margin-right:-0.125em;content:"[ "}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::after{margin-left:-0.125em;content:" ]"}.mw-parser-output .navbar li{word-spacing:-0.125em}.mw-parser-output .navbar-mini abbr{font-variant:small-caps;border-bottom:none;text-decoration:none;cursor:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-full{font-size:114%;margin:0 7em}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-mini{font-size:114%;margin:0 4em}.mw-parser-output .infobox .navbar{font-size:100%}.mw-parser-output .navbox .navbar{display:block;font-size:100%}.mw-parser-output .navbox-title .navbar{float:left;text-align:left;margin-right:0.5em}</style>
