      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_culture" title="Ukrainian culture">Ukrainian culture</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Pysanky2011.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Pysanky2011.JPG/220px-Pysanky2011.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="151" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Pysanky2011.JPG/330px-Pysanky2011.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Pysanky2011.JPG/440px-Pysanky2011.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3250" data-file-height="2224"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Pysanky2011.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A collection of traditional Ukrainian Easter eggs – <a href="/wiki/Pysanka" title="Pysanka">pysanky</a>. The design motifs on pysanky date back to early Slavic cultures.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Rushnyk_-_Ukraine_embroidered_decorative_towels..jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Rushnyk_-_Ukraine_embroidered_decorative_towels..jpg/220px-Rushnyk_-_Ukraine_embroidered_decorative_towels..jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Rushnyk_-_Ukraine_embroidered_decorative_towels..jpg/330px-Rushnyk_-_Ukraine_embroidered_decorative_towels..jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Rushnyk_-_Ukraine_embroidered_decorative_towels..jpg/440px-Rushnyk_-_Ukraine_embroidered_decorative_towels..jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="600"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Rushnyk_-_Ukraine_embroidered_decorative_towels..jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Rushnyk" title="Rushnyk">Rushnyk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_embroidery" title="Ukrainian embroidery">Ukrainian embroidery</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Ukrainian customs are heavily influenced by <a href="/wiki/Orthodox_Christianity" class="mw-redirect" title="Orthodox Christianity">Orthodox Christianity</a>, the dominant religion in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-derzhkomrelig_367-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-derzhkomrelig-367">[363]</a></sup> Gender roles also tend to be more traditional, and grandparents play a greater role in bringing up children, than in the West.<sup id="cite_ref-409" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-409">[405]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> The culture of Ukraine has also been influenced by its eastern and western neighbours, reflected in its <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_architecture" title="Ukrainian architecture">architecture</a>, music and art.<sup id="cite_ref-410" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-410">[406]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>The Communist era had quite a strong effect on the art and writing of Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-411" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-411">[407]</a></sup> In 1932, Stalin made <a href="/wiki/Socialist_realism" title="Socialist realism">socialist realism</a> state policy in the Soviet Union when he promulgated the decree "On the Reconstruction of Literary and Art Organisations". This greatly stifled creativity. During the 1980s <a href="/wiki/Glasnost" title="Glasnost">glasnost</a> (openness) was introduced and Soviet artists and writers again became free to express themselves as they wanted.<sup id="cite_ref-412" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-412">[408]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The tradition of the <a href="/wiki/Easter_egg" title="Easter egg">Easter egg</a>, known as <a href="/wiki/Pysanky" class="mw-redirect" title="Pysanky">pysanky</a>, has long roots in Ukraine. These eggs were drawn on with wax to create a pattern; then, the dye was applied to give the eggs their pleasant colours, the dye did not affect the previously wax-coated parts of the egg. After the entire egg was dyed, the wax was removed leaving only the colourful pattern. This tradition is thousands of years old, and precedes the arrival of Christianity to Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413">[409]</a></sup> In the city of <a href="/wiki/Kolomyia" title="Kolomyia">Kolomyia</a> near the foothills of the <a href="/wiki/Carpathian_Mountains" title="Carpathian Mountains">Carpathian Mountains</a> in 2000 was built the museum of Pysanka which won a nomination as the monument of modern Ukraine in 2007, part of the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Wonders_of_Ukraine" title="Seven Wonders of Ukraine">Seven Wonders of Ukraine</a> action. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Weaving_and_embroidery">Weaving and embroidery</span></h3> 
      <p>Artisan <a href="/wiki/Textile_arts" title="Textile arts">textile arts</a> play an important role in Ukrainian culture,<sup id="cite_ref-414" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-414">[410]</a></sup> especially in <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_wedding_traditions" title="Ukrainian wedding traditions">Ukrainian wedding traditions</a>. <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_embroidery" title="Ukrainian embroidery">Ukrainian embroidery</a>, <a href="/wiki/Weaving" title="Weaving">weaving</a> and lace-making are used in traditional <a href="/wiki/Folk_dress" class="mw-redirect" title="Folk dress">folk dress</a> and in traditional celebrations. Ukrainian embroidery varies depending on the region of origin<sup id="cite_ref-415" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-415">[411]</a></sup> and the designs have a long history of motifs, compositions, choice of colours and types of stitches.<sup id="cite_ref-museum_416-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-museum-416">[412]</a></sup> Use of colour is very important and has roots in <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_folklore" title="Ukrainian folklore">Ukrainian folklore</a>. Embroidery motifs found in different parts of Ukraine are preserved in the <a href="/wiki/Rushnyk" title="Rushnyk">Rushnyk</a> Museum in <a href="/wiki/Pereiaslav" title="Pereiaslav">Pereiaslav</a>. </p>
      <p>National dress is woven and highly decorated. Weaving with handmade looms is still practised in the village of Krupove, situated in <a href="/wiki/Rivne_Oblast" title="Rivne Oblast">Rivne Oblast</a>. The village is the birthplace of two famous personalities in the scene of national crafts fabrication. Nina Myhailivna<sup id="cite_ref-417" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-417">[413]</a></sup> and Uliana Petrivna<sup id="cite_ref-418" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-418">[414]</a></sup> with international recognition. To preserve this traditional knowledge the village is planning to open a local weaving centre, a museum and weaving school. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_literature" title="Ukrainian literature">Ukrainian literature</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The history of Ukrainian literature dates back to the 11th&nbsp;century, following the Christianisation of Kyivan Rus'.<sup id="cite_ref-ualit_419-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ualit-419">[415]</a></sup> The writings of the time were mainly liturgical and were written in <a href="/wiki/Old_Church_Slavonic" title="Old Church Slavonic">Old Church Slavonic</a>. Historical accounts of the time were referred to as <i><a href="/wiki/Chronicle" title="Chronicle">chronicles</a></i>, the most significant of which was the <a href="/wiki/Primary_Chronicle" title="Primary Chronicle">Primary Chronicle</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ualitmsn_420-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ualitmsn-420">[416]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="ref_Gnone"><a href="#endnote_Gnone">[g]</a></sup> Literary activity faced a sudden decline during the <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasion_of_Rus%27" class="mw-redirect" title="Mongol invasion of Rus'">Mongol invasion of Rus'</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ualit_419-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ualit-419">[415]</a></sup> </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:149px;max-width:149px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:194px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Taras_Shevchenko_selfportrait_oil_1840-2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Taras_Shevchenko_selfportrait_oil_1840-2.jpg/147px-Taras_Shevchenko_selfportrait_oil_1840-2.jpg" decoding="async" width="147" height="194" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Taras_Shevchenko_selfportrait_oil_1840-2.jpg/221px-Taras_Shevchenko_selfportrait_oil_1840-2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Taras_Shevchenko_selfportrait_oil_1840-2.jpg/294px-Taras_Shevchenko_selfportrait_oil_1840-2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1517" data-file-height="2006"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Taras_Shevchenko" title="Taras Shevchenko">Taras Shevchenko</a>, self-portrait
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:139px;max-width:139px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:194px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:%D0%9B%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%8F_%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%B0.1888.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/%D0%9B%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%8F_%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%B0.1888.jpg/137px-%D0%9B%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%8F_%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%B0.1888.jpg" decoding="async" width="137" height="196" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/%D0%9B%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%8F_%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%B0.1888.jpg/206px-%D0%9B%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%8F_%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%B0.1888.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/%D0%9B%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%8F_%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%B0.1888.jpg/274px-%D0%9B%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%8F_%D0%A3%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%B0.1888.jpg 2x" data-file-width="560" data-file-height="800"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Lesya_Ukrainka" title="Lesya Ukrainka">Lesya Ukrainka</a>, one of the foremost Ukrainian women writers
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Ukrainian literature again began to develop in the 14th&nbsp;century, and was advanced significantly in the 16th&nbsp;century with the introduction of <a href="/wiki/Printing" title="Printing">print</a> and with the beginning of the Cossack era, under both Russian and Polish dominance.<sup id="cite_ref-ualit_419-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ualit-419">[415]</a></sup> The Cossacks established an independent society and popularized a <a href="/wiki/Duma_(epic)" title="Duma (epic)">new kind</a> of <a href="/wiki/Epic_poem" class="mw-redirect" title="Epic poem">epic poems</a>, which marked a high point of Ukrainian <a href="/wiki/Oral_literature" title="Oral literature">oral literature</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ualitmsn_420-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ualitmsn-420">[416]</a></sup> These advances were then set back in the 17th and early 18th&nbsp;centuries, when publishing in the Ukrainian language was outlawed and prohibited. Nonetheless, by the late 18th&nbsp;century modern literary Ukrainian finally emerged.<sup id="cite_ref-ualit_419-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ualit-419">[415]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The 19th&nbsp;century initiated a <a href="/wiki/Vernacular" title="Vernacular">vernacular</a> period in Ukraine, led by <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Kotliarevsky" title="Ivan Kotliarevsky">Ivan Kotliarevsky</a>'s work <i lang="uk-Latn" title="Ukrainian-language text">Eneyida</i>, the first publication written in modern Ukrainian. By the 1830s, Ukrainian <a href="/wiki/Romanticism" title="Romanticism">romanticism</a> began to develop, and the nation's most renowned cultural figure, romanticist poet-painter <a href="/wiki/Taras_Shevchenko" title="Taras Shevchenko">Taras Shevchenko</a> emerged. Where Ivan Kotliarevsky is considered to be the father of literature in the Ukrainian vernacular; Shevchenko is the father of a national revival.<sup id="cite_ref-421" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-421">[417]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Then, in 1863, use of the Ukrainian language in print was effectively <a href="/wiki/Ems_Ukaz" title="Ems Ukaz">prohibited</a> by the Russian Empire.<sup id="cite_ref-censor_68-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-censor-68">[65]</a></sup> This severely curtailed literary activity in the area, and Ukrainian writers were forced to either publish their works in Russian or release them in Austrian controlled <a href="/wiki/Galicia_(Central_Europe)" class="mw-redirect" title="Galicia (Central Europe)">Galicia</a>. The ban was never officially lifted, but it became obsolete after the revolution and the Bolsheviks' coming to power.<sup id="cite_ref-ualitmsn_420-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ualitmsn-420">[416]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Ukrainian literature continued to flourish in the early Soviet years, when nearly all literary trends were approved (the most important literary figures of that time were <a href="/wiki/Mykola_Khvylovy" title="Mykola Khvylovy">Mykola Khvylovy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Valerian_Pidmohylny" title="Valerian Pidmohylny">Valerian Pidmohylny</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mykola_Kulish" title="Mykola Kulish">Mykola Kulish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mykhayl_Semenko" class="mw-redirect" title="Mykhayl Semenko">Mykhayl Semenko</a> and some others). These policies faced a steep decline in the 1930s, when prominent representatives as well as many others were killed by <a href="/wiki/NKVD" title="NKVD">NKVD</a> as part of the <a href="/wiki/Great_Purge" title="Great Purge">Great Purge</a>. In general around 223 writers were repressed by what was known as the <a href="/wiki/Executed_Renaissance" title="Executed Renaissance">Executed Renaissance</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-422" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-422">[418]</a></sup> These repressions were part of Stalin's implemented policy of <a href="/wiki/Socialist_realism" title="Socialist realism">socialist realism</a>. The doctrine did not necessarily repress the use of the Ukrainian language, but it required that writers follow a certain style in their works. </p>
      <p>In post-Stalinist times literary activities continued to be somewhat limited under the Communist Party. The most famous figures of Ukrainian post-war Soviet literature were <a href="/wiki/Lina_Kostenko" title="Lina Kostenko">Lina Kostenko</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dmytro_Pavlychko" title="Dmytro Pavlychko">Dmytro Pavlychko</a>, <a href="/wiki/Borys_Oliynyk_(poet)" title="Borys Oliynyk (poet)">Borys Oliynyk (poet)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Drach" title="Ivan Drach">Ivan Drach</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oles_Honchar" title="Oles Honchar">Oles Honchar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vasyl_Stus" title="Vasyl Stus">Vasyl Stus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vasyl_Symonenko" title="Vasyl Symonenko">Vasyl Symonenko</a>. </p>
      <p>Literary freedom grew in the late 1980s and early 1990s alongside the decline and collapse of the USSR and the reestablishment of Ukrainian independence in 1991.<sup id="cite_ref-ualit_419-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ualit-419">[415]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_architecture" title="Ukrainian architecture">Ukrainian architecture</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:80-391-9007_Kyiv_St.Michael%27s_Golden-Domed_Monastery_RB_18.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/80-391-9007_Kyiv_St.Michael%27s_Golden-Domed_Monastery_RB_18.jpg/220px-80-391-9007_Kyiv_St.Michael%27s_Golden-Domed_Monastery_RB_18.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/80-391-9007_Kyiv_St.Michael%27s_Golden-Domed_Monastery_RB_18.jpg/330px-80-391-9007_Kyiv_St.Michael%27s_Golden-Domed_Monastery_RB_18.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/80-391-9007_Kyiv_St.Michael%27s_Golden-Domed_Monastery_RB_18.jpg/440px-80-391-9007_Kyiv_St.Michael%27s_Golden-Domed_Monastery_RB_18.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5400" data-file-height="3600"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:80-391-9007_Kyiv_St.Michael%27s_Golden-Domed_Monastery_RB_18.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/St._Michael%27s_Golden-Domed_Cathedral" class="mw-redirect" title="St. Michael's Golden-Domed Cathedral">St. Michael's Golden-Domed Cathedral</a> in <a href="/wiki/Kyiv" title="Kyiv">Kyiv</a>, foremost example of <a href="/wiki/Cossack_Baroque" class="mw-redirect" title="Cossack Baroque">Cossack Baroque</a> and one of Ukraine's most recognizable landmarks
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Ukrainian architecture includes the motifs and styles that are found in structures built in modern Ukraine, and by <a href="/wiki/Ukrainians" title="Ukrainians">Ukrainians</a> worldwide. These include initial roots which were established in the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Slavs" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Slavs">Eastern Slavic</a> state of <a href="/wiki/Kyivan_Rus%27" class="mw-redirect" title="Kyivan Rus'">Kyivan Rus'</a>. Since the <a href="/wiki/Christianization_of_Kyivan_Rus%27" class="mw-redirect" title="Christianization of Kyivan Rus'">Christianization of Kyivan Rus'</a> for several ages Ukrainian architecture was influenced by the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_architecture" title="Byzantine architecture">Byzantine architecture</a>. After the <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasion_of_Rus" class="mw-redirect" title="Mongol invasion of Rus">12th century</a>, the distinct <a href="/wiki/Architectural_history" class="mw-redirect" title="Architectural history">architectural history</a> continued in the principalities of <a href="/wiki/Galicia-Volhynia" class="mw-redirect" title="Galicia-Volhynia">Galicia-Volhynia</a>. During the epoch of the <a href="/wiki/Zaporozhian_Cossacks" title="Zaporozhian Cossacks">Zaporozhian Cossacks</a>, a new style unique to Ukraine was developed under the western influences of the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth">Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth</a>. After the union with the <a href="/wiki/Tsardom_of_Russia" title="Tsardom of Russia">Tsardom of Russia</a>, many structures in the larger eastern, Russian-ruled area were built in the styles of <a href="/wiki/Russian_architecture" title="Russian architecture">Russian architecture</a> of that period, whilst the western <a href="/wiki/Galicia_(Central_Europe)" class="mw-redirect" title="Galicia (Central Europe)">Galicia</a> was developed under <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Austria" class="mw-redirect" title="Architecture of Austria">Austro-Hungarian architectural influences</a>. Ukrainian national motifs would finally be used during the period of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> and in modern independent Ukraine. </p>
      <p>The great <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Kyivan_Rus" class="mw-redirect" title="Architecture of Kyivan Rus">churches of the Rus'</a>, built after the <a href="/wiki/Baptism_of_Kyivan_Rus%27" class="mw-redirect" title="Baptism of Kyivan Rus'">adoption of Christianity</a> in 988, were the first examples of monumental architecture in the East Slavic lands. The architectural style of the Kyivan state was strongly influenced by the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_architecture" title="Byzantine architecture">Byzantine</a>. Early <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Orthodox">Eastern Orthodox</a> churches were mainly made of wood, with the simplest form of church becoming known as a <a href="/wiki/Cell_church" title="Cell church">cell church</a>. Major cathedrals often featured scores of small domes, which led some art historians to take this as an indication of the appearance of pre-Christian pagan Slavic temples. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Curitiba_Parque_Tingui.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Curitiba_Parque_Tingui.jpg/220px-Curitiba_Parque_Tingui.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Curitiba_Parque_Tingui.jpg/330px-Curitiba_Parque_Tingui.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Curitiba_Parque_Tingui.jpg/440px-Curitiba_Parque_Tingui.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1536"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Curitiba_Parque_Tingui.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Traditional Ukrainian village <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_architecture" title="Ukrainian architecture">architecture</a> in <a href="/wiki/Curitiba" title="Curitiba">Curitiba</a>, Brazil, which has a large <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_diaspora" title="Ukrainian diaspora">Ukrainian diaspora</a><sup id="cite_ref-423" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-423">[419]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Several examples of these churches survive; however, during the 16th, 17th and 18th centuries, many were externally rebuilt in the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Baroque" title="Ukrainian Baroque">Ukrainian Baroque</a> style (see below). Examples include the grand <a href="/wiki/Saint_Sophia%27s_Cathedral,_Kyiv" class="mw-redirect" title="Saint Sophia's Cathedral, Kyiv">St. Sophia of Kyiv</a>&nbsp;– the year 1017 is the earliest record of foundation laid, <a href="/wiki/Church_of_the_Saviour_at_Berestove" title="Church of the Saviour at Berestove">Church of the Saviour at Berestove</a> – built from 1113 to 1125 and <a href="/wiki/St._Cyril%27s_Monastery,_Kyiv" title="St. Cyril's Monastery, Kyiv">St. Cyril's Church</a>, circa 12th-century. All can still be found in the Ukrainian capital. Several buildings were reconstructed during the late-19th century, including the <a href="/wiki/File:WladimirWolynsk_Uspenski_Cathedral.jpeg" title="File:WladimirWolynsk Uspenski Cathedral.jpeg">Assumption Cathedral</a> in <a href="/wiki/Volodymyr-Volynskyi" title="Volodymyr-Volynskyi">Volodymyr-Volynskyi</a>, built in 1160 and reconstructed in 1896–1900, the <a href="/wiki/File:AX_Chernigiv_Pyatnitska_Church.jpg" title="File:AX Chernigiv Pyatnitska Church.jpg">Paraskevi church in Chernihiv</a>, built in 1201 with reconstruction done in the late 1940s, and the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Gate,_Kyiv" title="Golden Gate, Kyiv">Golden gates in Kyiv</a>, built in 1037 and reconstructed in 1982. The latter's reconstruction was criticised by some art and architecture historians as a revivalist fantasy. Unfortunately little secular or <a href="/wiki/Vernacular_architecture" title="Vernacular architecture">vernacular architecture</a> of <a href="/wiki/Kyivan_Rus%27" class="mw-redirect" title="Kyivan Rus'">Kyivan Rus'</a> has survived. </p>
      <p>As Ukraine became increasingly integrated into the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian Empire</a>, Russian architects had the opportunity to realise their projects in the picturesque landscape that many Ukrainian cities and regions offered. <a href="/wiki/St_Andrew%27s_Church,_Kyiv" title="St Andrew's Church, Kyiv">St. Andrew's Church of Kyiv</a> (1747–1754), built by <a href="/wiki/Bartolomeo_Rastrelli" class="mw-redirect" title="Bartolomeo Rastrelli">Bartolomeo Rastrelli</a>, is a notable example of <a href="/wiki/Baroque" title="Baroque">Baroque</a> architecture, and its location on top of the Kyivan mountain made it a recognisable monument of the city. An equally notable contribution of Rasetrelli was the <a href="/wiki/Mariyinsky_Palace" title="Mariyinsky Palace">Mariyinsky Palace</a>, which was built to be a summer residence to Russian Empress <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_of_Russia" title="Elizabeth of Russia">Elizabeth</a>. During the reign of the last <a href="/wiki/Hetmans_of_Ukrainian_Cossacks" title="Hetmans of Ukrainian Cossacks">Hetman of Ukraine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kirill_Razumovsky" class="mw-redirect" title="Kirill Razumovsky">Kirill Razumovsky</a>, many of the <a href="/wiki/Cossack_Hetmanate" title="Cossack Hetmanate">Cossack Hetmanate</a>'s towns such as <a href="/wiki/Hlukhiv" title="Hlukhiv">Hlukhiv</a>, <a href="/wiki/Baturyn" title="Baturyn">Baturyn</a> and <a href="/wiki/Koselets" class="mw-redirect" title="Koselets">Koselets</a> had grandiose projects built by <a href="/wiki/Andrey_Kvasov" title="Andrey Kvasov">Andrey Kvasov</a>. Russia eventually conquered the south of Ukraine and Crimea, and renamed them as <a href="/wiki/New_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="New Russia">New Russia</a>. New cities such as <a href="/wiki/Mykolayiv" class="mw-redirect" title="Mykolayiv">Nikolayev</a>, <a href="/wiki/Odessa" title="Odessa">Odessa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kherson" title="Kherson">Kherson</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sevastopol" title="Sevastopol">Sevastopol</a> were founded. These would contain notable examples of Imperial Russian architecture. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Kryvyi_Rih_-_apartment_building2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Kryvyi_Rih_-_apartment_building2.jpg/220px-Kryvyi_Rih_-_apartment_building2.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="152" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Kryvyi_Rih_-_apartment_building2.jpg/330px-Kryvyi_Rih_-_apartment_building2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Kryvyi_Rih_-_apartment_building2.jpg/440px-Kryvyi_Rih_-_apartment_building2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4032" data-file-height="2784"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kryvyi_Rih_-_apartment_building2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>An example of a <a href="/wiki/Khrushchyovka" title="Khrushchyovka">Khrushchyovka</a> in <a href="/wiki/Kryvyi_Rih" title="Kryvyi Rih">Kryvyi Rih</a>. Such apartments were built throughout Ukraine during Soviet times and are found in every major city.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 1934, the capital of Soviet Ukraine moved from <a href="/wiki/Kharkiv" title="Kharkiv">Kharkiv</a> to <a href="/wiki/Kyiv" title="Kyiv">Kyiv</a>. Previously, the city was seen as only a regional centre, hence received little attention. All of that was to change, at great price. The first examples of <a href="/wiki/Stalinist_architecture" title="Stalinist architecture">Stalinist architecture</a> were already showing, and, in light of the official policy, a new city was to be built on top of the old one. This meant that much-admired examples such as the <a href="/wiki/St._Michael%27s_Golden-Domed_Monastery" title="St. Michael's Golden-Domed Monastery">St. Michael's Golden-Domed Monastery</a> were destroyed. Even the St. Sophia Cathedral was under threat. Also, the Second World War contributed to the wreckage. After the war, a new project for the reconstruction of central Kyiv transformed <a href="/wiki/Khreshchatyk" title="Khreshchatyk">Khreshchatyk</a> avenue into a notable example of Stalinism in Architecture. However, by 1955, the new politics of architecture once again stopped the project from fully being realised. </p>
      <p>The task for modern Ukrainian architecture is diverse application of modern aesthetics, the search for an architect's own artistic style and inclusion of the existing historico-cultural environment. An example of modern Ukrainian architecture is the reconstruction and renewal of the <a href="/wiki/Maidan_Nezalezhnosti" title="Maidan Nezalezhnosti">Maidan Nezalezhnosti</a> in central Kyiv. Despite the limit set by narrow space within the plaza, the engineers were able to blend together the uneven landscape, and use underground space for a new shopping centre. </p>
      <p>A major project, which may take up most of the 21st century, is the construction of the Kyiv City-Centre on the <a href="/wiki/Rybalskyi_Peninsula" title="Rybalskyi Peninsula">Rybalskyi Peninsula</a>, which, when finished, will include a dense skyscraper park amid the picturesque landscape of the <a href="/wiki/Dnieper_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Dnieper River">Dnieper</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-gradsovet_05_12_07_424-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gradsovet_05_12_07-424">[420]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Ukraine" title="Music of Ukraine">Music of Ukraine</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Cossack_Mamay_1st_half_of_19th_c_(4).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Cossack_Mamay_1st_half_of_19th_c_%284%29.jpg/220px-Cossack_Mamay_1st_half_of_19th_c_%284%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="238" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Cossack_Mamay_1st_half_of_19th_c_%284%29.jpg/330px-Cossack_Mamay_1st_half_of_19th_c_%284%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Cossack_Mamay_1st_half_of_19th_c_%284%29.jpg/440px-Cossack_Mamay_1st_half_of_19th_c_%284%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4737" data-file-height="5125"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Cossack_Mamay_1st_half_of_19th_c_(4).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Cossack_Mamay" title="Cossack Mamay">Cossack Mamay</a> playing a <a href="/wiki/Kobza" title="Kobza">kobza</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Music is a major part of Ukrainian culture, with a long history and many influences. From traditional <a href="/wiki/Folk_music" title="Folk music">folk music</a>, to <a href="/wiki/Classical_music" title="Classical music">classical</a> and <a href="/wiki/Modern_rock" title="Modern rock">modern rock</a>, Ukraine has produced several internationally recognised musicians including <a href="/wiki/Kirill_Karabits" title="Kirill Karabits">Kirill Karabits</a>, <a href="/wiki/Okean_Elzy" title="Okean Elzy">Okean Elzy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ruslana" title="Ruslana">Ruslana</a>. Elements from traditional Ukrainian folk music made their way into Western music and even into modern <a href="/wiki/Jazz" title="Jazz">jazz</a>. </p>
      <p>Ukrainian music sometimes presents a perplexing mix of exotic melismatic singing with chordal harmony. The most striking general characteristic of authentic ethnic Ukrainian folk music is the wide use of minor modes or keys which incorporate augmented 2nd intervals. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:%D0%9B%D0%B8%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%BE_%D0%9C%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B0.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/%D0%9B%D0%B8%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%BE_%D0%9C%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B0.jpg/170px-%D0%9B%D0%B8%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%BE_%D0%9C%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B0.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="266" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/%D0%9B%D0%B8%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%BE_%D0%9C%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B0.jpg/255px-%D0%9B%D0%B8%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%BE_%D0%9C%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B0.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/%D0%9B%D0%B8%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%BE_%D0%9C%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B0.jpg/340px-%D0%9B%D0%B8%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%BE_%D0%9C%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B0.jpg 2x" data-file-width="378" data-file-height="591"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:%D0%9B%D0%B8%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%BE_%D0%9C%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B0.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Mykola_Lysenko" title="Mykola Lysenko">Mykola Lysenko</a> is widely considered to be the father of Ukrainian classical music.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>During the Baroque period, music was an important discipline for those that had received a higher education in Ukraine. It had a place of considerable importance in the curriculum of the <a href="/wiki/Kyiv-Mohyla_Academy" class="mw-redirect" title="Kyiv-Mohyla Academy">Kyiv-Mohyla Academy</a>. Much of the nobility was well versed in music with many Ukrainian Cossack leaders such as (Mazepa, Paliy, Holovatyj, Sirko) being accomplished players of the <a href="/wiki/Kobza" title="Kobza">kobza</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bandura" title="Bandura">bandura</a> or <a href="/wiki/Torban" title="Torban">torban</a>. </p>
      <p>The first dedicated musical academy was set up in Hlukhiv, Ukraine in 1738 and students were taught to sing, play violin and bandura from manuscripts. As a result, many of the earliest composers and performers within the Russian empire were ethnically Ukrainian, having been born or educated in Hlukhiv, or had been closely associated with this music school. See: <a href="/wiki/Dmytro_Bortniansky" class="mw-redirect" title="Dmytro Bortniansky">Dmytro Bortniansky</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maksym_Berezovsky" class="mw-redirect" title="Maksym Berezovsky">Maksym Berezovsky</a> and <a href="/wiki/Artemy_Vedel" title="Artemy Vedel">Artemiy Vedel</a>. </p>
      <p>Ukrainian classical music falls into three distinct categories defined by whether the composer was of Ukrainian ethnicity living in Ukraine, a composer of non-Ukrainian ethnicity who was born or at some time was a citizen of Ukraine, or an ethnic Ukrainian living outside of Ukraine within the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_diaspora" title="Ukrainian diaspora">Ukrainian diaspora</a>. The music of these three groups differs considerably, as do the audiences for whom they cater. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Rapid_Trident_2014_06.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Rapid_Trident_2014_06.jpg/220px-Rapid_Trident_2014_06.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="125" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Rapid_Trident_2014_06.jpg/330px-Rapid_Trident_2014_06.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Rapid_Trident_2014_06.jpg/440px-Rapid_Trident_2014_06.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3792" data-file-height="2155"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Rapid_Trident_2014_06.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Ukrainian dance <i><a href="/wiki/Hopak" title="Hopak">hopak</a></i>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Since the mid-1960s, Western-influenced pop music has been growing in popularity in Ukraine. Folk singer and harmonium player <a href="/wiki/Mariana_Sadovska" title="Mariana Sadovska">Mariana Sadovska</a> is prominent. Ukrainian pop and folk music arose with the international popularity of groups and performers like <a href="/wiki/Vopli_Vidoplyasova" class="mw-redirect" title="Vopli Vidoplyasova">Vopli Vidoplyasova</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dakh_Daughters" title="Dakh Daughters">Dakh Daughters</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dakha_Brakha" class="mw-redirect" title="Dakha Brakha">Dakha Brakha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Dorn" title="Ivan Dorn">Ivan Dorn</a> and <a href="/wiki/Okean_Elzy" title="Okean Elzy">Okean Elzy</a>. </p>
      <p>Modern musical culture of Ukraine is presented both with academic and entertainment music. Ukraine has five conservatories, 6 opera houses, five houses of Chamber Music, Philharmony in all regional centers. </p>
      <p>Ukraine hosted the <a href="/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest_2005" title="Eurovision Song Contest 2005">Eurovision Song Contest 2005</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest_2017" title="Eurovision Song Contest 2017">Eurovision Song Contest 2017</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cinema">Cinema</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Ukraine" title="Cinema of Ukraine">Cinema of Ukraine</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Ukraine has had an influence on the history of the cinema. Ukrainian directors <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Dovzhenko" title="Alexander Dovzhenko">Alexander Dovzhenko</a>, often cited as one of the most important early Soviet filmmakers, as well as being a pioneer of <a href="/wiki/Soviet_montage_theory" title="Soviet montage theory">Soviet montage theory</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dovzhenko_Film_Studios" title="Dovzhenko Film Studios">Dovzhenko Film Studios</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sergei_Parajanov" title="Sergei Parajanov">Sergei Parajanov</a>, Armenian film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and Georgian cinema. He invented his own cinematic style, Ukrainian poetic cinema, which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of socialist realism. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Muratova.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Muratova.jpg/170px-Muratova.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="163" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Muratova.jpg/255px-Muratova.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Muratova.jpg/340px-Muratova.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="1148"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Muratova.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Kira_Muratova" title="Kira Muratova">Kira Muratova</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Other important directors including <a href="/wiki/Kira_Muratova" title="Kira Muratova">Kira Muratova</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sergei_Loznitsa" title="Sergei Loznitsa">Sergei Loznitsa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Myroslav_Slaboshpytskyi" title="Myroslav Slaboshpytskyi">Myroslav Slaboshpytskyi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Larisa_Shepitko" title="Larisa Shepitko">Larisa Shepitko</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sergei_Bondarchuk" title="Sergei Bondarchuk">Sergei Bondarchuk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leonid_Bykov" title="Leonid Bykov">Leonid Bykov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yuri_Ilyenko" title="Yuri Ilyenko">Yuri Ilyenko</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leonid_Osyka" title="Leonid Osyka">Leonid Osyka</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ihor_Podolchak" title="Ihor Podolchak">Ihor Podolchak</a> with his <a href="/wiki/Delirium_(2013_film)" title="Delirium (2013 film)">Delirium</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Maryna_Vroda&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maryna Vroda (page does not exist)">Maryna Vroda</a>. Many Ukrainian actors have achieved international fame and critical success, including: <a href="/wiki/Vera_Kholodnaya" title="Vera Kholodnaya">Vera Kholodnaya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bohdan_Stupka" title="Bohdan Stupka">Bohdan Stupka</a>, <a href="/wiki/Milla_Jovovich" title="Milla Jovovich">Milla Jovovich</a>, <a href="/wiki/Olga_Kurylenko" title="Olga Kurylenko">Olga Kurylenko</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mila_Kunis" title="Mila Kunis">Mila Kunis</a>. </p>
      <p>Despite a history of important and successful productions, the industry has often been characterised by a debate about its identity and the level of European and Russian influence. Ukrainian producers are active in international co-productions and Ukrainian actors, directors and crew feature regularly in Russian (Soviet in past) films. Also successful films have been based on Ukrainian people, stories or events, including <a href="/wiki/Battleship_Potemkin" title="Battleship Potemkin">Battleship Potemkin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Man_with_a_Movie_Camera" title="Man with a Movie Camera">Man with a Movie Camera</a>, <a href="/wiki/Winter_on_Fire:_Ukraine%27s_Fight_for_Freedom" title="Winter on Fire: Ukraine's Fight for Freedom">Winter on Fire: Ukraine's Fight for Freedom</a>, <a href="/wiki/Everything_Is_Illuminated_(film)" title="Everything Is Illuminated (film)">Everything Is Illuminated</a>. </p>
      <p>Ukrainian State Film Agency owns <a href="/wiki/National_Oleksandr_Dovzhenko_Film_Centre" title="National Oleksandr Dovzhenko Film Centre">National Oleksandr Dovzhenko Film Centre</a>, film copying laboratory and archive, takes part in hosting of the <a href="/wiki/Odessa_International_Film_Festival" class="mw-redirect" title="Odessa International Film Festival">Odessa International Film Festival</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Molodist" class="mw-redirect" title="Molodist">Molodist</a> is the only one <a href="/wiki/FIAPF" title="FIAPF">FIAPF</a> accredited International Film Festival held in Ukraine; competition program is devoted to student, first short and first full feature films from all over the world. Held annually in October. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="Media of Ukraine">Media of Ukraine</a>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Ukrayinska_Pravda" title="Ukrayinska Pravda">Ukrayinska Pravda</a><sup id="cite_ref-alexa.com_425-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-alexa.com-425">[421]</a></sup> was founded by <a href="/wiki/Georgiy_Gongadze" title="Georgiy Gongadze">Georgiy Gongadze</a> in April 2000 (the day of the Ukrainian constitutional referendum). Published mainly in Ukrainian with selected articles published in or translated to Russian and English, the newspaper has particular emphasis on the politics of Ukraine. Freedom of the press in Ukraine is considered to be among the freest of the post-Soviet states other than the Baltic states. <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">Freedom House</a> classifies the Internet in Ukraine as "free" and the press as "partly free". Press freedom has significantly improved since the Orange Revolution of 2004. However, in 2010 Freedom House perceived "negative trends in Ukraine". </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Kyiv" title="Kyiv">Kyiv</a> dominates the media sector in Ukraine: the <i><a href="/wiki/Kyiv_Post" title="Kyiv Post">Kyiv Post</a></i> is Ukraine's leading English-language newspaper. National <a href="/wiki/List_of_newspapers_in_Ukraine" title="List of newspapers in Ukraine">newspapers</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Den_(newspaper)" class="mw-redirect" title="Den (newspaper)">Den</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Dzerkalo_Tyzhnia" title="Dzerkalo Tyzhnia">Dzerkalo Tyzhnia</a></i>, tabloids, such as <i><a href="/wiki/The_Ukrainian_Week" title="The Ukrainian Week">The Ukrainian Week</a></i> or <i><a href="/wiki/Focus_(Ukrainian_magazine)" title="Focus (Ukrainian magazine)">Focus</a></i>, and television and radio are largely based there, although <a href="/wiki/Lviv" title="Lviv">Lviv</a> is also a significant national media centre. The National News Agency of Ukraine, <a href="/wiki/Ukrinform" title="Ukrinform">Ukrinform</a> was founded here in 1918. The Ukraine publishing sector, including books, directories and databases, journals, magazines and business media, newspapers and news agencies, has a combined turnover. <a href="/wiki/Sanoma" title="Sanoma">Sanoma</a> publishes Ukrainian editions of such magazines as <i><a href="/wiki/Esquire_(magazine)" title="Esquire (magazine)">Esquire</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Harpers_Bazaar" class="mw-redirect" title="Harpers Bazaar">Harpers Bazaar</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/National_Geographic_Magazine" class="mw-redirect" title="National Geographic Magazine">National Geographic Magazine</a></i>. <a href="/wiki/BBC_Ukrainian" class="mw-redirect" title="BBC Ukrainian">BBC Ukrainian</a> started its broadcasts in 1992. </p>
      <p>Ukrainians listen to radio programming, such as <a href="/wiki/Radio_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="Radio Ukraine">Radio Ukraine</a> or <a href="/wiki/Radio_Liberty" class="mw-redirect" title="Radio Liberty">Radio Liberty</a>, largely commercial, on average just over two-and-a-half hours a day. Several television channels operate, and many websites are popular. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sport">Sport</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Ukraine" title="Sport in Ukraine">Sport in Ukraine</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Andriy_Shevchenko_goal_celebration_Euro_2012_vs_Sweden.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Andriy_Shevchenko_goal_celebration_Euro_2012_vs_Sweden.jpg/220px-Andriy_Shevchenko_goal_celebration_Euro_2012_vs_Sweden.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="148" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Andriy_Shevchenko_goal_celebration_Euro_2012_vs_Sweden.jpg/330px-Andriy_Shevchenko_goal_celebration_Euro_2012_vs_Sweden.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Andriy_Shevchenko_goal_celebration_Euro_2012_vs_Sweden.jpg/440px-Andriy_Shevchenko_goal_celebration_Euro_2012_vs_Sweden.jpg 2x" data-file-width="656" data-file-height="440"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Andriy_Shevchenko_goal_celebration_Euro_2012_vs_Sweden.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Ukrainian footballer <a href="/wiki/Andriy_Shevchenko" title="Andriy Shevchenko">Andriy Shevchenko</a> celebrates a goal against Sweden at Euro 2012
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Ukraine greatly benefited from the Soviet emphasis on <a href="/wiki/Physical_education" title="Physical education">physical education</a>. Such policies left Ukraine with hundreds of stadia, swimming pools, gymnasia and many other athletic facilities.<sup id="cite_ref-426" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-426">[422]</a></sup> The most popular sport is <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">football</a>. The top professional league is the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Premier_League" title="Ukrainian Premier League">Vyscha Liha</a> ("premier league"). </p>
      <p>Many Ukrainians also played for the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_national_football_team" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet national football team">Soviet national football team</a>, most notably <a href="/wiki/Ballon_d%27Or" title="Ballon d'Or">Ballon d'Or</a> winners <a href="/wiki/Ihor_Belanov" class="mw-redirect" title="Ihor Belanov">Ihor Belanov</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oleh_Blokhin" class="mw-redirect" title="Oleh Blokhin">Oleh Blokhin</a>. This award was only presented to one Ukrainian after the dissolution of the Soviet Union, <a href="/wiki/Andriy_Shevchenko" title="Andriy Shevchenko">Andriy Shevchenko</a>. The national team made its debut in the <a href="/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2006 FIFA World Cup">2006 FIFA World Cup</a>, and reached the quarterfinals before losing to eventual champions, <a href="/wiki/Italy_national_football_team" title="Italy national football team">Italy</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:VladimirVitaliy.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/VladimirVitaliy.jpg/170px-VladimirVitaliy.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="228" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/VladimirVitaliy.jpg/255px-VladimirVitaliy.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/VladimirVitaliy.jpg/340px-VladimirVitaliy.jpg 2x" data-file-width="597" data-file-height="800"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:VladimirVitaliy.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Vitali_Klitschko" title="Vitali Klitschko">Vitali Klitschko</a> and his brother, <a href="/wiki/Wladimir_Klitschko" title="Wladimir Klitschko">Wladimir</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Ukrainian <a href="/wiki/Boxing" title="Boxing">boxers</a> are amongst the best in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-427" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-427">[423]</a></sup> The brothers <a href="/wiki/Vitali_Klitschko" title="Vitali Klitschko">Vitali</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wladimir_Klitschko" title="Wladimir Klitschko">Wladimir Klitschko</a> are former <a href="/wiki/Heavyweight" title="Heavyweight">heavyweight</a> world champions who held multiple world titles throughout their careers. Also hailing from Ukraine, <a href="/wiki/Vasyl_Lomachenko" title="Vasyl Lomachenko">Vasyl Lomachenko</a>, a <a href="/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics" title="2008 Summer Olympics">2008</a> and <a href="/wiki/2012_Olympic_games" class="mw-redirect" title="2012 Olympic games">2012 Olympic</a> gold medalist. He is the current <a href="/wiki/Unified_champion" class="mw-redirect" title="Unified champion">unified</a> <a href="/wiki/Lightweight" title="Lightweight">lightweight</a> world champion who ties the record for winning a world title in the fewest professional fights; three. As of September 2018, he is ranked as the world's best active boxer, <a href="/wiki/Pound_for_pound" title="Pound for pound">pound for pound</a>, by <a href="/wiki/Boxing_pound_for_pound_rankings#ESPN" title="Boxing pound for pound rankings">ESPN</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-428" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-428">[424]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Sergey_Bubka" title="Sergey Bubka">Sergey Bubka</a> held the record in the <a href="/wiki/Pole_vault" title="Pole vault">Pole vault</a> from 1993 to 2014; with great strength, speed and gymnastic abilities, he was voted the world's best athlete on several occasions.<sup id="cite_ref-429" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-429">[425]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-430" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-430">[426]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">Basketball</a> is becoming popular in Ukraine. In 2011, Ukraine was granted a right to organize <a href="/wiki/EuroBasket_2015" title="EuroBasket 2015">EuroBasket 2015</a>. Two years later the <a href="/wiki/Ukraine_national_basketball_team" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukraine national basketball team">Ukraine national basketball team</a> finished 6th in <a href="/wiki/EuroBasket_2013" title="EuroBasket 2013">EuroBasket 2013</a> and qualified to <a href="/wiki/2014_FIBA_Basketball_World_Cup" title="2014 FIBA Basketball World Cup">FIBA World Cup</a> for the first time in its history. <a href="/wiki/Euroleague" class="mw-redirect" title="Euroleague">Euroleague</a> participant <a href="/wiki/BC_Budivelnyk" title="BC Budivelnyk">Budivelnyk Kyiv</a> is the strongest professional basketball club in Ukraine. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Chess" title="Chess">Chess</a> is a popular sport in Ukraine. <a href="/wiki/Ruslan_Ponomariov" title="Ruslan Ponomariov">Ruslan Ponomariov</a> is the former world champion. There are about 85 <a href="/wiki/Grandmaster_(chess)" title="Grandmaster (chess)">Grandmasters</a> and 198 <a href="/wiki/International_Masters" class="mw-redirect" title="International Masters">International Masters</a> in Ukraine. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Rugby_league" title="Rugby league">Rugby league</a> is played throughout Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-431" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-431">[427]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Ukraine made its Olympic debut at the <a href="/wiki/1994_Winter_Olympics" title="1994 Winter Olympics">1994 Winter Olympics</a>. So far, <a href="/wiki/Ukraine_at_the_Olympics" title="Ukraine at the Olympics">Ukraine at the Olympics</a> has been much more successful in <a href="/wiki/Summer_Olympics" class="mw-redirect" title="Summer Olympics">Summer Olympics</a> (115 medals in five appearances) than in the <a href="/wiki/Winter_Olympics" class="mw-redirect" title="Winter Olympics">Winter Olympics</a>. Ukraine is currently ranked 35th by number of gold medals won in the <a href="/wiki/All-time_Olympic_Games_medal_count" class="mw-redirect" title="All-time Olympic Games medal count">All-time Olympic Games medal count</a>, with every country above it, except for Russia, having more appearances.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2014)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_cuisine" title="Ukrainian cuisine">Ukrainian cuisine</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Wareniki.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Wareniki.JPG/220px-Wareniki.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Wareniki.JPG/330px-Wareniki.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Wareniki.JPG/440px-Wareniki.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3328" data-file-height="1872"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Wareniki.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Varenyky" class="mw-redirect" title="Varenyky">Varenyky</a> topped with fried onion
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The traditional Ukrainian diet includes chicken, pork, beef, fish and mushrooms. Ukrainians also tend to eat a lot of potatoes, grains, fresh, boiled or pickled vegetables. Popular traditional dishes include <i lang="uk-Latn" title="Ukrainian-language text"><a href="/wiki/Varenyky" class="mw-redirect" title="Varenyky">varenyky</a></i> (boiled dumplings with mushrooms, potatoes, sauerkraut, cottage cheese, cherries or berries), <a href="/wiki/Nalysnyky" class="mw-redirect" title="Nalysnyky">nalysnyky</a> (pancakes with cottage cheese, poppy seeds, mushrooms, caviar or meat), <a href="/wiki/Kapu%C5%9Bniak" class="mw-redirect" title="Kapuśniak">kapuśniak</a> (soup made with meat, potatoes, carrots, onions, cabbage, millet, tomato paste, spices and fresh herbs), <a href="/wiki/Borscht" title="Borscht">borscht</a> (soup made of beets, cabbage and mushrooms or meat), <i lang="uk-Latn" title="Ukrainian-language text"><a href="/wiki/Go%C5%82%C4%85bki" title="Gołąbki">holubtsy</a></i> (stuffed cabbage rolls filled with rice, carrots, onion and minced meat) and <a href="/wiki/Pierogi" title="Pierogi">pierogi</a> (dumplings filled with boiled potatoes and cheese or meat). Ukrainian specialties also include <a href="/wiki/Chicken_Kiev" title="Chicken Kiev">Chicken Kiev</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kyiv_cake" title="Kyiv cake">Kyiv cake</a>. Ukrainians drink <a href="/wiki/Kompot" title="Kompot">stewed fruit</a>, juices, milk, buttermilk (they make cottage cheese from this), mineral water, tea and coffee, beer, wine and <i lang="uk-Latn" title="Ukrainian-language text"><a href="/wiki/Horilka" title="Horilka">horilka</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-432" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-432">[428]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r936637989">.mw-parser-output .portal{border:solid #aaa 1px;padding:0}.mw-parser-output .portal.tleft{margin:0.5em 1em 0.5em 0}.mw-parser-output .portal.tright{margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul{display:table;box-sizing:border-box;padding:0.1em;max-width:175px;background:#f9f9f9;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li{display:table-row}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li>span:first-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li>span:last-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle}</style>

       <li><a href="/wiki/Outline_of_Ukraine" title="Outline of Ukraine">Outline of Ukraine</a>

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1004355016">.mw-parser-output .refbegin{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-hanging-indents>ul{margin-left:0}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-hanging-indents>ul>li{margin-left:0;padding-left:3.2em;text-indent:-3.2em}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-hanging-indents ul,.mw-parser-output .refbegin-hanging-indents ul li{list-style:none}@media(max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .refbegin-hanging-indents>ul>li{padding-left:1.6em;text-indent:-1.6em}}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-100{font-size:100%}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-columns dl,.mw-parser-output .refbegin-columns ol,.mw-parser-output .refbegin-columns ul{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-columns li,.mw-parser-output .refbegin-columns dd{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}</style>
      <div class="refbegin refbegin-columns references-column-width" style="column-width: 30em"> 
       <p><b>a.</b><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_Anone"><a href="#ref_Anone"><b><sup>^</sup></b></a></span> Among the Ukrainians that rose to the highest offices in the Russian Empire were <a href="/wiki/Aleksey_Razumovsky" class="mw-redirect" title="Aleksey Razumovsky">Aleksey Razumovsky</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Bezborodko" title="Alexander Bezborodko">Alexander Bezborodko</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Paskevich" title="Ivan Paskevich">Ivan Paskevich</a>. Among the Ukrainians who greatly influenced the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Orthodox_Church" title="Russian Orthodox Church">Russian Orthodox Church</a> in this period were <a href="/wiki/Stephen_Yavorsky" class="mw-redirect" title="Stephen Yavorsky">Stephen Yavorsky</a>, <a href="/wiki/Feofan_Prokopovich" class="mw-redirect" title="Feofan Prokopovich">Feofan Prokopovich</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dimitry_of_Rostov" title="Dimitry of Rostov">Dimitry of Rostov</a>. </p>
       <p><b>b.</b><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_Bnone"><a href="#ref_Bnone"><b><sup>^</sup></b></a></span> Estimates on the number of deaths vary. Official Soviet data is not available because the Soviet government denied the existence of the famine. See the <a href="/wiki/Holodomor" title="Holodomor">Holodomor</a> article for details. Sources differ on interpreting various statements from different branches of different governments as to whether they amount to the official recognition of the Famine as Genocide by the country. For example, after the statement issued by the Latvian Sejm on 13 March 2008, the total number of countries is given as 19 (according to <i>Ukrainian <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">BBC</a></i>: <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.bbc.com/ukrainian/domestic/story/2008/03/080313_latvia_holodomor_oh.shtml"><span lang="uk" title="Ukrainian-language text">"Латвія визнала Голодомор ґеноцидом"</span></a>), 16 (according to <i><a href="/wiki/Korrespondent" title="Korrespondent">Korrespondent</a></i>, Russian edition: <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://korrespondent.net/ukraine/politics/403002"><span lang="ru" title="Russian-language text">"После продолжительных дебатов Сейм Латвии признал Голодомор геноцидом украинцев"</span></a>), "more than 10" (according to <i>Korrespondent</i>, Ukrainian edition: <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://ua.korrespondent.net/ukraine/403780-latviya-viznala-golodomor-1932-33-rr-genocidom-ukrayinciv"><span lang="uk" title="Ukrainian-language text">"Латвія визнала Голодомор 1932–33 рр. геноцидом українців"</span></a>) Retrieved 27 January 2008. </p>
       <p><b>c.</b><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_C1"><a href="#ref_C1"><b><sup>1</sup></b></a></span> <span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_C2"><a href="#ref_C2"><b><sup>2</sup></b></a></span> These figures are likely to be much higher, as they <b>do not</b> include Ukrainians of other nationalities or Ukrainian Jews, but only <a href="/wiki/Ethnic" class="mw-redirect" title="Ethnic">ethnic</a> Ukrainians, from the Ukrainian SSR. </p>
       <p><b>d.</b><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_Dnone"><a href="#ref_Dnone"><b><sup>^</sup></b></a></span> This figure excludes <a href="/wiki/POW" class="mw-redirect" title="POW">POW</a> deaths. </p>
       <p><b>e.</b><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_Enone"><a href="#ref_Enone"><b><sup>^</sup></b></a></span> Several countries with territory in Europe have a larger total area, but all of those also include territory outside of Europe. Only Russia's European territory is larger than Ukraine. </p>
       <p><b>f.</b><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_F1"><a href="#ref_F1"><b><sup>1</sup></b></a></span> <span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_F2"><a href="#ref_F2"><b><sup>2</sup></b></a></span> <span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_F3"><a href="#ref_F3"><b><sup>3</sup></b></a></span> According to the official <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Census_(2001)" title="Ukrainian Census (2001)">2001 census</a> data (by nationality;<sup id="cite_ref-433" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-433">[429]</a></sup> by language<sup id="cite_ref-434" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-434">[430]</a></sup>) about 75&nbsp;percent of Kyiv's population responded 'Ukrainian' to the native language (ridna mova) census question, and roughly 25&nbsp;percent responded 'Russian'. On the other hand, when the question 'What language do you use in everyday life?' was asked in the 2003 sociological survey, the Kyivans' answers were distributed as follows: 'mostly Russian': 52&nbsp;percent, 'both Russian and Ukrainian in equal measure': 32&nbsp;percent, 'mostly Ukrainian': 14&nbsp;percent, 'exclusively Ukrainian': 4.3&nbsp;percent.<br><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r999302996">.mw-parser-output cite.citation{font-style:inherit}.mw-parser-output .citation q{quotes:"\"""\"""'""'"}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-free a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-free a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/65/Lock-green.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-limited a,.mw-parser-output .id-lock-registration a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-limited a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-registration a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d6/Lock-gray-alt-2.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-subscription a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-subscription a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/aa/Lock-red-alt-2.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .cs1-subscription,.mw-parser-output .cs1-registration{color:#555}.mw-parser-output .cs1-subscription span,.mw-parser-output .cs1-registration span{border-bottom:1px dotted;cursor:help}.mw-parser-output .cs1-ws-icon a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg")right 0.1em center/12px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output code.cs1-code{color:inherit;background:inherit;border:none;padding:inherit}.mw-parser-output .cs1-hidden-error{display:none;font-size:100%}.mw-parser-output .cs1-visible-error{font-size:100%}.mw-parser-output .cs1-maint{display:none;color:#33aa33;margin-left:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-format{font-size:95%}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-left,.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-wl-left{padding-left:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-right,.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-wl-right{padding-right:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .citation .mw-selflink{font-weight:inherit}</style><cite class="citation news cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20171011112630/http://www.wumag.kiev.ua/index2.php?param=pgs20032%2F72">"What language is spoken in Ukraine?"</a>. Welcome to Ukraine. February 2003. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.wumag.kiev.ua/index2.php?param=pgs20032/72">the original</a> on 11 October 2017<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">11 July</span> 2008</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.atitle=What+language+is+spoken+in+Ukraine%3F&amp;rft.date=2003-02&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.wumag.kiev.ua%2Findex2.php%3Fparam%3Dpgs20032%2F72&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AUkraine" class="Z3988"></span> </p>
       <p><b>g.</b><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_Gnone"><a href="#ref_Gnone"><b><sup>^</sup></b></a></span> Such writings were also the base for Russian and Belarusian literature. </p> 
      </div> 
      <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;"> 
      </div> 
      <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: lower-alpha;"> 
       <div class="mw-references-wrap">
        <ol class="references"> 
         <li id="cite_note-5"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-5">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><i>De jure</i> from the Russian Republic, <i>de facto</i> from the Bolshevist <a href="/wiki/Russian_SFSR" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian SFSR">Russian Soviet Republic</a>.</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-6">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">A <a href="/wiki/Cossacks" title="Cossacks">Cossack</a> state, also inofficially referred as "Ukraine" or "Vkraine", "country of Ukraine" by the Ottoman Empire, or "Ukraine or the Land of Cossacks" in Latin</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-12"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-12">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Ukraine also borders <a href="/wiki/Crimea" title="Crimea">Crimea</a> to its south, which <a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation" title="Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation">Russia annexed from Ukraine in 2014</a>, though Ukraine <a href="/wiki/Territorial_dispute" title="Territorial dispute">still continues to claim the territory</a> as its integral part.</span> </li> 
        </ol>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2> 
      <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;"> 
       <div class="mw-references-wrap">
        <ol class="references"> 
         <li id="cite_note-154"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-154">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Pavol_Demes" class="mw-redirect" title="Pavol Demes">Pavol Demes</a> and Joerg Forbrig estimate in 2006 that only <a href="/wiki/United_States_dollar" title="United States dollar">US$</a>130,000 out of a total of US$1.56 million in <a href="/wiki/Pora" class="mw-redirect" title="Pora">Pora</a> came from donors outside Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-ORRNC_153-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ORRNC-153">[150]</a></sup></span> </li>

        <li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://conventions.coe.int/Treaty/Commun/ListeDeclarations.asp?NT=148&amp;CM=8&amp;DF=23/01/05&amp;CL=ENG&amp;VL=1">"List of declarations made with respect to treaty No. 148 (Status as of: 21/9/2011)"</a>. <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a><span class="reference-accessdate">.         <li id="cite_note-19"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-19">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

        <li id="cite_note-zaporizhia-59"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-zaporizhia_59-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFKrupnytsky_B._and_Zhukovsky_A." class="citation web cs1">Krupnytsky B. and Zhukovsky A. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkPath=pages\Z\A\ZaporizhiaThe.htm">"Zaporizhia, The"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Encyclopedia_of_Ukraine" title="Encyclopedia of Ukraine">Encyclopedia of Ukraine</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate">.         <li id="cite_note-Basilevsky2016-81"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Basilevsky2016_81-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFAlexander_Basilevsky2016" class="citation book cs1">Alexander Basilevsky (2016). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=oa_uCwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA9"><i>Early Ukraine: A Military and Social History to the Mid–19th Century</i></a>. U.S. Department of State<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">22 September</span> 2014</span>. <q>Voting procedures and the veto power of permanent members of the Security Council were finalized at the <a href="/wiki/Yalta_Conference" title="Yalta Conference">Yalta Conference</a> in 1945 when Roosevelt and Stalin agreed that the veto would not prevent discussions by the Security Council. Roosevelt agreed to General Assembly membership for Ukraine and Byelorussia while reserving the right, which was never exercised, to seek two more votes for the United States.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=United+Nations&amp;rft.pub=U.S.+Department+of+State&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2F2001-2009.state.gov%2Fr%2Fpa%2Fho%2Ftime%2Fwwii%2F17604.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AUkraine" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li>

        <li id="cite_note-132"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-132">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFHrabovsky2010" class="citation news cs1">Hrabovsky, Serhiy (1 October 2010). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.radiosvoboda.org/content/article/2174129.html"><bdi lang="uk">Судові абсурди, або Котляревський знову сміється</bdi></a> [Judicial absurdities, or Kotliarevsky is laughing again] (in Ukrainian). radiosvoboda.org<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">6 April</span> 2016</span>. <q>(Translation) These words handed down on the decision of the Constitutional Court of Ukraine (CCU) regarding cancelling the political reforms of 2004 are worthy of being inscribed in the annals of world jurisprudence. It turns out that "the stability of the constitutional order" will not be changed by the will of the voters, or even by Parliament, but by the decision of 18 persons.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.atitle=%D0%A1%D1%83%D0%B4%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%96+%D0%B0%D0%B1%D1%81%D1%83%D1%80%D0%B4%D0%B8%2C+%D0%B0%D0%B1%D0%BE+%D0%9A%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%BB%D1%8F%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B2%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9+%D0%B7%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%83+%D1%81%D0%BC%D1%96%D1%94%D1%82%D1%8C%D1%81%D1%8F&amp;rft.date=2010-10-01&amp;rft.aulast=Hrabovsky&amp;rft.aufirst=Serhiy&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.radiosvoboda.org%2Fcontent%2Farticle%2F2174129.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AUkraine" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li>

        <li id="cite_note-279"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-279">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

        <li id="cite_note-296"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-296">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFBarr2017" class="citation news cs1">Barr, Caelainn (26 April 2017). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.theguardian.com/inequality/datablog/2017/apr/26/inequality-index-where-are-the-worlds-most-unequal-countries">"Inequality index: where are the world's most unequal countries?"</a>. <i>The Guardian</i>. <a href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a>&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/0261-3077">0261-3077</a><span class="reference-accessdate">.         <li id="cite_note-297"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-297">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.pewforum.org/2017/05/10/religious-belief-and-national-belonging-in-central-and-eastern-europe/">"Religious Belief and National Belonging in Central and Eastern Europe"</a>. <i>Pew Research Center's Religion &amp; Public Life Project</i>. 10 May 2017.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Pew+Research+Center%27s+Religion+%26+Public+Life+Project&amp;rft.atitle=Religious+Belief+and+National+Belonging+in+Central+and+Eastern+Europe&amp;rft.date=2017-05-10&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.pewforum.org%2F2017%2F05%2F10%2Freligious-belief-and-national-belonging-in-central-and-eastern-europe%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AUkraine" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li>

        <li id="cite_note-411"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-411">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080418030322/http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-30078/Ukraine">"Interwar Soviet Ukraine"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Encyclop%C3%A6dia_Britannica" title="Encyclopædia Britannica">Encyclopædia Britannica</a></i>. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-30078/Ukraine">the original</a> on 18 April 2008<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">12 September</span> 2007</span>. <q>In all, some four-fifths of the Ukrainian cultural elite was repressed or perished in the course of the 1930s</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Encyclop%C3%A6dia+Britannica&amp;rft.atitle=Interwar+Soviet+Ukraine&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.britannica.com%2Feb%2Farticle-30078%2FUkraine&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AUkraine" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
        <li id="cite_note-412"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-412">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20071218133116/http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9037405">"Gorbachev, Mikhail"</a>. Encyclopædia Britannica (fee required). Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9037405">the original</a> on 18 December 2007<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">30 July</span> 2008</span>. <q>Under his new policy of glasnost ("openness"), a major cultural thaw took place: freedoms of expression and of information were significantly expanded; the press and broadcasting were allowed unprecedented candour in their reportage and criticism; and the country's legacy of Stalinist totalitarian rule was eventually completely repudiated by the government</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Gorbachev%2C+Mikhail&amp;rft.pub=Encyclop%C3%A6dia+Britannica+%28fee+required%29&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.britannica.com%2Feb%2Farticle-9037405&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AUkraine" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li>

        <li id="cite_note-gradsovet_05_12_07-424"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-gradsovet_05_12_07_424-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
          <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130510032158/http://archunion.com.ua/sovet-2005/gradsovet_05_12_07.shtml"><bdi lang="ru">Архитекторы Киева – Градостроительное обоснование внесения изменений в генеральный план развития г.        <ul>
        <li>Aslund, Anders, and Michael McFaul. <i>Revolution in Orange: The Origins of Ukraine's Democratic Breakthrough</i> (2006)</li> 
        <li>Birch, Sarah. <i>Elections and Democratization in Ukraine</i> Macmillan, 2000 <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.questia.com/read/98201086/elections-and-democratization-in-ukraine">online edition</a></li>
